<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 4: Architecture<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/"><i>Course 4 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course4.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=4&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++4&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>Architecture Design</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4b.html">Architecture Studies</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4c.html">Art, Culture and Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4d.html">Building Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4e.html">Computation</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4f.html">History, Theory and Criticism of Architecture and Art</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4g.html">Thesis and UROP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Architecture Design</h2>
<a name="4.021"></a>
<p><h3>4.021 Introduction to Architecture Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m4a.html#4.02A">4.02A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the architecture design process. Develops skills that enable design creativity, thinking, representation, and development. Beginning with abstract exercises, introduces techniques for designing and developing 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional form and space in architecture. Limited to 25; preference to Course 4 majors and minors, and first- and second-year students.
<br><I>L. Bello</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.022"></a>
<p><h3>4.022 Architecture Design Foundations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4022">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4022</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>MW2-5</i> (STUDIO) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides the foundations for architectural design. Focuses on design methodologies, formal and spatial analysis and the translation of creative conceptual strategies into architectural design propositions. Instruction in design skills, including digital and analogue representational techniques. Preference to Course 4 majors and minors.
<br><I>S. Ghantous</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.023"></a>
<p><h3>4.023 Architecture Design Studio I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.021">4.021</a>, <a href="m4a.html#4.022">4.022</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-12
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides instruction in architectural design and project development within design constraints including architectural program and site. Students engage the design process through various 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional media. Working directly with representational and model making techniques, students gain experience in the conceptual, formal, spatial and material aspects of architecture. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided. Preference to Course 4 majors and minors.
<br><I>C. Parreno Alonso</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.024"></a>
<p><h3>4.024 Architecture Design Studio II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.023">4.023</a>, <a href="m4d.html#4.401">4.401</a>, <a href="m4e.html#4.500">4.500</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-12
<br><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4024">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4024</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TRF1-5</i> (STUDIO) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides instruction in architectural design and project development with an emphasis on social, cultural, or civic programs. Builds on foundational design skills with more complex constraints and contexts. Integrates aspects of architectural theory, building technology, and computation into the design process. Preference to Course 4 majors.
<br><I>W. O'Brien</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.025"></a>
<p><h3>4.025 Architecture Design Studio III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.024">4.024</a>, <a href="m4d.html#4.440">4.440</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-12
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides instruction in more advanced architectural design projects. Students develop integrated design skills as they negotiate the complex issues of program, site, and form in a specific cultural context. Focuses on how architectural concepts and ideas translate into built environments that transform the public sphere. Studio designed to prepare students for graduate studies in the field. Preference to Course 4 majors.
<br><I>C. Parreno Alonso</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.02A"></a>
<p><h3>4.02A Introduction to Architecture Design Intensive
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-5-2
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m4a.html#4.021">4.021</A>
<br>IAP URL: <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-402a">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-402a</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the architecture design process. Develops skills that enable design creativity, thinking, representation, and development. Beginning with abstract exercises, introduces techniques for designing and developing 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional form and space in architecture. Limited to 25; preference to Course 4 majors and minors, and first- and second-year students.
<br><I>J. Jih</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.031"></a>
<p><h3>4.031 Design Studio: Objects and Interaction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4031">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4031</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=7">7-434</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Overview of design as the giving of form, order, and interactivity to the objects that define our daily life. Follows the path from project to interactive product. Covers the overall design process, preparing students for work in a hands-on studio learning environment. Emphasizes design development and constraints. Topics include the analysis of objects; interaction design and user experience; design methodologies, current dialogues in design; economies of scale vs. means; and the role of technology in design. Provides a foundation in prototyping skills such as carpentry, casting, digital fabrication, electronics, and coding.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Coelho</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Coelho</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.032"></a>
<p><h3>4.032 Design Studio: Information and Visualization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4a.html#4.033">4.033</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4032">http://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4032</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N52">N52-337</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to working with information, data and visualization in a hands-on studio learning environment. Studies the history and theory of information, followed by a series of projects in which students apply the ideas directly. Progresses though basic data analysis, visual design and presentation, and more sophisticated interaction techniques. Topics include storytelling and narrative, choosing representations, understanding audiences, and the role of designers working with data. Graduate students are expected to complete additional assignments.
<br>Fall: <I>R. The</I><br>Spring: <I>Glen Cummings</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.033"></a>
<p><h3>4.033 Design Studio: Information and Visualization
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4a.html#4.032">4.032</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4032">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4032</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N52">N52-337</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to working with information, data and visualization in a hands-on studio learning environment. Studies the history and theory of information, followed by a series of projects in which students apply the ideas directly. Progresses though basic data analysis, visual design and presentation, and more sophisticated interaction techniques. Topics include storytelling and narrative, choosing representations, understanding audiences, and the role of designers working with data. Graduate students are expected to complete additional assignments.
<br><I>Glen Cummings</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.091"></a>
<p><h3>4.091 Independent Study in Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Supplementary work on individual or group basis. Registration subject to prior arrangement for subject matter and supervision by staff.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Caso</I><br>IAP: <I>R. Caso</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Caso</I><br>No textbook information available (IAP 2018); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2018)
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.092"></a>
<p><h3>4.092 Independent Study in Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.093"></a>
<p><h3>4.093 Independent Study in Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="4.094"></a>
<p><h3>4.094 Independent Study in Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Supplementary work on individual or group basis. Registration subject to prior arrangement for subject matter and supervision by staff.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Caso</I><br>IAP: <I>R. Caso</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Caso</I><br>No textbook information available (IAP 2018); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2018)
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.100"></a>
<p><h3>4.100 Design Workshop: Fabricating Function
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-3-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Through design and making, students discover the relationship between mind and hand and acquire the elemental skills necessary to research, conceptualize, represent, develop and fabricate design solutions to real-world problems. Covers the steps to creating and fabricating a functional object critical to understanding design and provides useful tools for problem solving in general. Lab fee. Limited to 15; preference to freshmen.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.101"></a>
<p><h3>4.101 Design Studio: Introduction to Design Techniques and Technologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4101">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4101</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TR3-5</i> (STUDIO)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces core principles, techniques and technologies for design across a wide range of media in a studio environment. Explores ideas related to form, materials, tools, systems, and structures through project-based exercises. Develops familiarity with design process, critical observation, and tools for the translation of design concepts into digital and physical constructs. Utilizing traditional and contemporary tools, faculty across various design disciplines expose students to a unique cross-section of inquiry.
<br><I>J. Jih</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.105"></a>
<p><h3>4.105 Geometric Disciplines and Architecture Skills I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive introduction to architectural design tools and process, taught through a series of short exercises. Together with 4.107, covers a broad range of topics relating to the discourse of geometry as the basis of architectural design process. Focuses on projective drawings, explicit 3D modeling, and the reciprocity between representation and materialization. Lectures, workshops, and pin-ups address the architectural arguments intrinsic to geometry and its representation. Restricted to level one MArch students.
<br><I>J. Lamere</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.109"></a>
<p><h3>4.109 Materials and Fabrication for Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-3-3
<br>IAP URL: <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-4109">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-4109</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides the material system knowledge and fabrication process skills to successfully engage with all areas of the shop, from precision handwork to multi-axis computer numerically controlled (CNC) machining. Progresses through a series of basic exercises that introduce the material and workflow, concluding with more complex problems that explore opportunities and issues specific to architecture. Lab fee. Limited to 12; preference to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>J. Lavallee</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.110"></a>
<p><h3>4.110 Design Across Scales and Disciplines
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.650">MAS.650</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4110">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4110</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E14">E14-633</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W EVE (7-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-217</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-450A</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-450B</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Inspired by Charles and Ray Eames' canonical <i>Powers of Ten</i>, explores the relationship between science and engineering through the lens of design. Examines how transformations in science and technology have influenced design thinking and vice versa. Provides interdisciplinary skills and methods to represent, model, design and fabricate objects, machines, and systems using new computational and fabrication tools. Aims to develop methodologies for design research of interdisciplinary problems. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version of the subject. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 4 minors.
<br><I>N. Oxman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.117"></a>
<p><h3>4.117 Creative Computation
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Architecture has a deep history of integrating drawing and making; however, the Albertian orthographic mandate has produced a schism in this reciprocal relationship. It has relegated architects to producing representations of architectural intent while handing over the responsibility of means and methods of making to builders. With recent advances in digital technologies, this relationship is once again becoming entangled. In doing so, it brings into question the renewed roles of architects, designers, creators, computers, and makers. Subject disputes the compartmentalization present in architectural practice today. Through the tools of computation and fabrication, it empowers students to design as architect, engineer, and craftsman.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.119"></a>
<p><h3>4.119 Preparation for Undergraduate Architecture Design Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.024">4.024</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selection of thesis topic, defining method of approach, and preparation of thesis proposal for BSA degree in architecture. Weekly class meeting as well as individual conference with faculty.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.120"></a>
<p><h3>4.120 Furniture Making Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4120">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4120</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides instruction in designing and building a functional piece of furniture from an original design. Develops woodworking techniques from use of traditional hand tools to digital fabrication. Gives students the opportunity to practice design without using a building program or code. Surveys the history of furniture making and includes site visits to local collections and artists/craftsmen. Limited to 12; preference to Course 4 students.
<br><I>C. Dewart</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.123"></a>
<p><h3>4.123 Architectural Assemblies
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4123">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4123</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-133</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fosters a holistic understanding of the architectural-building cycle, enabling students to build upon the history of design and construction to make informed decisions towards developing innovative building systems. Includes an overview of materials, processing methods, and their formation into building systems across cultures. Looks at developing innovative architectural systems focusing on the building envelope. Seeks to adapt processes from the aerospace and automotive industries to investigate buildings as prefabricated design and engineering assemblies. Synthesizes knowledge in building design and construction systems, environmental and structural design, and geometric and computational approaches.
<br><I>J. Klein</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.130"></a>
<p><h3>4.130 Architectural Design Theory and Methodologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies design as an interrogative technique to examine material sciences, media arts and technology, cultural studies, computation and emerging fabrication protocols. Provides in-depth, theoretical grounding to the notion of 'design' in architecture, and to the consideration of contemporary design methodologies, while encouraging speculation on emerging design thinking. Topical focus varies with instructor. May be repeated for credit with permission of department.
<br><I>J. Leung</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.140"></a>
<p><h3>4.140[J] How to Make (Almost) Anything
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.943">6.943[J]</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.863">MAS.863[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-9-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a practical hands-on introduction to digital fabrication, including CAD/CAM/CAE, NC machining, 3-D printing and scanning, molding and casting, composites, laser and waterjet cutting, PCB design and fabrication; sensors and actuators; mixed-signal instrumentation, embedded processing, and wired and wireless communications. Develops an understanding of these capabilities through projects using them individually and jointly to create functional systems.
<br><I>N. Gershenfeld</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.141"></a>
<p><h3>4.141 How to Design (almost) Anything
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4a.html#4.142">4.142</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-9-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4141">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4141</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N52">N52-GARAGE</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental design principles and practices, such as seeing, sketching, storytelling, prototyping and performing, as a way to demystify design as a discipline. Taught by a diverse group of faculty, students dive deeply into design through lectures, labs, and weekly project assignments. Technique-based class intended for students without a design background enables more effective collaboration with designers and the ability to apply the foundations of design to any discipline. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br><I>S. Tibbitts</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.142"></a>
<p><h3>4.142 How to Design (almost) Anything

<br>Introduces fundamental design principles and practices, such as seeing, sketching, storytelling, prototyping and performing, as a way to demystify design as a discipline. Taught by a diverse group of faculty, students dive deeply into design through lectures, labs, and weekly project assignments. Technique-based class intended for students without a design background enables more effective collaboration with designers and the ability to apply the foundations of design to any discipline. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.

<a name="4.151"></a>
<p><h3>4.151 Architecture Design Core Studio I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Establishes foundational processes, techniques and attitudes towards architectural design. Includes projects of increasing scope and complexity engaging issues of structure, circulation, program, organization, building systems, materiality and tectonics. Develops methods of representation that incorporate both analogue and digital drawings and models. First in a sequence of design subjects, which must be taken in order. Limited to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>W. O'Brien</I><br>
<a name="4.152"></a>
<p><h3>4.152 Architecture Design Core Studio II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.151">4.151</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4152">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4152</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TRF1-5</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TRF1-5</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TRF1-5</i> (STUDIO)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Builds on Core I skills and expands the constraints of the architectural problem to include issues of urban site logistics, cultural and programmatic material (inhabitation and human factors), and long span structures. Two related projects introduce a range of disciplinary issues, such as working with precedents, site, sectional and spatial proposition of the building, and the performance of the outer envelope. Emphasizes the clarity of intentions and the development of appropriate architectural and representational solutions. Limited to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>M. Ibanez</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="4.153"></a>
<p><h3>4.153 Architecture Design Core Studio III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.152">4.152</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary approach to design through studio design problems that engage the domains of building technology, computation, and the cultural/historical geographies of energy. Uses different modalities of thought to examine architectural agendas for 'sustainability'; students position their work with respect to a broader understanding of the environment and its relationship to society and technology. Students develop a project with a comprehensive approach to programmatic organization, energy load considerations, building material assemblies, exterior envelope and structure systems. Limited to second-year MArch students.
<br><I>S. Kennedy</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.154"></a>
<p><h3>4.154 Architecture Design Option Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.153">4.153</a>
<br>Units: 0-10-11
<br><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subjects">http://architecture.mit.edu/subjects</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Offers a broad range of advanced-level investigations in architectural design in various contexts, including international sites. Integrates theoretical and technological discourses into specific topics. Studio problems may include urbanism and city scale strategies, habitation and urban housing systems, architecture in landscapes, material investigations and new production technologies, programmatic and spatial complex building typologies, and research centered studies. Mandatory lottery process.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Stewart</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Stewart</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.162"></a>
<p><h3>4.162 Introductory Urban Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-10-11
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based introduction to urban observation, research, analysis, and design. Focuses on urban elements, urban and architectural interventions, and landscape in existing cities. Emphasizes city form, sustainability, and social conditions. Projects require both conventional and digital techniques. Preference to Urbanism SMArchS students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.163"></a>
<p><h3>4.163[J] Urban Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.332">11.332[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.162">4.162</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The design of urban environments. Strategies for change in large areas of cities, to be developed over time, involving different actors. Fitting forms into natural, man-made, historical, and cultural contexts; enabling desirable activity patterns; conceptualizing built form; providing infrastructure and service systems; guiding the sensory character of development. Involves architecture and planning students in joint work; requires individual designs or design and planning guidelines.
<br><I>R. Segal</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.173"></a>
<p><h3>4.173[J] Beijing Urban Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.307">11.307[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-18-0
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design studio that includes architects and city planners working in teams on a contemporary development project of importance in China. Students analyze conditions, explore alternatives, and synthesize architecture, city design, and implementation plans. Lectures and brief study tours expose students to history and contemporary issues of urbanism in China. Offered every other summer in residence at Tsinghua University, Beijing, involving students and faculty from both schools. Limited to 10.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.180"></a>
<p><h3>4.180 Architectural Design Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.023">4.023</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Subject in design inquiry taught in studio format treating selected issues of the built world in depth. The problem may be prototypical or a particular aspect of a whole project, but always interdisciplinary in nature.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.181"></a>
<p><h3>4.181 Architectural Design Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">; first half of term

<a name="4.183"></a><a name="4.184"></a><a name="4.185"></a>
<h3>4.183-4.185 Architectural Design Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>IAP URL: <b>4.183:</b> <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-4183">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-4183</a><br><b>4.185:</b> <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-4185">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-4185</a><br>Spring URL: <b>4.183:</b> <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4183">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4183</a><br><b>4.184:</b> <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4184">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4184</a>
<br><b>4.183:</b> Consult instructor <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s--><br><b>4.184:</b> TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses design inquiry in a studio format. In-depth consideration of selected issues of the built world. The problem may be prototypical or a particular aspect of a whole project, but is always interdisciplinary in nature.
<br>Fall: <I>Y. Daniels</I><br>IAP: <I>Gabriel Kozlowski Maia</I><br><b>4.183:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>4.184:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>4.185:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.189"></a>
<p><h3>4.189 Preparation for MArch Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4189">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4189</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Preparatory research development leading to a well-conceived proposition for the MArch design thesis. Students formulate a cohesive thesis argument and critical project using supportive research and case studies through a variety of representational media, critical traditions, and architectural/artistic conventions. Group study in seminar and studio format, with periodic reviews supplemented by conference with faculty and a designated committee member for each individual thesis. Restricted to MArch students.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Norford</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Dutta</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.190"></a>
<p><h3>4.190 Practical Experience in Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical experience through summer internships secured by the student in the field of architecture, urbanism, digital design, art, or building technology. Before registering for this subject, students must have an employment offer and complete an application signed by the advisor. Upon completion of the work, students must submit an employer evaluation form available from the departmental academic office. Registration limited to two summers. Restricted to Course 4 students
<br>Fall: <I>R. Caso</I><br>IAP: <I>P. Pettigrew</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.191"></a>

<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Supplementary work on individual or group basis. Registration subject to prior arrangement for subject matter and supervision by staff.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Caso</I><br>IAP: <I>R. Caso</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Caso</I><br>No textbook information available (IAP 2018); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2018)
</p><!--end-->
