<h1 align="center">Course 5: Chemistry<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://chemistry.mit.edu"><i>Course 5 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course5.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=5&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++5&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>5.00-5.4999</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m5b.html">5.50-5.999, plus UROP and Theses</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="5.00"></a>
<p><h3>5.00[J] Energy Technology and Policy:  From Principles to Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.929">6.929[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.579">10.579[J]</A>, <A HREF="m22c.html#22.813">22.813[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops analytical skills to lead a successful technology implementation with an integrated approach that combines technical, economical and social perspectives. Considers corporate and government viewpoints as well as international aspects, such as nuclear weapons proliferation and global climate issues.  Discusses technologies such as oil and gas, nuclear, solar, and energy efficiency. Limited to 100.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.03"></a>
<p><h3>5.03 Principles of Inorganic Chemistry I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-231</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) or <i>TR4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents principles of chemical bonding and molecular structure, and their application to the chemistry of representative elements of the periodic system.
<br><I>A. Radosevich</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=5.03');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
<a name="5.04"></a>
<p><h3>5.04 Principles of Inorganic Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Systematic presentation of the chemical applications of group theory. Emphasis on the formal development of the subject and its applications to the physical methods of inorganic chemical compounds. Against the backdrop of electronic structure, the electronic, vibrational, and magnetic properties of transition metal complexes are presented and their investigation by the appropriate spectroscopy described.
<br><I>Y. Surendranath</I><br>
<a name="5.05"></a>
<p><h3>5.05 Principles of Inorganic Chemistry III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.04">5.04</a></I>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of main group (s and p block) element chemistry with an emphasis on synthesis, structure, bonding, and reaction mechanisms.
<br><I>C. Cummins</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.061"></a>
<p><h3>5.061 Principles of Organometallic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A comprehensive treatment of organometallic compounds of the transition metals with emphasis on structure, bonding, synthesis, and mechanism.
<br><I>C. Cummins, R. Schrock</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=5.061');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.062"></a>
<p><h3>5.062 Principles of Bioinorganic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Delineates principles that form the basis for understanding how metal ions function in biology. Includes the choice, uptake and assembly of metal-containing units; metal-induced folding of biomolecules; control of metal ion concentrations in cells; electron-transfer chemistry; atom and group transfer chemistry; protein tuning of metal properties; and applications to diagnosis and treatment of disease. Introduces additional topics to expose students to exciting new advances in the field, such as medicinal application of inorganic chemistry; multi-component enzyme systems (e.g.,nitrogenase, hydrogenase, and photosystem II); and metalloprotein engineering and design (e.g., the conversion by mutagenesis of existing metalloprotein scaffolds to achieve novel functions).
<br><I>D. Suess</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.063"></a>
<p><h3>5.063 Organometallic Compounds in Catalytic Reactions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.061">5.061</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An exploration of organometallic chemistry from the perspective of catalytic reactions in organic and polymer chemistry.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.067"></a>
<p><h3>5.067 Crystal Structure Refinement
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.068">5.068</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.069">5.069</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-3-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical aspects of crystal structure determination from data collection strategies to data reduction and basic and advanced refinement problems of organic and inorganic molecules.
<br><I>P. Mueller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.068"></a>
<p><h3>5.068 Physical Inorganic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.04">5.04</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses the physical methods used to probe the electronic and geometric structures of inorganic compounds, with additional techniques employed in the characterization of inorganic solids and surfaces. Includes vibrational spectroscopy, solid state and solution magnetochemical methods, M&ouml;ssbauer spectroscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, electrochemical methods, and a brief survey of surface techniques. Applications to current research problems in inorganic and solid-state chemistry.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.069"></a>
<p><h3>5.069 Crystal Structure Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.04">5.04</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8.30-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to X-ray crystallography: symmetry in real and reciprocal space, space and Laue groups, geometry of diffraction, structure factors, phase problem, direct and Patterson methods, electron density maps, structure refinement, crystal growth, powder methods, limits of diffraction methods, structure data bases.
<br><I>P. Mueller</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=5.069');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.07"></a>
<p><h3>5.07[J] Biological Chemistry I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.507">20.507[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Chemical and physical properties of the cell and its building blocks. Structures of proteins and principles of catalysis. The chemistry of organic/inorganic cofactors required for chemical transformations within the cell. Basic principles of metabolism and regulation in pathways, including glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, fatty acid synthesis/degradation, pentose phosphate pathway, Krebs cycle and oxidative phosphorylation, DNA replication, and transcription and translation.
<br><I>A. Klibanov, E. Nolan</I><br>
<a name="5.08"></a>
<p><h3>5.08[J] Biological Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.08">7.08[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.80">7.80</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>; <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) or <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More advanced treatment of biochemical mechanisms that underlie biological processes.  Topics include macromolecular machines such as the ribosome, the proteosome, fatty acid synthases as a paradigm for polyketide synthases and non-ribosomal polypeptide synthases, and polymerases. Emphasis is on experimental methods used to unravel these processes and how these processes fit into the cellular context and coordinate regulation.
<br><I>E. Nolan, R. Raines</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.111"></a>
<p><h3>5.111 Principles of Chemical Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/chem.gif" alt="Chemistry" title="Chemistry" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.091">3.091</A>, <A HREF="m5a.html#5.112">5.112</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.5111">CC.5111</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.3091">ES.3091</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5111">ES.5111</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5112">ES.5112</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-119</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-4101</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=13">13-4101</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to chemistry, with emphasis on basic principles of atomic and molecular electronic structure, thermodynamics, acid-base and redox equilibria, chemical kinetics, and catalysis. Introduction to the chemistry of biological, inorganic, and organic molecules.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Hong, K. Nelson</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Bawendi, B. Pentelute</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=5.111');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.112"></a>
<p><h3>5.112 Principles of Chemical Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/chem.gif" alt="Chemistry" title="Chemistry" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m3a.html#3.091">3.091</A>, <A HREF="m5a.html#5.111">5.111</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.5111">CC.5111</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.3091">ES.3091</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5111">ES.5111</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.5112">ES.5112</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to chemistry for students with an unusually strong background in chemistry. Knowledge of calculus equivalent to 18.01 is recommended. Emphasis on basic principles of atomic and molecular electronic structure, thermodynamics, acid-base and redox equilibria, chemical kinetics, and catalysis. Applications of basic principles to problems in metal coordination chemistry, organic chemistry, and biological chemistry.
<br><I>S. Ceyer, R. Schrock</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.12"></a>
<p><h3>5.12 Organic Chemistry I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.512">CC.512</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>) or <i>MW3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-155</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-153</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-156</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to organic chemistry. Development of basic principles to understand the structure and reactivity of organic molecules. Emphasis on substitution and elimination reactions and chemistry of the carbonyl group. Introduction to the chemistry of aromatic compounds.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Johnson, C. Rotsides</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Danheiser, C. Rotsides</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=5.12');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
<a name="5.13"></a>
<p><h3>5.13 Organic Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on synthesis, structure determination, mechanism, and the relationships between structure and reactivity. Selected topics illustrate the role of organic chemistry in biological systems and in the chemical industry.
<br><I>M. Movassaghi</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.24"></a>
<p><h3>5.24[J] Archaeological Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3b.html#3.985">3.985[J]</A>, <A HREF="m12a.html#12.011">12.011[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a> or <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Pressing issues in archaeology as an anthropological science. Stresses the natural science and engineering methods archaeologists use to address these issues. Reconstructing time, space, and human ecologies provides one focus; materials technologies that transform natural materials to material culture provide another. Topics include 14C dating, ice core and palynological analysis, GIS and other remote sensing techniques for site location, organic residue analysis, comparisons between Old World and New World bronze production, invention of rubber by Mesoamerican societies, analysis and conservation of Dead Sea Scrolls.
<br><I>H. Lechtman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.301"></a>
<p><h3>5.301 Chemistry Laboratory Techniques
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-4-1 [P/D/F]
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://chemistry.mit.edu/freshmen-pre-freshmen/chemistry-lab-techniques-5301">http://chemistry.mit.edu/freshmen-pre-freshmen/chemistry-lab-techniques-5301</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical training in basic chemistry laboratory techniques. Intended to provide freshmen with the skills necessary to undertake original research projects in chemistry. Freshmen only. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Dolhun</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018JA&Subject=5.301');" >Textbooks (IAP 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.310"></a>
<p><h3>5.310 Laboratory Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a></I>
<br>Units: 2-8-2
<br>1st lec mandatory. Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces experimental chemistry for students who are not majoring in Course 5. Principles and applications of chemical laboratory techniques, including preparation and analysis of chemical materials, measurement of pH, gas and liquid chromatography, visible-ultraviolet spectrophotometry, infrared spectroscopy, kinetics, data analysis, and elementary synthesis. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Dolhun</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Dolhun</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=5.310');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.351"></a>
<p><h3>5.351 Fundamentals of Spectroscopy
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/PartLab.gif" alt="Partial Lab" title="Partial Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">; partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 1-2-1
<br>Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students carry out an experiment that introduces fundamental principles of the most common types of spectroscopy, including UV-visible absorption and fluorescence, infrared, and nuclear magnetic resonance. Emphasizes principles of how light interacts with matter, a fundamental and hands-on understanding of how spectrometers work, and what can be learned through spectroscopy about prototype molecules and materials. Students record and analyze spectra of small organic molecules, native and denatured proteins, semiconductor quantum dots, and laser crystals. Satisfies 4 units of Institute Laboratory credit.
<br>Fall: <I>K. Nelson</I><br>Spring: <I>K. Nelson</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.352"></a>
<p><h3>5.352 Synthesis of Coordination Compounds and Kinetics
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/PartLab.gif" alt="Partial Lab" title="Partial Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">; partial term
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.351">5.351</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-2-1
<br>Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students carry out an experiment that provides an introduction to the synthesis of simple coordination compounds and chemical kinetics. Illustrates cobalt coordination chemistry and its transformations as detected by visible spectroscopy. Students observe isosbestic points in visible spectra, determine the rate and rate law, measure the rate constant at several temperatures, and derive the activation energy for the aquation reaction. Satisfies 4 units of Institute Laboratory credit.
<br>Fall: <I>Y. Surendranath</I><br>Spring: <I>Y. Surendranath</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.353"></a>
<p><h3>5.353 Fabrication of a Polymeric Light-Emitting Device
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/PartLab.gif" alt="Partial Lab" title="Partial Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">; partial term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5a.html#5.35">5.35</A>)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.352">5.352</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-2-1
<br>Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on an experiment involving the polymerization of a monomer to produce a high molecular weight conjugated polymer of the poly(phenylene vinylene) family. Students fully characterize the material and use it to fabricate a light-emitting device by spin coating and metal evaporation methods in an inert glovebox environment. Compares the optical absorption and photoemission of the polymer device to the electrically-induced emission. Studies the theory of electroluminescent and photovoltaic devices, including relative energy levels of organic materials and the nature charge carriers in organic polymers. Satisfies 4 units of Institute Laboratory credit.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Swager</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Rotsides</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.361"></a>
<p><h3>5.361 Expression and Purification of Enzyme Mutants
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.352">5.352</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a> <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.362">5.362</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-1-1
<br>Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students use biochemical techniques for protein expression and DNA manipulation of Bcr-Abl kinase, which is inhibited by the blockbuster drug Gleevec in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia. Uses various standard bioanalytical and biochemical methods in lab to characterize and produce this protein.
<br><I>B. Pentelute</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.362"></a>
<p><h3>5.362 Kinetics of Enzyme Inhibition
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.352">5.352</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a> <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.361">5.361</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-2-2
<br>Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students study the activity and structure of the domains developed in 5.361 to understand the role of mutations in the development of resistance to Gleevec. Students assay both mutant and wild-type Abl kinase domains for phosphorylation activity to determine enzyme kinetics and the inhibition efficacy of Gleevec. They conduct additional testing on kinase activity of Gleevec-resistant mutants in the presence of other potential inhibitors. Uses structure-viewing programs to enable analysis of the mechanistic basis of Bcr-Abl inhibition and Gleevec-resistance.
<br><I>B. Pentelute</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.363"></a>
<p><h3>5.363 Organic Structure Determination
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/PartLab.gif" alt="Partial Lab" title="Partial Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">; partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-2-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces modern methods for the elucidation of the structure of organic compounds. Students carry out transition metal-catalyzed coupling reactions, based on chemistry developed in the Buchwald laboratory, using reactants of unknown structure. Students also perform full spectroscopic characterization - by proton and carbon NMR, IR, and mass spectrometry of the reactants - and carry out coupling products in order to identify the structures of each compound. Other techniques include transfer and manipulation of organic and organometallic reagents and compounds, separation by extraction, and purification by column chromatography. Satisfies 4 units of Institute Laboratory credit.
<br><I>J. Van Humbeck</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.371"></a>
<p><h3>5.371 Continuous Flow Chemistry:  Sustainable Conversion of Reclaimed Vegetable Oil into Biodiesel
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.363">5.363</a>
<br>Units: 1-2-1
<br>Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the theoretical and practical fundamentals of continuous flow synthesis, wherein pumps, tubes, and connectors are used to conduct chemical reactions instead of flasks, beakers, etc. Focuses on a catalytic reaction that converts natural vegetable oil into biodiesel that can be used in a variety of combustion engines. Provides instruction in several important organic chemistry experimental techniques, including purification by extraction, rotary evaporation, acid-base titration, gas chromatography (GC), and <SUP>1</SUP>H NMR.
<br><I>T. Jamison</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.372"></a>
<p><h3>5.372 Chemistry of Renewable Energy
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.352">5.352</a>
<br>Units: 1-2-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the electrochemical processes that underlie renewable energy storage and recovery. Students investigate charge transfer reactions at electrode surfaces that are critical to the operation of advanced batteries, fuel cells, and electrolyzers. Develops basic theory behind inner- and outer-sphere charge transfer reactions at interfaces and applies this theory to construct mechanistic models for important energy conversion reactions including the reduction of O<SUB>2</SUB> to water and the reduction of protons to H<SUB>2</SUB>. Students will also synthesize new catalytic materials for these reactions and investigate their relative performance.
<br><I>Y. Surendranath</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.373"></a>
<p><h3>5.373 Dinitrogen Cleavage
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.03">5.03</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.363">5.363</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="m5b.html#5.61">5.61</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-2-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the research area of small-molecule activation by transition-element complexes. Covers techniques such as glove-box methods for synthesis for exclusion of oxygen and water; filtration, reaction mixture concentration, and recrystallization under a dinitrogen atmosphere and under static vacuum. Characterization methods include proton NMR spectroscopy of both paramagnetic and diamagnetic systems, Evans method magnetic susceptibility measurement, UV-Vis spectroscopy, and infrared spectroscopy of a metal-nitrogen triple bond system.
<br><I>C. Cummins</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.381"></a>
<p><h3>5.381 Quantum Dots
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.61">5.61</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.353">5.353</a>
<br>Units: 1-1-1
<br>Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-119</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers synthesis of a discrete size series of quantum dots, followed by synthesis of a single size of core/shell quantum dots utilizing air-free Schlenk manipulation of precursors. Uses characterization by absorption and fluorescence spectroscopies to rationalize the compositional/size dependence of the shell on the electronic structure of the quantum dots. Students acquire time traces of the fluorescence of single core and core/shell quantum dots using single molecule spectroscopic tools. The fluorescence on/off blinking distribution observed will be fit to a standard model. Students use Matlab for computational modeling of the electron and hole wavefunction in core and core/shell quantum dots. Analyzes several commercial applications of quantum dot technologies.
<br><I>M. Bawendi</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.382"></a>
<p><h3>5.382 Time- and Frequency-resolved Spectroscopy of Photosynthesis
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.61">5.61</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.361">5.361</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-2-2
<br>Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-119</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses time- and frequency-resolved fluorescence measurements to investigate photosynthetic light harvesting and energy transfer.
<br><I>G. Schlau-Cohen</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.383"></a>
<p><h3>5.383 Fast-flow Peptide and Protein Synthesis
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; <a href="m5a.html#5.363">5.363</a>
<br>Units: 1-2-1
<br>Safety lecture mandatory. 2/6 or 2/7 at 1 pm room TBA. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-119</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-430</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops understanding of both the theory and practice of fundamental techniques in biological chemistry, including chemical reactivity (amide-bond formation, solid phase synthesis, disulfide bond formation, and protecting group chemistry); separation science for purification and analysis, such as preparative HPLC and MALDI-TOF MS; and protein structure-function relationships (protein folding and binding). Periodically, guest lecturers from the local biotech research community will describe practical applications in industry.
<br><I>B. Pentelute</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.43"></a>
<p><h3>5.43 Advanced Organic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m5b.html#5.53">5.53</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reaction mechanisms in organic chemistry: methods of investigation, relation of structure to reactivity, and reactive intermediates.  Photochemistry and organometallic chemistry, with an emphasis on fundamental reactivity, mechanistic studies, and applications in organic chemistry.
<br><I>T. Swager</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.44"></a>
<p><h3>5.44 Organometallic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.43">5.43</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.47">5.47</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.061">5.061</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examination of the most important transformations of organotransition-metal species. Emphasizes basic mechanisms of their reactions, structure-reactivity relationships, and applications in synthesis.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.45"></a>
<p><h3>5.45 Heterocyclic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.511">5.511</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.53">5.53</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (5.30-8.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the chemistry of heterocyclic compounds. Surveys synthesis and reactivity of the major classes of heterocyclic organic compounds. Discusses the importance of these molecules in the pharmaceutical and other industries.
<br><I>S. Buchwald</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=5.45');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.46"></a>
<p><h3>5.46 NMR Spectroscopy and Organic Structure Determination
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.43">5.43</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applications of 1-D and 2-D <SUP>1</SUP>H and <SUP>13</SUP>C NMR spectroscopy to organic structure determination.
<br><I>W. Massefski</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="5.47"></a>
<p><h3>5.47 Tutorial in Organic Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.43">5.43</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Systematic review of basic principles concerned with the structure and transformations of organic molecules. Problem-solving workshop format. The program is intended primarily for first-year graduate students with a strong interest in organic chemistry. Meets during the month of September.
<br><I>R. Danheiser</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
