<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Program of research leading to the writing of a PhD thesis. To be arranged by the student and the appropriate MIT faculty member.
<br>Fall: <I>Staff</I><br>IAP: <I>Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>Staff</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<h3>Biology</h3>
<a name="7.50"></a>
<p><h3>7.50 Method and Logic in Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor or <I>Coreq: <a href="m7a.html#7.51">7.51</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.52">7.52</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Logic, experimental design and methods in biology, using discussions of the primary literature to discern the principles of biological investigation in making discoveries and testing hypotheses.  In collaboration with faculty, students also apply those principles to generate a potential research project, presented in both written and oral form. Limited to Course 7 graduate students.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.51"></a>
<p><h3>7.51 Principles of Biochemical Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of biochemistry, emphasizing structure, equilibrium studies, kinetics, informatics, single-molecule studies, and experimental design. Topics include macromolecular binding and specificity, protein folding and unfolding, allosteric systems, transcription factors, kinases, membrane channels and transporters, and molecular machines.
<br><I>A. Keating, R. T. Sauer</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.52"></a>
<p><h3>7.52 Genetics for Graduate Students
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles and approaches of genetic analysis, including Mendelian inheritance and prokaryotic genetics, yeast genetics, developmental genetics, neurogenetics, and human genetics.
<br><I>A. Amon, D. Housman, H. R. Horvitz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.540"></a>
<p><h3>7.540[J] Frontiers in Chemical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5b.html#5.54">5.54[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.554">20.554[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to current research at the interface of chemistry, biology, and bioengineering. Topics include imaging of biological processes, metabolic pathway engineering, protein engineering, mechanisms of DNA damage, RNA structure and function, macromolecular machines, protein misfolding and disease, metabolomics, and methods for analyzing signaling network dynamics. Lectures are interspersed with class discussions and student presentations based on current literature.
<br><I>L. Kiessling</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.546"></a>
<p><h3>7.546[J] Science and Business of Biotechnology
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15b.html#15.480">15.480[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.586">20.586[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the new types of drugs and other therapeutics in current practice and under development, the financing and business structures of early-stage biotechnology companies, and the evaluation of their risk/reward profiles. Includes a series of live case studies with industry leaders of both established and emerging biotechnology companies as guest speakers, focusing on the underlying science and engineering as well as core financing and business issues. Students must possess a basic background in cellular and molecular biology.
<br><I>A. Lo, H. Lodish</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.546');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.547"></a>
<p><h3>7.547[J] Principles and Practice of Drug Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.547">10.547[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.136">15.136[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.920">HST.920[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.620">IDS.620[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Description and critical assessment of the major issues and stages of developing a pharmaceutical or biopharmaceutical. Drug discovery, preclinical development, clinical investigation, manufacturing and regulatory issues considered for small and large molecules. Economic and financial considerations of the drug development process. Multidisciplinary perspective from faculty in clinical; life; and management sciences; as well as industry guests.
<br><I>S. Finkelstein</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.548"></a>
<p><h3>7.548[J] Advances in Biomanufacturing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.53">10.53[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with 7.458[J], <A HREF="m10a.html#10.03">10.03[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar examines how biopharmaceuticals, an increasingly important class of pharmaceuticals, are manufactured. Topics range from fundamental bioprocesses to new technologies to the economics of biomanufacturing. Also covers the impact of globalization on regulation and quality approaches as well as supply chain integrity. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Sinskey</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Sinskey</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.549"></a>
<p><h3>7.549[J] Case Studies and Strategies in Drug Discovery and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.137">15.137[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.486">20.486[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.916">HST.916[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><a href="http://mit.edu/7.549j">http://mit.edu/7.549j</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Aims to develop appreciation for the stages of drug discovery and development, from target identification, to the submission of preclinical and clinical data to regulatory authorities for marketing approval. Following introductory lectures on the process of drug development, students working in small teams analyze how one of four new drugs or drug candidates traversed the discovery/development landscape. For each case, an outside expert from the sponsoring drug company or pivotal clinical trial principal investigator provides guidance and critiques the teams' presentations to the class.
<br><I>A. Wood</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.55"></a>
<p><h3>7.55 Case Studies in Modern Experimental Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-253</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on enhancing students' ability to analyze, design and present experiments, emphasizing modern techniques. Class discussions begin with papers that developed or utilized contemporary approaches (e.g., quantitative microscopy, biophysical and molecular genetic methods) to address important problems in biology. Each student prepares one specific aim of a standard research proposal for a project that emphasizes research strategy, experimental design, and writing.
<br><I>L. Guarente,  F. Solomon</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.57"></a>
<p><h3>7.57 Quantitative Biology for Graduate Students
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the fundamental concepts and tools of quantitative approaches to molecular and cellular biology.  Covers a wide range of mathematical, computational, and statistical methods, although no previous expertise in these areas is required. Focuses on understanding quantitative approaches through the analysis of particular problems and examples drawn from classical genetics, molecular biology, cell biology, genomics, and systems biology.
<br><I>P. Gupta, A. Regev, G. W. Li</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.58"></a>
<p><h3>7.58 Molecular Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>W11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-169</a>) or <i>W EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>M 10-11</i> <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Detailed analysis of the biochemical mechanisms that control the maintenance, expression, and evolution of prokaryotic and eukaryotic genomes. Topics covered in lecture and readings of relevant literature include: gene regulation, DNA replication, genetic recombination, and mRNA translation. Logic of experimental design and data analysis emphasized. Presentations include both lectures and group discussions of representative papers from the literature. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>U. RajBhandary, E. Calo</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.58');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.59"></a>
<p><h3>7.59[J] Teaching College-Level Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.95">1.95[J]</A>, <A HREF="m5b.html#5.95">5.95[J]</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.395">8.395[J]</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.094">18.094[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2c.html#2.978">2.978</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Participatory seminar focuses on the knowledge and skills necessary for teaching science and engineering in higher education. Topics include theories of adult learning; course development; promoting active learning, problemsolving, and critical thinking in students; communicating with a diverse student body; using educational technology to further learning; lecturing; creating effective tests and assignments; and assessment and evaluation. Students research and present a relevant topic of particular interest. Appropriate for both novices and those with teaching experience.
<br><I>J. Rankin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.60"></a>
<p><h3>7.60 Cell Biology: Structure and Functions of the Nucleus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Eukaryotic genome structure, function, and expression, processing of RNA, and regulation of the cell cycle.  Emphasis on the techniques and logic used to address important problems in nuclear cell biology. Lectures on broad topic areas in nuclear cell biology and discussions on representative recent papers.
<br><I>R. Young, L. Boyer</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.61"></a>
<p><h3>7.61 Eukaryotic Cell Biology: Principles and Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes methods and logic used to analyze structure and function of eukaryotic cells in diverse systems (e.g., yeast, fly, worm, mouse, human; development, stem cells, neurons). Combines lectures and in-depth roundtable discussions of literature readings with the active participation of faculty experts. Focuses on membranes (structure, function, traffic), organelles, the cell surface, signal transduction, cytoskeleton, cell motility and extracellular matrix. Ranges from basic studies to applications to human disease, while stressing critical analysis of experimental approaches. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>M. Krieger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.62"></a>
<p><h3>7.62 Microbial Physiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.21">7.21</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Biochemical properties of bacteria and other microorganisms that enable them to grow under a variety of conditions. Interaction between bacteria and bacteriophages. Genetic and metabolic regulation of enzyme action and enzyme formation. Structure and function of components of the bacterial cell envelope. Protein secretion with a special emphasis on its various roles in pathogenesis. Additional topics include bioenergetics, symbiosis, quorum sensing, global responses to DNA damage, and biofilms. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>G. C. Walker, A. J. Sinskey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.63"></a>
<p><h3>7.63 Immunology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.23">7.23</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive survey of molecular, genetic, and cellular aspects of the immune system. Topics include innate and adaptive immunity; cells and organs of the immune system; immunoglobulin, T cell receptor, and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins and genes; development and functions of B and T lymphocytes; immune responses to infections and tumors; hypersensitivity, autoimmunity, and immunodeficiencies. Particular attention to the development and function of the immune system as a whole, as studied by modern methods and techniques. Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.64"></a>
<p><h3>7.64 Molecular Mechanisms, Pathology and Therapy of Human Neuromuscular Disorders
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (3-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-146</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Investigates the molecular and clinical basis of central nervous system and neuromuscular disorders with particular emphasis on strategies for therapeutic intervention. Considers the in-depth analysis of clinical features, pathological mechanisms, and responses to current therapeutic interventions. Covers neurodegenerative diseases, such as Huntington's disease, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, Amyotropic Lateral Schlerosis, Frontal Temporal Dementia, and neuromuscular disorders, such as Myotonic Dystrophy, Facio Scapular Humoral Dystrophy, and Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.
<br><I>D. Housman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.65"></a>
<p><h3>7.65[J] Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience Core I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.015">9.015[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey and primary literature review of major topic areas in molecular and cellular neurobiology. Covers neurogenomics, nervous system formation, axonal pathfinding, cytoskeletal regulation, synapse formation, neurotransmitter release, and cellular neurophysiology. Includes lectures and weekly paper write-ups, together with student presentations and discussion of primary literature. A final two-page research write-up is also due at the end of the term.
<br><I>T. Littleton</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.66"></a>
<p><h3>7.66 Molecular Basis of Infectious Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.26">7.26</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-135</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-574</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-142</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the principles of host-pathogen interactions with an emphasis on infectious diseases of humans. Presents key concepts of pathogenesis through the study of various human pathogens. Includes critical analysis and discussion of assigned readings.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>D. Kim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.67"></a>
<p><h3>7.67[J] Genetic Methods in Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.322">9.322[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="http://mit.edu/7.67j/">http://mit.edu/7.67j/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents selected topics in which genetic analysis informs neurobiological issues, including action potential conduction and synaptic release in Drosophila, axon guidance in nematodes and Drosophila, olfaction and orienting behavior in nematodes. Studies hippocampal and cortical circuitry and function in mice, as well as genetically-determined and genetically-influenced human traits and diseases. Reviews methods such as mutagenesis, gene knockouts and transgene constructs, tissue-specific expression vectors, optically, chemically and thermally-inducible gene activation and inactivation.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.68"></a>
<p><h3>7.68[J] Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience Core II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.013">9.013[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-4062</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey and primary literature review of major areas in molecular and cellular neurobiology. Covers genetic neurotrophin signaling, adult neurogenesis, G-protein coupled receptor signaling, glia function, epigenetics, neuronal and homeostatic plasticity, neuromodulators of circuit function, and neurological/psychiatric disease mechanisms. Includes lectures and exams, and involves presentation and discussion of primary literature. 9.015 recommended, though the core subjects can be taken in any sequence.
<br><I>G. Feng</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.69"></a>
<p><h3>7.69[J] Developmental Neurobiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.181">9.181[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with 7.49[J], <A HREF="m9a.html#9.18">9.18[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.011">9.011</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers molecular control of neural specification, formation of neuronal connections, construction of neural systems, and the contributions of experience to shaping brain structure and function. Topics include: neural induction and pattern formation, cell lineage and fate determination, neuronal migration, axon guidance, synapse formation and stabilization, activity-dependent development and critical periods, development of behavior. In addition to final exam, analysis and presentation of  research papers required for final grade. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Students taking graduate version complete additional readings that will be addressed in their mid-term and final exams.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.70"></a>
<p><h3>7.70 Regulation of Gene Expression
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar examines basic principles of biological regulation of gene expression. Focuses on examples that underpin these principles, as well as those that challenge certain long-held views. Topics covered may include the role of transcription factors, enhancers, DNA modifications, non-coding RNAs, and chromatin structure in the regulation of gene expression and mechanisms for epigenetic inheritance of transcriptional states. Limited to 40.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.71"></a>
<p><h3>7.71 Structural and Biophysical Analysis of Biological Macromolecules
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5b.html#5.78">5.78</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a>; <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>; <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; permission of instructor.
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/5.78/www/">http://web.mit.edu/5.78/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1.30-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies theory and practice of 3-D analysis of macromolecules, using X-ray crystallography and EM analysis. Covers biophysical methods to characterize molecular properties and interactions. Includes discussion of current literature and, importantly, practical exercises in crystallization, model building, and the use of shared instrumentation available at MIT. Meets with 5.78 when offered concurrently.
<br><I>C. Drennan, T. Schwartz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.71');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.72"></a>
<p><h3>7.72 Principles and Frontiers of Developmental Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers fundamental principles and frontiers of animal development. Focuses on molecular mechanisms, experimental approaches, evolutionary context, human disorders, and topics of societal importance. Compares vertebrate (mouse, chick, frog, fish) and invertebrate (fly, worm) models. Modules include patterning and asymmetry of the body plan, cell type determination and diversity, organogenesis, morphogenesis, maternal control, organismal growth, stem cells, tissue engineering, and issues in human development.
<br><I>H. Sive, T. Orr-Weaver</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.73"></a>
<p><h3>7.73 Principles of Chemical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.41">7.41</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-112</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Spanning the fields of biology, chemistry and engineering, class addresses the principles of chemical biology and its application of chemical and physical methods and reagents to the study and manipulation of biological systems. Topics include bioorthogonal reactions and activity-based protein profiling, small molecule inhibitors and chemical genetics, fluorescent probes for biological studies, and unnatural amino acid mutagenesis. Also covers chemical biology approaches for studying dynamic post-translational modification reactions, natural product biosynthesis and mutasynthesis, and high-throughput drug screening.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>B. Imperiali, J. K. Weng</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.74"></a>
<p><h3>7.74[J] Topics in Biophysics and Physical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8b.html#8.590">8.590[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.416">20.416[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides broad exposure to research in biophysics and physical biology, with emphasis on the critical evaluation of scientific literature. Weekly meetings include in-depth discussion of scientific literature led by distinct faculty on active research topics. Each session also includes brief discussion of non-research topics including effective presentation skills, writing papers and fellowship proposals, choosing scientific and technical research topics, time management, and scientific ethics.
<br><I>N. Fakhri</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.76"></a>
<p><h3>7.76 Topics in Macromolecular Structure and Function
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth analysis and discussion of classic and current literature, with an emphasis on the structure, function, and mechanisms of proteins and other biological macromolecules.
<br><I>C. Drennan, R. T. Sauer</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.77"></a>
<p><h3>7.77 Nucleic Acids, Structure, Function, Evolution and Their Interactions with Proteins
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.51">7.51</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys primary literature, focusing on biochemical, biophysical, genetic, and combinatorial approaches for understanding nucleic acids.  Topics include the general properties, functions, and structural motifs of DNA and RNA; RNAs as catalysts and as regulators of gene expression; RNA editing and surveillance, and the interaction of nucleic acids with proteins, such as zinc-finger proteins, modification enzymes, aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases and other proteins of the translational machinery. Includes some lectures but is mostly analysis and discussion of current literature in the context of student presentations.
<br><I>D. Bartel, U. RajBhandary</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.80"></a>
<p><h3>7.80 Biological Chemistry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m5a.html#5.08">5.08[J]</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.08">7.08[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>; <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) or <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More advanced treatment of biochemical mechanisms that underlie biological processes. Topics include macromolecular machines such as the ribosome, the proteosome, fatty acid synthases as a paradigm for polyketide synthases and non-ribosomal polypeptide synthases, and polymerases. Emphasis is on experimental methods used to unravel these processes and how these processes fit into the cellular context and coordinate regulation.  Students taking the graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>E. Nolan, R. Raines</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.81"></a>
<p><h3>7.81[J] Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8b.html#8.591">8.591[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.32">7.32</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to cellular and population-level systems biology with an emphasis on synthetic biology, modeling of genetic networks, cell-cell interactions, and evolutionary dynamics.  Cellular systems include genetic switches and oscillators, network motifs, genetic network evolution, and cellular decision-making.  Population-level systems include models of pattern formation, cell-cell communication, and evolutionary systems biology. Students taking graduate version explore the subject in more depth.
<br><I>J. Gore</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.82"></a>
<p><h3>7.82 Topics of Mammalian Development and Genetics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (3-6 PM)</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar covering embryologic, molecular, and genetic approaches to development in mice and humans. Topics include preimplantation development; gastrulation; embryonic stem cells, gene targeting and nuclear  reprogramming of somatic cells; genomic imprinting; X-inactivation; sex determination; and germ cells.
<br><I>R. Jaenisch, R. Young</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.85"></a>
<p><h3>7.85 The Hallmarks of Cancer
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.45">7.45</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a comprehensive introduction to the fundamentals of cancer biology and cancer treatment. Topics include cancer genetics, genomics, and epigenetics; familial cancer syndromes; signal transduction, cell cycle control, and apoptosis; cancer metabolism; stem cells and cancer; metastasis; cancer immunology and immunotherapy; conventional and molecularly-targeted therapies; and early detection and prevention. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>T. Jacks, M. Vander Heiden</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.87"></a>
<p><h3>7.87 Protein Folding and Misfolding in Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.51">7.51</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.52">7.52</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers protein folding, misfolding, aggregation, and amyloid formation in the context of biological systems. Addresses topics such as chaperone structure and function, biofilm formation by bacteria, protein-folding diseases (including but not limited to Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and Huntington's diseases), the process of therapeutics discovery for drugs  and biologics. Features guest lectures and Skype discussions with international leaders in the field. Students present papers covering mutually agreed-upon topics of interest.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.89"></a>
<p><h3>7.89[J] Topics in Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mCSBa.html#CSB.100">CSB.100[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar based on research literature. Papers covered are selected to illustrate important problems and varied approaches in the field of computational and systems biology, and to provide students a framework from which to evaluate new developments. Preference to first-year CSB PhD students.
<br><I>C. Burge</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.930"></a>
<p><h3>7.930[J] Research Experience in Biopharma
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.930">20.930[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-10-0
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides exposure to industrial science and develops skills necessary for success in such an environment. Under the guidance of an industrial mentor, students participate in on-site research at a local biopharmaceutical company where they observe and participate in industrial science. Serves as a real-time case study to internalize the factors that shape R&D in industry, including the purpose and scope of a project, key decision points in the past and future, and strategies for execution. Students utilize company resources and work with a scientific team to contribute to the goals of their assigned project; they then present project results to the company and class, emphasizing the logic that dictated their work and their ideas for future directions. Lecture component focuses on professional development.
<br><I>S. Clarke</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.931"></a>
<p><h3>7.931 Independent Study in Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Program of study or research to be arranged with a department faculty member.
<br>Fall: <I>Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.932"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Fall: <I>Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.933"></a>
<p><h3>7.933 Research Rotations in Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to faculty participating in the Biology graduate program through a series of lab rotations, which provide broad exposure to biology research at MIT. Students select a lab for thesis research by the end of their first year. Limited to students in the Biology graduate program.
<br>Fall: <I>Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.934"></a>
<p><h3>7.934 Teaching Experience in Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For qualified graduate students in the Biology graduate program interested in teaching.  Classroom or laboratory teaching under the supervision of a faculty member.
<br>Fall: <I>Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.935"></a>
<p><h3>7.935 Responsible Conduct in Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Sessions focus on the responsible conduct of science. Considers recordkeeping and reporting; roles of mentor and mentee; authorship, review, and confidentiality; resolving conflicts; misfeasance and malfeasance; collaborations, competing interests, and intellectual property; and proper practices in the use of animal and human subjects. Limited to second-year graduate students in Biology.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.941"></a>
<p><h3>7.941 Research Problems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Directed research in a field of biological science, but not contributory to graduate thesis.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.942"></a>
<h3>7.942 Research Problems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.95"></a>
<p><h3>7.95 Cancer Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.85">7.85</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (Whitehead-7TH)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced seminar involving intensive analysis of historical and current developments in cancer biology. Topics address principles of apoptosis, principles of cancer biology, cancer genetics, cancer cell metabolism, tumor immunology, and therapy. Detailed analysis of research literature, including important reports published in recent years. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. Weinberg, O. Yilmaz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=7.95');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.98"></a>
<p><h3>7.98[J] Neural Plasticity in Learning and Memory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.301">9.301[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.98/">http://web.mit.edu/7.98/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-5305</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examination of the role of neural plasticity during learning and memory of invertebrates and mammals. Detailed critical analysis of the current literature of molecular, cellular, genetic, electrophysiological, and behavioral studies. Student-directed presentations and discussions of original papers supplemented by introductory lectures. Juniors and seniors require instructor's permission.
<br><I>S. Tonegawa</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="7.S930"></a>
