</p><!--end-->
<a name="12.URG"></a>
<p><h3>12.URG Undergraduate Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Undergraduate research opportunities in Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Jordan</I><br>IAP: <I>M. Jordan</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Jordan</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually (IAP 2018); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2018)
</p><!--end-->
<a name="12.IND"></a>
<p><h3>12.IND Independent Study
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m12a.html#12.TIP">12.TIP</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Independent reading, laboratory, or fieldwork in Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences. To be arranged by student and an appropriate EAPS faculty member. A written report may be required at the discretion of the advisor. Units arranged should reflect the project requirements.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="12.TIP"></a>
<p><h3>12.TIP Thesis Preparation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Definition of and early-stage work on the thesis project. Students develop a written research proposal and begin writing the supporting text of the thesis concurrent with conducting research for the thesis project. Supervision of the writing continues into the spring term which concludes with an oral presentation of the research results.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Connor</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Connor</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="12.THU"></a>
<p><h3>12.THU Undergraduate Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m12a.html#12.TIP">12.TIP</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Program of research leading to the writing of a thesis; to be arranged by the student and an appropriate MIT faculty member.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Jordan</I><br>IAP: <I>M. Jordan</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Jordan</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually (IAP 2018); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2018)
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 14: Economics<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://econ-www.mit.edu/"><i>Course 14 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course14.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=14&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++14&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>14.00-14.399 plus UROP</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m14b.html">14.40-14.999 and UROP and Thesis</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>General Economics and Theory</h2>
<a name="14.003"></a>
<p><h3>14.003 Microeconomic Theory and Public Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.03">14.03</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies microeconomic theory to analysis of public policy. Builds from microeconomic model of consumer behavior; extends to operation of single and multiple markets and analysis of why markets sometimes fail. Empirical examples to evaluate theory, focusing on the casual effects of policy interventions on economic outcomes. Topics include minimum wages and employment, food stamps and consumer welfare, economics of risk and safety regulation, the value of education, and gains from international trade.  Graduate students are expected to complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.01"></a>
<p><h3>14.01 Principles of Microeconomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>No lecture for recs 04-05. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-217</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>) or <i>MWF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) or <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=37">37-212</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces microeconomic concepts and analysis, supply and demand analysis, theories of the firm and individual behavior, competition and monopoly, and welfare economics. Applications to problems of current economic policy. Taught in two formats - lecture/recitation and recitation only - each with 3 sessions per week. Same content and exams.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Gruber</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Harris</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.01');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.02"></a>
<p><h3>14.02 Principles of Macroeconomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an overview of macroeconomic issues including the determination of national income, economic growth, unemployment, inflation, interest rates, and exchange rates.  Introduces basic macroeconomic models and illustrates key principles through applications to the experience of the US and other economies. Explores a range of current policy debates, such as the economic effects of monetary and fiscal policy, the causes and consequences of the 2008 global financial crisis, and the factors that influence long-term growth in living standards. Lectures are recorded and available for students with scheduling conflicts.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Caballero</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Poterba</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.02');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.03"></a>
<p><h3>14.03 Microeconomic Theory and Public Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.003">14.003</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies microeconomic theory to analysis of public policy. Builds from microeconomic model of consumer behavior; extends to operation of single and multiple markets and analysis of why markets sometimes fail. Empirical examples to evaluate theory, focusing on the casual effects of policy interventions on economic outcomes. Topics include minimum wages and employment, food stamps and consumer welfare, economics of risk and safety regulation, the value of education, and gains from international trade.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Autor</I><br>Spring: <I>N. Agarwal</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.04"></a>
<p><h3>14.04 Intermediate Microeconomic Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of consumer and producer decisions including analysis of competitive and monopolistic markets. Price-based partial and general equilibrium analysis. Introduction to game theory as a foundation for the strategic analysis of economic situations. Imperfect competition, dynamic games among firms. Failures of general equilibrium theory and their resolutions: externalities, public goods, incomplete information settings, signaling, screening, insurance, alternative market mechanisms, auctions, design of markets.
<br><I>J. Toikka</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.05"></a>
<p><h3>14.05 Intermediate Macroeconomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>; <a href="m14a.html#14.02">14.02</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses the tools of macroeconomics to investigate various macroeconomic issues in depth. Topics range from economic growth and inequality in the long run to economic stability and financial crises in the short run. Surveys many economic models used today. Requires a substantial research paper on the economics of long-run economic growth.
<br><I>A. Simsek</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.05');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.06"></a>
<p><h3>14.06 Advanced Macroeconomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.02">14.02</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Blends a thorough study of the theoretical foundations of modern macroeconomics with a review of useful mathematical tools, such as dynamic programming, optimal control, and dynamic systems. Develops comfort with formal macroeconomic reasoning and deepens understanding of key macroeconomic phenomena, such as business cycles. Goes on to study more specific topics, such as unemployment, financial crises, and the role of fiscal and monetary policy. Special attention to reviewing relevant facts and disentangling them from their popular interpretations. Uses insights and tools from game theory. Includes applications to recent and historical events.
<br><I>G. Angeletos</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.07"></a>
<p><h3>14.07 Financial Markets and the Macroeconomy
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.02">14.02</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes the macroeconomic effects of financial markets, with emphasis on understanding financial crises. Surveys the benchmark theories of asset pricing, investment, and the capital structure. Topics include risk, arbitrage, financial market equilibrium, and market efficiency. Also introduces financial frictions, and analyzes the mechanisms by which frictions cause financial crises; focuses on asymmetric information, leverage, financial intermediation, belief disagreements, asset bubbles, fire sales, bank runs, interconnections, and complexity.
<br><I>A. Simsek</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.08"></a>
<p><h3>14.08 Technical Topics in Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers technical issues of current research interest in economics.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<a name="14.11"></a>
<p><h3>14.11 Topics in Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers issues of current research interest in economics.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.12"></a>
<p><h3>14.12 Economic Applications of Game Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of strategic behavior in multi-person economic settings. Introduction to solution concepts, such as rationalizability, backwards induction, Nash equilibrium, subgame-perfect equilibrium, and sequential equilibrium, with a strong emphasis on the assumptions behind these solution concepts. Issues of incomplete information, such as signaling and reputation formation. Applications drawn from microeconomics and political economy.
<br><I>M. Yildiz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.121"></a>
<p><h3>14.121 Microeconomic Theory I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers consumer and producer theory, markets and competition, general equilibrium and the welfare theorems; featuring applications, uncertainty, identification and restrictions models place on data. Enrollment limited; preference to PhD students.
<br><I>R. Townsend</I><br>
<a name="14.122"></a>
<p><h3>14.122 Microeconomic Theory II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to game theory. Topics include normal form and extensive form games, and games with incomplete information. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>M. Yildiz</I><br>
<a name="14.123"></a>
<p><h3>14.123 Microeconomic Theory III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.122">14.122</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Models of individual decision-making under  certainty and uncertainty. Additional topics in  game theory. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>D. Fudenberg</I><br>No textbook information available
<a name="14.124"></a>
<p><h3>14.124 Microeconomic Theory IV
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.123">14.123</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to statistical decision theory, incentive contracting (moral hazard and adverse selection), mechanism design and incomplete contracting. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Wolitzky</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.125"></a>
<p><h3>14.125 Market Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theory and practice of market design, building on ideas from microeconomics, game theory and mechanism design.  Prominent case studies include auctions, labor markets, school choice, prediction markets, financial markets, and organ exchange clearinghouses.
<br><I>P. Pathak</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.126"></a>
<p><h3>14.126 Game Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.122">14.122</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Rigorous investigation of the evolutionary and epistemic foundations of solution concepts, such as rationalizability and Nash equilibrium. Covers classical topics, such as repeated games, bargaining, and supermodular games as well as new topics such as global games, heterogeneous priors, psychological games, and games without expected utility maximization. Applications provided when available.
<br><I>D. Fudenberg, M. Yildiz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.126');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.129"></a>
<p><h3>14.129 Advanced Contract Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.281">14.281</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Class ends March 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Recent developments in contract theory. Includes advanced models of moral hazard, adverse selection, mechanism design and incomplete contracts with applications to theory of the firm, organizational design, and financial structure.
<br><I>R. Townsend</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.13"></a>
<p><h3>14.13 Psychology and Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the theoretical and empirical literature of behavioral economics. Examines important and systematic departures from the standard models in economics by incorporating insights from psychology and other social sciences. Covers theory and evidence on time, risk, and social preferences; beliefs and learning; emotions; limited attention; and frames, defaults, and nudges. Studies applications to many different areas, such as credit card debt, procrastination, retirement savings, addiction, portfolio choice, poverty, labor supply, happiness, and government policy. Students participate in surveys and experiments in class, review evidence from lab experiments, examine how the results can be integrated into models, and test models using field and lab data.
<br><I>F. Schilbach</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.130"></a>
<p><h3>14.130 Reading Economic Theory
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>, <a href="m14b.html#14.451">14.451</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Class will read and discuss current research in economic theory with a focus on game theory, decision theory, and behavioral economics. Students will be expected to make one presentation and to read and post comments on every paper by the day before the paper is presented. Permission of the instructor required, and auditors are not allowed.
<br><I>D. Fudenberg</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.137"></a>
<p><h3>14.137[J] Psychology and Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9b.html#9.822">9.822[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-164</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines "psychology appreciation" for economics students. Aims to enhance knowledge and intuition about psychological processes in areas relevant to economics. Increases understanding of psychology as an experimental discipline, with its own distinct rules and style of argument. Topics include self-knowledge, cognitive dissonance, self-deception, emotions, social norms, self-control, learning, mental accounting, memory, individual and group behavior, and some personality and psycho-analytic models. Within each of these topics, we showcase effective and central experiments and discuss their role in the development of psychological theory. Term paper required.
<br><I>D. Prelec</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.147"></a>
<p><h3>14.147 Topics in Game Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.126">14.126</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-532</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced subject on topics of current research interest.
<br><I>M. Yildiz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.15"></a>
<p><h3>14.15[J] Networks
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.207">6.207[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-190</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Highlights common principles that permeate the functioning of diverse technological, economic and social networks. Utilizes three sets of tools for analyzing networks--random graph models, optimization, and game theory--to study informational and learning cascades; economic and financial networks; social influence networks; formation of social groups; communication networks and the Internet; consensus and gossiping; spread and control of epidemics; control and use of energy networks; and biological networks.
<br><I>M. Roozbehani, E. Sadler</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.16"></a>
<p><h3>14.16 Strategy and Information
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced course in game theory provides rigorous overview of equilibrium concepts for non-cooperative games in static and dynamic settings. Covers iterated strict dominance, rationalizability, Nash equilibrium, subgame perfection, sequential, perfect and proper equilibria, the intuitive criterion, and iterated weak dominance. Applications to auctions, bargaining, and repeated games. Introduces solution concepts for cooperative games and their non-cooperative implementations, as well as matching theory.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.160"></a>
<p><h3>14.160 Behavioral Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.122">14.122</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers recent theory and empirical evidence in behavioral economics. Topics include deviations from the neoclassical model in terms of (i) preferences (present bias, reference dependence, social preferences), (ii) beliefs (overconfidence, projection bias), and (iii) decision-making (cognition, attention, framing, persuasion), as well as (iv) market reactions to such deviations. Applications will cover a large range of fields, including labor and public economics, industrial organization, health economics, finance, and development economics.
<br><I>F. Schilbach</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.18"></a>
<p><h3>14.18 Mathematical Economic Modeling
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.12">14.12</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.15">14.15</a>, or <a href="m14a.html#14.19">14.19</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-532</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-063</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Guides students through the process of developing and analyzing formal economic models and effectively communicating their results.  Topics include decision theory, game theory, voting, and matching.  Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided. Prior coursework in microeconomic theory and/or proof-based mathematics required.
<br><I>A. Wolitzky</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.19"></a>
<p><h3>14.19 Market Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the design and operation of organized markets, building on ideas from microeconomic and game theory.  Topics may include mechanism design, auctions, matching markets, and other resource allocation problems.
<br><I>P. Pathak</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.191"></a>
<p><h3>14.191 Independent Research Paper
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-12-0
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Under supervision of a faculty member approved by Graduate Registration Officer, student writes a substantial, probably publishable research paper. Must be completed by the end of a student's second year to satisfy the departmental minor requirement.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Caballero</I><br>IAP: <I>R. Caballero</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Caballero</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.193"></a>
<p><h3>14.193 Advanced Seminar in Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<h2>Industrial Organization</h2>
<a name="14.20"></a>
<p><h3>14.20 Industrial Organization and Competitive Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes the behavior and performance of firms in markets, with a particular focus on strategic interactions.  Topics include monopoly power, behavior of firms in oligopoly markets, static and dynamic measurement of market performance, pricing and product choice decisions, advertising, research and development, and theory of the firm. Requires attendance and team participation in a Competitive Strategy Game.
<br><I>N. Rose</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.21"></a>
<p><h3>14.21 Health Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/14.21j/www/">http://web.mit.edu/14.21j/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies theoretical and empirical tools of economics to problems of health and medical care delivery. Concentrates on selected topics such as decision-making under uncertainty, cost-benefit analysis, health insurance, physician remuneration, government regulation, health care systems of developing countries, and the economics of AIDS.
<br><I>J. Harris</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.26"></a>
<p><h3>14.26 Economics of Incentives: Theory and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a rigorous, but not overly technical introduction to the economic theory of incentives and organization together with a varying set of applications. These include, among others, the optimal design of sales and CEO incentive schemes; the impact of incentives on risk taking and innovation; tournament design; the analysis of venture capital and other forms of financial incentive contracts; relational and behavioral aspects of incentive contracts; and various organizational design problems.
<br><I>B. Holmstrom</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.26');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.27"></a>
<p><h3>14.27 Economics and E-Commerce
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses theoretical economic models and empirical evidence to help understand the growth and future of e-commerce.  Economic models help frame class discussions of, among other topics, content provision, privacy, piracy, sales taxation, group purchasing, price search, and advertising on the internet.  Empirical project and paper required.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.271"></a>
<p><h3>14.271 Industrial Organization I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers theoretical and empirical work dealing with the structure, behavior, and performance of firms and markets and core issues in antitrust. Topics include: the organization of the firm, monopoly, price discrimination, oligopoly, and auctions. Theoretical and empirical work are integrated in each area.
<br><I>N. Agarwal</I><br>
<a name="14.272"></a>
<p><h3>14.272 Industrial Organization II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.271">14.271</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A continuation of 14.271.  Topics covered include horizontal mergers and demand estimation, vertical integration and vertical restraints, natural monopoly and its regulation, public enterprise, political economy of regulation, network access pricing, deregulation of telecommunications, electric power, cable television, transportation sectors, and risk and environmental regulation.
<br><I>N. Rose, M. Whinston</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.272');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.273"></a>
<p><h3>14.273 Advanced Topics in Industrial Organization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.271">14.271</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Empirical analysis of theoretically derived models of market behavior. Varied topics include demand estimation, differentiated products, production functions, analysis of market power, entry and exit, vertical relationships, auctions, matching markets, network externalities, dynamic oligopoly, moral hazard and adverse selection. Discussion will focus on methodological issues, including identification, estimation, counter-factual analysis and simulation techniques.
<br><I>N. Agarwal, M. Igami</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.281"></a>
<p><h3>14.281 Contract Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers theoretical research on contracts in static as well as dynamic settings. Emphasis is on canonical models in contracting (agency theory, mechanism design, incomplete contracting) illustrated by major areas of application (e.g. compensation, labor and capital markets, property rights, organizational design, corporate finance).
<br><I>J. Toikka</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.282"></a>
<p><h3>14.282 Introduction to Organizational Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Begins with survey of contract theory for organizational economists, then introduces the main areas of the field, including the boundary of the firm; decision-making, employment, structures and processes in organizations;  and organizations other than firms.
<br><I>R. Gibbons</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.283"></a>
<p><h3>14.283 Advanced Topics in Organizational Economics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br>Builds on the work done in 14.282 to develop more in-depth analysis of topics in the field.

<h2>Statistics and Econometrics</h2>
<a name="14.30"></a>
<p><h3>14.30 Introduction to Statistical Methods in Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.300">14.300</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Self-contained introduction to probability and statistics with some economic applications.  Elements of probability theory, sampling theory, statistical estimation, and hypothesis testing. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. May not count toward HASS  requirement.
<br><I>A. Abadie</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.300"></a>
<p><h3>14.300 Introduction to Statistical Methods in Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Self-contained introduction to probability and statistics with some economic applications. Elements of probability theory, sampling theory, statistical estimation, and hypothesis testing. Graduate students are expected to complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.31"></a>
<p><h3>14.31 Data Analysis for Social Scientists
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.310">14.310</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces methods for harnessing data to answer questions of cultural, social, economic, and policy interest. Presents essential notions of probability and statistics. Covers techniques in modern data analysis: regression and econometrics, prediction, design of experiment, randomized control trials (and A/B testing), machine learning, data visualization, analysis of network data, and geographic information systems. Projects include analysis of data with a written description and interpretation of results; may involve gathering of original data or use of existing data sets. Applications drawn from real world examples and frontier research. Instruction in use of the statistical package R. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.310"></a>
<p><h3>14.310 Data Analysis for Social Scientists
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.31">14.31</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces methods for harnessing data to answer questions of cultural, social, economic, and policy interest. Presents essential notions of probability and statistics. Covers techniques in modern data analysis: regression and econometrics, prediction, design of experiment, randomized control trials (and A/B testing), machine learning, data visualization, analysis of network data, and geographic information systems. Projects include analysis of data with a written description and interpretation of results; may involve gathering of original data or use of existing data sets. Applications drawn from real world examples and frontier research. Instruction in use of the statistical package R. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.32"></a>
<p><h3>14.32 Econometric Data Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i> <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-085</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces multiple regression methods for causal inference and descriptive analysis in economics and related disciplines. Extensions include instrumental variables methods, analysis of randomized experiments and quasi-experimental research designs, and regression with time series data. Develops the skills needed to conduct - and critique - empirical studies in economics and related fields. Students complete an empirical project with a written description and interpretation of results; this may involve original data collection or use of existing data sets. Applications drawn from real-world examples and frontier research. Familiarity with statistical programming languages is helpful.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Mikusheva</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Angrist</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.32');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.33"></a>
<p><h3>14.33 Research and Communication in Economics:  Topics, Methods, and Implementation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.02">14.02</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.32">14.32</a>
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to the process of conducting independent research in empirical economics and effectively communicating the results of the research. Emphasizes econometric analysis of an assigned economic question and culminates in each student choosing an original topic, performing appropriate analysis, and delivering oral and written project reports.
<br>Fall: <I>G. Chodorow-Reich</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Jaeger</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.33');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.36"></a>
<p><h3>14.36 Advanced Econometrics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.387">14.387</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.32">14.32</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes econometric theory, methods, and applications using regression, instrumental variables, differences-in-differences, regression discontinuity designs, machine learning and big data sets, and problems related to standard errors and statistical inference. Includes a project with a theoretical, written and data-analytic component. Familiarity with Stata or a similar statistical programming language recommended. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. Angrist, V. Chernozhukov</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.36');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.381"></a>
<p><h3>14.381 Statistical Method in Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to probability and statistics as background for advanced econometrics and introduction to the linear regression model. Covers elements of probability theory; sampling theory; asymptotic approximations; decision-theory approach to statistical estimation focusing on regression, hypothesis testing; and maximum-likelihood methods. Includes simple and multiple regression, estimation and hypothesis testing. Illustrations from economics and application of these concepts to economic problems. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Mikusheva</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.382"></a>
<p><h3>14.382 Econometrics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.381">14.381</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) or <i>F4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers key models as well as identification and estimation methods used in modern econometrics. Presents modern ways to set up problems and do better estimation and inference than the current empirical practice. Introduces generalized method of moments and the method of M-estimators in addition to more modern versions of these methods dealing with important issues, such as weak identification or biases arising in high dimensions. Also discusses the bootstrap and explores very high dimensional formulations, or "big data." Students gain practical experience by applying the methods to real data sets. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>V. Chernozhukov</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.384"></a>
<p><h3>14.384 Time Series Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies theory and application of time series methods in econometrics, including spectral analysis, estimation with stationary and non-stationary processes, VARs, factor models, unit roots, cointegration, estimation of DSGE models, and Bayesian methods. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Mikusheva</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.385"></a>
<p><h3>14.385 Nonlinear Econometric Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies micro-econometric models, including large sample theory for estimation and hypothesis testing, generalized method of moments, estimation of censored and truncated specifications, quantile regression, structural estimation, nonparametric and semiparametric estimation, panel data, bootstrapping, and simulation methods. Methods illustrated with economic applications. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Abadie</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.386"></a>
<p><h3>14.386 New Econometric Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on recent developments in econometrics, especially structural estimation.  Topics include nonseparable models, models of imperfect competition, auction models, duration models, and nonlinear panel data.  Results illustrated with economic applications.
<br><I>A. Abadie, W. Newey</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.387"></a>
<p><h3>14.387 Applied Econometrics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14a.html#14.36">14.36</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes econometric theory, methods, and applications using regression, instrumental variables, differences-in-differences, regression discontinuity designs, machine learning and big data sets, and problems related to standard errors and statistical inference. Includes a project with a theoretical, written and data-analytic component. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>J. Angrist, V. Chernozhukov</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=14.387');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.389"></a>
<p><h3>14.389 Econometrics Paper
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.382">14.382</a> or <a href="m14a.html#14.32">14.32</a>
<br>Units: 0-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Paper in econometrics required of all PhD candidates. Paper due at the end of IAP.
<br><I>A. Abadie</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.391"></a>
<p><h3>14.391 Workshop in Economic Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>, <a href="m14b.html#14.454">14.454</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops research ability of students through intensive discussion of dissertation research as it proceeds, individual or group research projects, and critical appraisal of current reported research. Workshops divided into various fields, depending on interest and size.
<br><I>R. Caballero</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.392"></a>
<h3>14.392 Workshop in Economic Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.124">14.124</a>, <a href="m14b.html#14.454">14.454</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Recitation:</b> <i>M2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-432</a>) or <i>M4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-650</a>) or <i>R2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-650</a>) or <i>W2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) or <i>R EVE (4.30-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-432</a>) or <i>T EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-432</a>) or <i>R EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) or <i>R4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-532</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops research ability of students through intensive discussion of dissertation research as it proceeds, individual or group research projects, and critical appraisal of current reported research. Workshops divided into various fields, depending on interest and size.
<br><I>R. Caballero</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
