<a name="17.198"></a>
<p><h3>17.198 Current Topics in Comparative Political Economy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes and compares approaches in current political economy literatures. Weekly topics are selected by instructor and participants. Examples include the organization of interests, industrial policy, growth and inequality, resource "curse", late development. Topics vary each year depending on the research interests of the seminar participants. The subject is for graduate students in social sciences with previous coursework in political economy.
<br><I>S. Berger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>American Politics</h2>
<a name="17.20"></a>
<p><h3>17.20 Introduction to the American Political Process
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a substantive overview of US politics and an introduction to the discipline of political science. Surveys the institutional foundations of US politics as well as the activities of political elites, organizations, and ordinary citizens. Explores the application of general political science concepts and analytic frameworks to specific episodes and phenomena in US politics. Enrollment limited
<br><I>D. Caughey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.200"></a>
<p><h3>17.200 American Political Behavior I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes mass political behavior within the American political system. Examines political ideology, party identification, public opinion, voting behavior, media effects, racial attitudes, mass-elite relations, and opinion-policy linkages. Surveys and critiques the major theoretical approaches and empirical research in the field of political behavior.
<br><I>A. White</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.202"></a>
<p><h3>17.202 American Political Institutions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W1.30-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E53">E53-485</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes the institutions of the American political system, with primary emphasis on the national level. Examines American federalism, political parties, national political institutions, and the policymaking process. Focuses on core works in contemporary American politics and public policy. Critiques both research methodologies and the explicit and implicit theoretical assumptions of such work.
<br><I>D. Caughey</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=17.202');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.210"></a>
<p><h3>17.210 American Political Behavior II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17a.html#17.200">17.200</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E53">E53-485</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes mass political behavior within the American political system. Goes beyond the topics covered in 17.200, to explore additional areas and research frontiers in political behavior. Examines recent research on political ideology, party identification, public opinion, voting behavior, media effects, racial attitudes, mass-elite relations, and opinion-policy linkages. Introduces new topics such as personality, emotion, networks, polarization, opinion on war.
<br><I>A. Berinsky</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.245"></a>
<p><h3>17.245 Constitutional Law: Structures of Power and Individual Rights
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines American constitutional law in historical and modern context. Focuses closely on the constitutional text and Supreme Court case law. Explores the allocation of decision-making authority among government institutions, including the distribution of power across the branches of the federal government and between the federal and state governments. Examines the guarantees of individual rights and liberties stemming from the due process, equal protection, and other clauses in the Bill of Rights and post Civil War amendments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.251"></a>
<p><h3>17.251 Congress and the American Political System I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m17a.html#17.252">17.252</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17a.html#17.20">17.20</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on both the internal processes of the House and Senate and on the place of Congress in the American Political System. Attention to committee behavior, leadership patterns, and informal organization. Considers relations between Congress and other branches of government, as well as relations between the two houses of Congress itself. Students taking the graduate version are expected to pursue the subject in greater depth through reading and individual research.
<br><I>C. Stewart</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.252"></a>
<h3>17.252 Congress and the American Political System I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m17a.html#17.251">17.251</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on both the internal processes of the House and Senate and on the place of Congress in the American political system. Attention to committee behavior, leadership patterns, and informal organization. Considers relations between Congress and other branches of government, as well as relations between the two houses of Congress itself. Students taking the graduate version are expected to pursue the subject in greater depth through reading and individual research.
<br><I>C. Stewart</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.261"></a>
<p><h3>17.261 Congress and the American Political System II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m17a.html#17.262">17.262</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17a.html#17.251">17.251</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://www.mit.edu/~17.261/">http://www.mit.edu/~17.261/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes the development of the Congress by focusing on the competing theoretical lenses through which legislatures have been studies. Particularly compares sociological and economic models of legislative behavior, applying those models to floor decision making, committee behavior, political parties, relations with other branches of the federal government, and elections. Students taking the graduate version are expected to pursue the subject in greater depth through reading and individual research.
<br><I>C. Stewart</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.262"></a>
<h3>17.262 Congress and the American Political System II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m17a.html#17.261">17.261</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes the development of the US Congress by focusing on the competing theoretical lenses through which legislatures have been studied. Particularly compares sociological and economic models of legislative behavior, applying those models to floor decision-making, committee behavior, political parties, relations with other branches of the Federal government, and elections. Students taking the graduate version are expected to pursue the subject in greater depth through reading and individual research.
<br><I>C. Stewart</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.263"></a>
<p><h3>17.263 Electoral Politics, Public Opinion, and Democracy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers the role of elections in American politics. Issues explored include empirical and theoretical models of electoral competition, the effect of elections on public policy, and proposals to improve elections.  Special emphasis is given to mass voting behavior, political parties, the media, and campaign finance. Subject focuses on US elections, but provides some contrasts with other countries, especially the United Kingdom.
<br><I>A. White</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.264"></a>
<p><h3>17.264 Electoral Politics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes elections in light of theories about voters, parties, and candidates. Topics include election laws and reforms, and the formation of governments. Focus is mainly on US elections, though other democracies are also examined. Familiarity with statistics recommended but not required. Open to qualified undergraduates.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.265"></a>
<p><h3>17.265 Public Opinion and American Democracy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to public opinion in politics and public policymaking. Surveys theories of political psychology and political behavior. Examines empirical research on public understanding of and attitudes towards important issues, including war, economic and social policies, and moral questions.
<br><I>A. Berinsky</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.266"></a>
<p><h3>17.266 Public Opinion
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the scholarly literature devoted to public opinion. Surveys the major theoretical approaches and empirical research in the field of political behavior. Topics include mass-elite relations, racial politics, political ideology, public opinion and war, public opinion and public policy and media effects. Primarily focuses on American public opinion, though research on comparative public opinion is also covered.
<br><I>A.  Berinsky</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.267"></a>
<p><h3>17.267 Democracy in America
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the functioning of democracy in the US beginning with the theoretical foundations of democratic representation. Explores how the views of the public influence policy making. Examines factors, such as malapportionment, that lead to non-majoritarian outcomes. Reviews evidence on how well policy outcomes reflect public opinion, and whether certain groups are over or under-represented in the policy process. Discusses reforms that might make our democracy more responsive to the American public.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.269"></a>
<p><h3>17.269 Race, Ethnicity, and American Politics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-379</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the role of race and ethnicity in modern American politics. Focuses on social science approaches to measuring the effects of race, both at the individual level and more broadly. Topics include race and representation, measurement of racial and ethnic identities, voting rights and electoral districting, protest and other forms of political participation, and the meaning and measurement of racial attitudes.
<br><I>A. White</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=17.269');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.270"></a>
<p><h3>17.270 American Political Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the evolution of American national political processes over time: how political culture, governing institutions, and structures of political linkage (parties and organized interests) shape political conflict and public policy. Topics include the evolution of electoral politics and the party system, eras of political reform and state expansion (Populist, Progressive, New Deal, and Great Society), major wars and their effects, and the adaptation of government institutions to crisis and complexity in society and in the economy. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.
<br><I>D. Caughey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.275"></a>
<p><h3>17.275 Public Opinion Research Design and Training Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the basic skills required to design, use, and interpret opinion surveys and survey experiments. Acts as both a reading subject on survey analysis and a practicum on collecting and analyzing observational and experimental survey data. Culminates in a group project involving a survey experiment on a particular topic chosen by the class and the instructor.
<br><I>A. Berinsky</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.276"></a>
<p><h3>17.276 Public Opinion Research Training Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17b.html#17.800">17.800</a>, <a href="m17a.html#17.266">17.266</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Follows 17.266. Offers practical training in public opinion research and provides students with an opportunity to conduct their own survey research. As a group, students design a national sample survey and field the survey. Students analyze the survey results and examine literatures related to the content of the survey. Ideal for second and third year PhD students and advanced undergraduates, though others are welcome.
<br><I>A. Berinsky</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.28"></a>
<p><h3>17.28[J] The War at Home: American Politics and Society in Wartime
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Ha.html#21H.213">21H.213[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the relationship between war and domestic politics in the US since the start of 20th century. Students engage in historical and social scientific research to analyze the ways that overseas military commitments shaped US political institutions, and how domestic politics has in turn structured US engagements abroad. Moving chronologically from World War I to the Iraq War, subject draws on materials across the disciplines, including political documents, opinion polls, legal decisions, and products of American popular culture.
<br><I>A. Berinsky, C. Capozzola</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Public Policy</h2>
<a name="17.30"></a>
<p><h3>17.30[J] Making Public Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.002">11.002[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines how the struggle among competing advocates shapes the outputs of government. Considers how conditions become problems for government to solve, why some political arguments are more persuasive than others, why some policy tools are preferred over others, and whether policies achieve their goals. Investigates the interactions among elected officials, think tanks, interest groups, the media, and the public in controversies over global warming, urban sprawl, Social Security, health care, education, and other issues.
<br><I>J. Thompson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.303"></a>
<p><h3>17.303[J] Methods of Policy Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.003">11.003[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m11a.html#11.002">11.002J</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-401</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with an introduction to public policy analysis. Examines various approaches to policy analysis by considering the concepts, tools, and methods used in economics, political science, and other disciplines. Students apply and critique these approaches through case studies of current public policy problems.
<br><I>C. Abbanat</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.307"></a>
<p><h3>17.307 American Public Policy for Washington Interns
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines US policymaking process, with special attention to making of policy for science and technology. Subject spans Spring and Fall terms. Spring term attends to origins and development of American policymaking institutions and their roles in settling controversial policy questions. Fall term focuses on development of representative policies in the US, such as pollution controls, biotechnical engineering, and telecommunications. Selection and participation in Washington Summer Internship program required. Fulfills undergraduate public policy requirement in the major and minor.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Stewart</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Stewart</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.309"></a>
<h3>17.309[J] Science, Technology, and Public Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.055">IDS.055[J]</A>, <A HREF="mSTSa.html#STS.082">STS.082[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m17a.html#17.310">17.310</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.412">IDS.412</A>, <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.482">STS.482</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of issues at the intersection of science, technology, public policy, and business. Cases drawn from antitrust and intellectual property rights; health and environmental policy; defense procurement and strategy; strategic trade and industrial policy; and R&D funding. Structured around theories of political economy, modified to take into account integration of uncertain technical information into public and private decision-making. Meets with 17.310.
<br>Fall: <I>K. Oye</I><br>Spring: <I>N. Selin</I><br>
<a name="17.310"></a>
<h3>17.310[J] Science, Technology, and Public Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.412">IDS.412[J]</A>, <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.482">STS.482[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m17a.html#17.309">17.309</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.055">IDS.055</A>, <A HREF="mSTSa.html#STS.082">STS.082</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of issues at the intersection of science, technology, public policy, and business.  Cases drawn from antitrust and intellectual property rights; health and environmental policy; defense procurement and strategy; strategic trade and industrial policy; and R&D funding. Structured around theories of political economy, modified to take account of integration of uncertain technical information into public and private decision-making. Meets with 17.309.
<br><I>K. Oye</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.315"></a>
<p><h3>17.315 Health Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-164</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) or <i>R EVE (7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes the health policy problems facing America including adequate access to care, the control of health care costs, and the encouragement of medical advances. Considers market and regulatory alternatives as well as international models including Canadian, Swedish, British, and German arrangements. Emphasis on historical development, interest group behavior, public opinion, and organizational influences in shaping and implementing policy.
<br><I>A. Campbell</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.317"></a>
<p><h3>17.317 US Social Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores historical development and contemporary politics of the American welfare state. Examines interactions among political institutions, elites, the media, and the mass public. Emphasis on reciprocal relationship between policy designs and public opinion/political action. Investigates broad spectrum of government policies that shape well-being, opportunity and political influence, including welfare, social security, health care, education, and tax policy.
<br><I>A. Campbell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.320"></a>
<p><h3>17.320 Social Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of Instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the politics of social policy in comparative perspective. Empirical and theoretical overview of the origins, development, and future of social provision in industrialized countries, in the context of broader political and historical trends. Examines concepts such as social citizenship, risk sharing, de-commodification, and welfare regimes, and the challenges of globalization, neo-liberalism, and demographic change. Topics include pensions, health care, poverty alleviation, and family policy. Combines classic work and research frontiers.
<br><I>A. Campbell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.381"></a>
<p><h3>17.381[J] The Art and Science of Negotiation: Advanced Applications
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.111">11.111[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m11a.html#11.011">11.011</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-354</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Building on the skills and strategies honed in 11.011, explores advanced negotiation through theory and practice. Emphasizes an experiential, personal skill-building approach, underpinned by foundational and cutting-edge research. Examines applications in management, public policy, social entrepreneurship, international diplomacy, and scientific discovery. Strengthens collaborative decision-making, communication, and leadership skills while enhancing students' ability to proactively frame conflicts, analyze problems, engage stakeholders, create value, negotiate agreements, and resolve disputes.
<br><I>B. Verdini Trejo</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.391"></a>
<p><h3>17.391[J] Human Rights at Home and Abroad
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.164">11.164[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m11c.html#11.497">11.497</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a rigorous and critical introduction to the history, foundation, structure, and operation of the human rights movement. Focuses on key ideas, actors, methods and sources, and critically evaluates the field. Addresses current debates in human rights, including the relationship with security, democracy, development and globalization, urbanization, equality (in housing and other economic and social rights; women's rights; ethnic, religious and racial discrimination; and policing/conflict), post-conflict rebuilding and transitional justice, and technology in human rights activism. No prior coursework needed, but work experience, or community service that demonstrates familiarity with global affairs or engagement with ethics and social justice issues, preferred. Students taking graduate version are expected to write a research paper.
<br><I>B. Rajagopal</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.393"></a>
<p><h3>17.393[J] Environmental Law, Policy, and Economics: Pollution Prevention and Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.801">1.801[J]</A>, <A HREF="m11a.html#11.021">11.021[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.060">IDS.060[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.811">1.811[J]</A>, <A HREF="m11c.html#11.630">11.630[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15b.html#15.663">15.663[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.540">IDS.540[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reviews and analyzes federal and state regulation of air and water pollution, hazardous waste, green-house gas emissions, and the production and use of toxic chemicals. Analyzes pollution as an economic problem and the failure of markets. Explores the role of science and economics in legal decisions. Emphasizes use of legal mechanisms and alternative approaches (such as economic incentives and voluntary approaches) to control pollution and encourage chemical accident and pollution prevention. Focuses on the major federal legislation, the underlying administrative system, and the common law in analyzing environmental policy, economic consequences, and the role of the courts. Discusses classical pollutants and toxic industrial chemicals, green-house gas emissions, community right-to-know, and environmental justice. Develops basic legal skills: how to read/understand cases, regulations, and statutes. Students taking graduate version are expected to explore the subject in greater depth.
<br><I>N. Ashford</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.395"></a>
<p><h3>17.395[J] Innovation Systems for Science, Technology, Energy, Manufacturing, and Health
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mSTSa.html#STS.081">STS.081[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br>Ends Apr 27. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>T2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-234</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines science and technology innovation systems, including case studies on energy, computing, advanced manufacturing, and health sectors. Emphasizes public policy and the federal government's role in that system. Focuses on the US but uses international examples. Reviews foundations of economic growth theory, innovation systems theory, and the basic approaches to science and technology policy. Explores the organization and role of energy and medical science R&D agencies, as well as gaps in those innovation systems. Also addresses the science and technology talent base as a factor in growth, and educational approaches to better support it. Class meets for nine weeks; in the remaining weeks, students work on a final paper due at the end of the term. Limited to 25.
<br><I>W. Bonvillian</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=17.395');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.397"></a>
<p><h3>17.397[J] Energy Decisions, Markets, and Policies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.161">11.161[J]</A>, <A HREF="m14b.html#14.43">14.43[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.031">15.031[J]</A>, <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.415">21A.415[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.0111">15.0111</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Structured around choices and constraints regarding sources and uses of energy by households, firms, and governments, introduces managerial, economic, political, social and cultural frameworks for describing and explaining behavior at various levels of aggregation. Includes examples of cost-benefit, organizational and institutional analyses of energy generation, distribution, and consumption. Topics include the role of markets and prices; financial analysis of energy-related investments; institutional path dependence; economic and political determinants of government regulation and the impact of regulation on decisions; and other forms of government action and social norms regarding desired behavior and opportunities for businesses and consumers, including feedback into the political/regulatory system. Examples drawn from a wide range of countries and settings.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.399"></a>
<p><h3>17.399[J] Global Energy: Politics, Markets, and Policy
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.167">11.167[J]</A>, <A HREF="m14b.html#14.47">14.47[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.2191">15.2191[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m11b.html#11.267">11.267</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.219">15.219</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the ways economics and politics influence the fate of energy technologies, business models, and policies around the world. Extends fundamental concepts in the social sciences to case studies and simulations that illustrate how corporate, government, and individual decisions shape energy and environmental outcomes. In a final project, students apply the concepts in order to assess the prospects for an energy innovation to scale and advance sustainability goals in a particular regional market. Recommended prerequisite: 14.01. Meets with 15.219 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details. Preference to juniors, seniors, and Energy Minors.
<br><I>V. Karplus</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 18: Mathematics<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://www-math.mit.edu/"><i>Course 18 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course18.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=18&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++18&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>18.01-18.499</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m18b.html">18.50-18.THG</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>General Mathematics</h2>
<a name="18.01"></a>
<p><h3>18.01 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc1.gif" alt="Calculus I" title="Calculus I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01A">18.01A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.181A">CC.181A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1801">ES.1801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.181A">ES.181A</A>
<br><a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.01/">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.01/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-135</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-135</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Differentiation and integration of functions of one variable, with applications.  Informal treatment of limits and continuity.  Differentiation: definition, rules, application to graphing, rates, approximations, and extremum problems. Indefinite integration; separable first-order differential equations.  Definite integral; fundamental theorem of calculus. Applications of integration to geometry and science.  Elementary functions.  Techniques of integration.  Polar coordinates. L'Hopital's rule.  Improper integrals.  Infinite series: geometric, p-harmonic, simple comparison tests, power series for some elementary functions.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Speck</I><br>IAP: <I>B. Peskin</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Bush</I><br>No textbook information available (IAP 2018); <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.01');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.01A"></a>
<p><h3>18.01A Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc1.gif" alt="Calculus I" title="Calculus I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: Knowledge of differentiation and elementary integration
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01">18.01</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.181A">CC.181A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1801">ES.1801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.181A">ES.181A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Six-week review of one-variable calculus, emphasizing material not on the high-school AB syllabus: integration techniques and applications, improper integrals, infinite series, applications to other topics, such as probability and statistics, as time permits. Prerequisites: one year of high-school calculus or the equivalent, with a score of 5 on the AB Calculus test (or the AB portion of the BC test, or an equivalent score on a standard international exam), or equivalent college transfer credit, or a passing grade on the first half of the 18.01 advanced standing exam.
<br><I>D. Maulik</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.02"></a>
<p><h3>18.02 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.022">18.022</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br><a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.02/">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.02/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-136</a>) or <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>) or <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-147</a>) or <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-147</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Calculus of several variables. Vector algebra in 3-space, determinants, matrices. Vector-valued functions of one variable, space motion. Scalar functions of several variables: partial differentiation, gradient, optimization techniques. Double integrals and line integrals in the plane; exact differentials and conservative fields; Green's theorem and applications, triple integrals, line and surface integrals in space, Divergence theorem, Stokes' theorem; applications.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Bush</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Guth</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.02');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.02A"></a>
<p><h3>18.02A Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.022">18.022</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A</a><br>Spring URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2 (BEGINS APR 2)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First half is taught during the last six weeks of the Fall term; covers material in the first half of 18.02 (through double integrals). Second half of 18.02A can be taken either during IAP (daily lectures) or during the second half of the Spring term; it covers the remaining material in 18.02.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Beck</I><br>IAP: <I>T. Beck</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Guth</I><br>No textbook information available (IAP 2018); <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.02A');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.022"></a>
<p><h3>18.022 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Calculus of several variables. Topics as in 18.02 but with more focus on mathematical concepts. Vector algebra, dot product, matrices, determinant. Functions of several variables, continuity, differentiability, derivative. Parametrized curves, arc length, curvature, torsion. Vector fields, gradient, curl, divergence. Multiple integrals, change of variables, line integrals, surface integrals. Stokes' theorem in one, two, and three dimensions.
<br><I>P. Etingof</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.03"></a>
<p><h3>18.03 Differential Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1803">CC.1803</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1803">ES.1803</A>
<br><a href="https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/18/sp18/18.03#info">https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/18/sp18/18.03#info</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-136</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-146</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-146</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of differential equations, including modeling physical systems. Solution of first-order ODEs by analytical, graphical, and numerical methods. Linear ODEs with constant coefficients. Complex numbers and exponentials. Inhomogeneous equations: polynomial, sinusoidal, and exponential inputs. Oscillations, damping, resonance. Fourier series. Matrices, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, diagonalization. First order linear systems: normal modes, matrix exponentials, variation of parameters. Heat equation, wave equation. Nonlinear autonomous systems: critical point analysis, phase plane diagrams.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Negut</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Poonen</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.031"></a>
<p><h3>18.031 System Functions and the Laplace Transform
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><a href="https://math.mit.edu/18.031">https://math.mit.edu/18.031</a>
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-151</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies basic continuous control theory as well as representation of functions in the complex frequency domain. Covers generalized functions, unit impulse response, and convolution; and Laplace transform, system (or transfer) function, and the pole diagram.  Includes examples from mechanical and electrical engineering.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Pearce</I><br>Spring: <I>P. Pearce</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.032"></a>
<p><h3>18.032 Differential Equations
<br>(18.034)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1803">CC.1803</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1803">ES.1803</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers much of the same material as 18.03 with more emphasis on theory. The point of view is rigorous and results are proven.  Local existence and uniqueness of solutions.
<br><I>N. Edelen</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.032');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.04"></a>
<p><h3>18.04 Complex Variables with Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0751">18.0751</A>
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/18.04/">http://math.mit.edu/18.04/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Complex algebra and functions; analyticity; contour integration, Cauchy's theorem; singularities, Taylor and Laurent series; residues, evaluation of integrals; multivalued functions, potential theory in two dimensions; Fourier analysis, Laplace transforms, and partial differential equations.
<br><I>J. Orloff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.05"></a>
<p><h3>18.05 Introduction to Probability and Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11,F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-082</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary introduction with applications. Basic probability models. Combinatorics. Random variables. Discrete and continuous probability distributions. Statistical estimation and testing. Confidence intervals. Introduction to linear regression.
<br><I>D. Vogan</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.05');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.06"></a>
<p><h3>18.06 Linear Algebra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</A>
<br><a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.06/">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.06/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>T11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) or <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) or <i>T2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) or <i>T3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic subject on matrix theory and linear algebra, emphasizing topics useful in other disciplines, including systems of equations, vector spaces, determinants, eigenvalues, singular value decomposition, and positive definite matrices. Applications to least-squares approximations, stability of differential equations, networks, Fourier transforms, and Markov processes. Uses MATLAB. Compared with 18.700, more emphasis on matrix algorithms and many applications.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Johnson</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Edelman</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.06');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.062"></a>
<p><h3>18.062[J] Mathematics for Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.042">6.042[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><a href="https://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.042/spring18/">https://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.042/spring18/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-082</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>) or <i>MWF2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary discrete mathematics for computer science and engineering. Emphasis on mathematical definitions and proofs as well as on applicable methods.  Topics include formal logic notation, proof methods; induction, well-ordering; sets, relations; elementary graph theory; asymptotic notation and growth of functions; permutations and combinations, counting principles; discrete probability.  Further selected topics include recursive definition and structural induction, state machines and invariants, integer congruences, recurrences, generating functions.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Meyer</I><br>Spring: <I>Z. Abel</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.065"></a>
<p><h3>18.065 Matrix Methods in Data Analysis, Signal Processing, and Machine Learning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0651">18.0651</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-190</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reviews linear algebra with applications to life sciences, finance, engineering, and big data. Covers singular value decomposition, weighted least squares, signal and image processing, principal component analysis, covariance and correlation matrices, directed and undirected graphs, matrix factorizations, neural nets, machine learning, and computations with large matrices.
<br><I>W. Strang</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.0651"></a>

Covers singular value decomposition, weighted least squares, signal and image processing, principal component analysis, covariance and correlation matrices, directed and undirected graphs, matrix factorizations, neural nets, machine learning, and computations with large matrices. <a name="18.075"></a>
<p><h3>18.075 Methods for Scientists and Engineers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0751">18.0751</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.04">18.04</A>
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.075">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.075</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers functions of a complex variable; calculus of residues. Includes ordinary differential equations; Bessel and Legendre functions; Sturm-Liouville theory; partial differential equations; heat equation; and wave equations.
<br><I>H. Cheng</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.075');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="18.085"></a>
<p><h3>18.085 Computational Science and Engineering I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0851">18.0851</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.085">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.085</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Review of linear algebra, applications to networks, structures, and estimation, finite difference and finite element solution of differential equations, Laplace's equation and potential flow, boundary-value problems, Fourier series, discrete Fourier transform, convolution. Frequent use of MATLAB in a wide range of scientific and engineering applications.
<br>Fall: <I>W. Strang</I><br>Spring: <I>P. Saenz Hervias</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.085');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.0851"></a>
<p><h3>18.0851 Computational Science and Engineering I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)

<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9

<a name="18.086"></a>
<p><h3>18.086 Computational Science and Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0861">18.0861</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/18086/">http://math.mit.edu/18086/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Initial value problems: finite difference methods, accuracy and stability, heat equation, wave equations, conservation laws and shocks, level sets, Navier-Stokes.  Solving large systems: elimination with reordering, iterative methods, preconditioning, multigrid, Krylov subspaces, conjugate gradients. Optimization and minimum principles: weighted least squares, constraints, inverse problems, calculus of variations, saddle point problems, linear programming, duality, adjoint methods.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.0861"></a>
<p><h3>18.0861 Computational Science and Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.086">18.086</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Initial value problems: finite difference methods, accuracy and stability, heat equation, wave equations, conservation laws and shocks, level sets, Navier-Stokes.  Solving large systems: elimination with reordering, iterative methods, preconditioning, multigrid, Krylov subspaces, conjugate gradients. Optimization and minimum principles: weighted least squares, constraints, inverse problems, calculus of variations, saddle point problems, linear programming, duality, adjoint methods. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.086.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.089"></a>
<p><h3>18.089 Review of Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)

<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.094"></a>
<p><h3>18.094[J] Teaching College-Level Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.95">1.95[J]</A>, <A HREF="m5b.html#5.95">5.95[J]</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.59">7.59[J]</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.395">8.395[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2c.html#2.978">2.978</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Participatory seminar focuses on the knowledge and skills necessary for teaching science and engineering in higher education. Topics include theories of adult learning; course development; promoting active learning, problemsolving, and critical thinking in students; communicating with a diverse student body; using educational technology to further learning; lecturing; creating effective tests and assignments; and assessment and evaluation. Students research and present a relevant topic of particular interest. Appropriate for both novices and those with teaching experience.
<br><I>J. Rankin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.095"></a>
<p><h3>18.095 Mathematics Lecture Series
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.095/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.095/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Ten lectures by mathematics faculty members on interesting topics from both classical and modern mathematics. All lectures accessible to students with calculus background and an interest in mathematics. At each lecture, reading and exercises are assigned. Students prepare these for discussion in a weekly problem session.
<br><I>A. Edelman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
