<a name="20.450"></a>
<p><h3>20.450 Molecular and Cellular Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.420">20.420</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.440">20.440</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Compares the complex molecular and cellular interactions in health and disease between commensal microbial communities,  pathogens and the human or animal host. Special focus is given to current research on microbe/host interactions, infection of significant importance to public health, and chronic infectious disease. Classwork will include lecture, but emphasize critical evaluation and class discussion of recent scientific papers, and the development of new research agendas in the fields presented.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.452"></a>
<p><h3>20.452[J] Principles of Neuroengineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.422">9.422[J]</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.881">MAS.881[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.352">20.352</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers how to innovate technologies for brain analysis and engineering, for accelerating the basic understanding of the brain, and leading to new therapeutic insight and inventions. Focuses on using physical, chemical and biological principles to understand technology design criteria governing ability to observe and alter brain structure and function. Topics include optogenetics, noninvasive brain imaging and stimulation, nanotechnologies, stem cells and tissue engineering, and advanced molecular and structural imaging technologies. Includes design projects. Designed for students with engineering maturity who are ready for design. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Boyden</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.454"></a>
<p><h3>20.454[J] Revolutionary Ventures: How to Invent and Deploy Transformative Technologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.455">9.455[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.128">15.128[J]</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.883">MAS.883[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar on envisioning and building ideas and organizations to accelerate engineering revolutions. Focuses on emerging technology domains, such as neurotechnology, imaging, cryotechnology, gerontechnology, and bio-and-nano fabrication. Draws on historical examples as well as live case studies of existing or emerging organizations, including labs, institutes, startups, and companies. Goals range from accelerating basic science to developing transformative products or therapeutics. Each class is devoted to a specific area, often with invited speakers, exploring issues from the deeply technical through the strategic. Individually or in small groups, students prototype new ventures aimed at inventing and deploying revolutionary technologies.
<br><I>E. Boyden</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.463"></a>
<p><h3>20.463[J] Biomaterials Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3b.html#3.963">3.963[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.055">3.055[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.363">20.363[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.034">3.034</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers, at a molecular scale, the analysis and design of materials used in contact with biological systems, and biomimetic strategies aimed at creating new materials based on principles found in biology. Topics include molecular interaction between bio- and synthetic molecules and surfaces; design, synthesis, and processing approaches for materials that control cell functions; and application of materials science to problems in tissue engineering, drug delivery, vaccines, and cell-guiding surfaces. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. Irvine</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.465"></a>
<p><h3>20.465 Engineering the Immune System in Cancer and Beyond
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.365">20.365</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines strategies in clinical and preclinical development for manipulating the immune system to treat and protect against disease. Begins with brief review of immune system. Discusses interaction of tumors with the immune system, followed by approaches by which the immune system can be modulated to attack cancer. Also covers strategies based in biotechnology, chemistry, materials science, and molecular biology to induce immune responses to treat infection, transplantation, and autoimmunity. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.470"></a>
<p><h3>20.470[J] Cellular Neurophysiology and Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.794">2.794[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.521">6.521[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.021">9.021[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.541">HST.541[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.791">2.791[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.021">6.021[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.21">9.21[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.370">20.370[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrated overview of the biophysics of cells from prokaryotes to neurons, with a focus on mass transport and electrical signal generation across cell membrane. First third of course focuses on mass transport through membranes: diffusion, osmosis, chemically mediated, and active transport. Second third focuses on electrical properties of cells: ion transport to action potential generation and propagation in electrically excitable cells. Synaptic transmission. Electrical properties interpreted via kinetic and molecular properties of single voltage-gated ion channels. Final third focuses on biophysics of synaptic transmission and introduction to neural computing. Laboratory and computer exercises illustrate the concepts. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments.
<br><I>T. Heldt</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.475"></a>
<p><h3>20.475 Applied Developmental Biology and Tissue Engineering
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.375">20.375</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>This subject addresses the integration of engineering and biology design principles to create human tissues and organs for regenerative medicine to drug development. Overview of embryogenesis; how morphogenic phenomena are governed by biochemical and biophysical cues. Analysis of in vitro generation of human brain, gut, and other organoids from stem cells. Roles of biomaterials and microreactors in improving organoid formation and function. Organoid use in modeling disease and physiology in vitro. Engineering and biological principles of reconstructing tissues and organs from postnatal donor cells using biomaterials scaffolds and bioreactors. Select applications such as liver disease, brain disorders, and others. Graduate students will have additional assignments.
<br><I>L. Griffith</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.482"></a>
<p><h3>20.482[J] Foundations of Algorithms and Computational Techniques in Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.581">6.581[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.503">6.503</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.021">6.021</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.034">6.034</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.336">6.336</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.417">18.417</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Illustrates computational approaches to solving problems in systems biology. Uses a series of case studies to demonstrate how an effective match between the statement of a biological problem and the selection of an appropriate algorithm or computational technique can lead to fundamental advances. Covers several discrete and numerical algorithms used in simulation, feature extraction, and optimization for molecular, network, and systems models in biology. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.486"></a>
<p><h3>20.486[J] Case Studies and Strategies in Drug Discovery and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.549">7.549[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.137">15.137[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.916">HST.916[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><a href="http://mit.edu/7.549j">http://mit.edu/7.549j</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Aims to develop appreciation for the stages of drug discovery and development, from target identification, to the submission of preclinical and clinical data to regulatory authorities for marketing approval. Following introductory lectures on the process of drug development, students working in small teams analyze how one of four new drugs or drug candidates traversed the discovery/development landscape. For each case, an outside expert from the sponsoring drug company or pivotal clinical trial principal investigator provides guidance and critiques the teams' presentations to the class.
<br><I>A. Wood</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.487"></a>
<p><h3>20.487[J] Optical Microscopy and Spectroscopy for Biology and Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.715">2.715[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the theory and the design of optical microscopy and its applications in biology and medicine.  The course starts from an overview of basic optical principles allowing an understanding of microscopic image formation and common contrast modalities such as dark field, phase, and DIC.  Advanced microscopy imaging techniques such as total internal reflection, confocal, and multiphoton will also be discussed.  Quantitative analysis of biochemical microenvironment using spectroscopic techniques based on fluorescence, second harmonic, Raman signals will be covered.  We will also provide an overview of key image processing techniques for microscopic data.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.490"></a>
<p><h3>20.490 Foundations of Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.802">6.802[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.874">6.874[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.390">20.390[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.506">HST.506[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.0002">6.0002</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>; or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.91/">http://web.mit.edu/7.91/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to computational and systems biology. Includes units on the analysis of protein and nucleic acid sequences, protein structures, and biological networks. Presents principles and methods used for sequence alignment, motif finding, expression array analysis, structural modeling, structure design and prediction, and network analysis and modeling. Techniques include dynamic programming, Markov and hidden Markov models, Bayesian networks, clustering methods, and energy minimization approaches. Exposes students to emerging research areas. Designed for students with strong backgrounds in either molecular biology or computer science. Some foundational material covering basic programming skills, probability and statistics is provided for students with less quantitative backgrounds. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.507"></a>
<p><h3>20.507[J] Biological Chemistry I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5a.html#5.07">5.07[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Chemical and physical properties of the cell and its building blocks. Structures of proteins and principles of catalysis. The chemistry of organic/inorganic cofactors required for chemical transformations within the cell. Basic principles of metabolism and regulation in pathways, including glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, fatty acid synthesis/degradation, pentose phosphate pathway, Krebs cycle and oxidative phosphorylation, DNA replication, and transcription and translation.
<br><I>A. Klibanov, E. Nolan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.554"></a>
<p><h3>20.554[J] Frontiers in Chemical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5b.html#5.54">5.54[J]</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.540">7.540[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to current research at the interface of chemistry, biology, and bioengineering. Topics include imaging of biological processes, metabolic pathway engineering, protein engineering, mechanisms of DNA damage, RNA structure and function, macromolecular machines, protein misfolding and disease, metabolomics, and methods for analyzing signaling network dynamics. Lectures are interspersed with class discussions and student presentations based on current literature.
<br><I>L. Kiessling</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.560"></a>
<p><h3>20.560 Statistics for Biological Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides basic tools for analyzing experimental data, interpreting statistical reports in the literature, and reasoning under uncertain situations. Topics include probability theory, statistical tests, data exploration, Bayesian statistics, and machine learning. Emphasizes discussion and hands-on learning. Experience with MATLAB, Python, or R recommended.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.586"></a>
<p><h3>20.586[J] Science and Business of Biotechnology
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.546">7.546[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15b.html#15.480">15.480[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the new types of drugs and other therapeutics in current practice and under development, the financing and business structures of early-stage biotechnology companies, and the evaluation of their risk/reward profiles. Includes a series of live case studies with industry leaders of both established and emerging biotechnology companies as guest speakers, focusing on the underlying science and engineering as well as core financing and business issues. Students must possess a basic background in cellular and molecular biology.
<br><I>A. Lo, H. Lodish</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=20.586');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>20.903 Independent Study in Biological Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="20.920"></a>
<p><h3>20.920 Practical Work Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-1-0 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For Course 20 students participating in off-campus work experiences in biological engineering. Before registering for this subject, students must have an employment offer from a company or organization and must identify a BE supervisor. Upon completion of the work, student must submit a letter from the employer describing the work accomplished, along with a substantive final report from the student approved by the MIT supervisor. Subject to departmental approval. Consult departmental undergraduate office.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Fares</I><br>IAP: <I>D. Fares</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Fares</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.930"></a>
<p><h3>20.930[J] Research Experience in Biopharma
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.930">7.930[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-10-0
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides exposure to industrial science and develops skills necessary for success in such an environment. Under the guidance of an industrial mentor, students participate in on-site research at a local biopharmaceutical company where they observe and participate in industrial science. Serves as a real-time case study to internalize the factors that shape R&D in industry, including the purpose and scope of a project, key decision points in the past and future, and strategies for execution. Students utilize company resources and work with a scientific team to contribute to the goals of their assigned project; they then present project results to the company and class, emphasizing the logic that dictated their work and their ideas for future directions. Lecture component focuses on professional development.
<br><I>S. Clarke</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.950"></a>
<p><h3>20.950 Research Problems in Biological Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For qualified graduate students interested in teaching. Tutorial, laboratory, or classroom teaching under the supervision of a faculty member. Enrollment limited by availability of suitable teaching assignments.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Fares</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Fares</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>20.BME Undergraduate Research in Biomedical Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Individual research project with biomedical or clinical focus, arranged with appropriate faculty member or approved supervisor. Forms and instructions for the proposal and final report are available in the BE Undergraduate Office.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Fares</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Fares</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.EPW"></a>
<p><h3>20.EPW UPOP Engineering Practice Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1c.html#1.EPW">1.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.EPW">2.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.EPW">3.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.EPW">6.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m10b.html#10.EPW">10.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m16a.html#16.EPW">16.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.EPW">20.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.EPW">22.EPW</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops foundational skills for the world of practice in science, technology, and engineering. Sophomores receive classroom instruction, and one-on-one and small-group coaching in basics of professional identity building. They attend field trips to local employers and receive job interview practice, coached by industry volunteers. Over IAP, students attend a weeklong Team Training Camp of experiential learning modules - led by MIT faculty with the help of MIT alums and other senior professionals in business, engineering, and science where students participate in creative simulations, team problem-solving challenges, and oral presentations, and practice networking with employers. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Crim</I><br>IAP: <I>J. Crim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.S900"></a>

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 21: Humanities<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate"><i>Course 21 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=21&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>21.TH-21.URG</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>Research subjects are also offered by programs within the Department of Humanities: Anthropology (21A), Comparative Media Studies/Writing (CMS/21W), Global Studies and Languages (21G), History (21H), Literature (21L), Music and Theater Arts (21M), Science, Technology, and Society (STS), and Women's and Gender Studies (WGS).  Consult those listings for details.
<a name="21.THT"></a>
<p><h3>21.THT Humanities Pre-Thesis Tutorial
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: As specified for particular field
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Definition of and early-stage work on thesis project leading to 21.THU Undergraduate Thesis in Humanities. Taken during the first term of the student's two-term commitment to the thesis project. Student works closely with an individual faculty tutor. Required for all students in Course 21, and those doing 21-E and 21-S degrees, for whom the thesis is a degree requirement.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21.THU"></a>
<p><h3>21.THU Undergraduate Thesis in Humanities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m21a.html#21.THT">21.THT</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Completion of work on the senior major thesis under supervision of a faculty tutor. Includes oral presentation of thesis progress early in the term, assembling and revising the final text, and meeting at the close with a committee of faculty evaluators to discuss the successes and limitations of the project. Required for most students in Course 21 and those doing 21-E and 21-S degrees.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>IAP: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21.UR"></a>
<p><h3>21.UR Undergraduate Research in Humanities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Individual participation in an ongoing research project. For students in the Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>IAP: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21.URG"></a>
<h3>21.URG Research in Humanities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->

<br>Fall: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>IAP: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
