<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 21W: Writing<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://writing.mit.edu/"><i>Course 21W Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course21W.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=21W&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+21W&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>Introductory Subjects & Creative Writing</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m21Wb.html">Science Writing, Digital Media, & Additional Subjects</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>The Program in Writing offers introductory writing as well as advanced coursework in these areas:<br> <br> 1) Creative Writing; <br> 2) Science Writing; and <br> 3) Digital Media.
<h2>First-Year Writing Subjects</h2>
<p>Students write frequently, give and receive feedback on work in progress, improve their work by revising, read the work of accomplished writers, and participate actively in class discussions and workshops.  Short oral presentations are also required.  Emphasizes writing with an awareness of audience and purpose.  <i>Writing and Rhetoric</i> focuses on forms of exposition, including narration, critique, argument, and persuasion, to develop students' ability to write clear and effective prose.  <i>Writing and Experience</i> focuses on the ways writers transform experience into finished and polished writing in the forms of essay, memoir, and autobiography.  <i>Science Writing and New Media</i> focuses on writing about science and new media and develops students' ability to write clear and effective prose for a range of media.  <i>Writing about Literature</i> focuses on reading and writing skills used to analyze literary texts.  <i>Writing with Shakespeare</i> focuses on writing and speaking, using Shakespeare as a model.  Readings and assignments vary by subject and focus on themes relevant to each genre.  <br>
<h2>Creative Writing</h2>
<h3><br>Introductory</h3>
<a name="21W.011"></a>
<p><h3>21W.011 Writing and Rhetoric: Rhetoric and Contemporary Issues
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.012">21W.012</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.013">21W.013</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.014">21W.014</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.015">21W.015</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.016">21W.016</A>
<br><a href="http://writing.mit.edu/academics/undergraduate/first-year">http://writing.mit.edu/academics/undergraduate/first-year</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR EVE (7-8.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-119</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides the opportunity for students - as readers, viewers, writers, and speakers - to engage with social and ethical issues they care deeply about. Explores perspectives on a range of social issues, such as the responsibilities of citizens, freedom of expression, poverty and homelessness, mental illness, the challenges of an aging society, the politics of food, and racial and gender inequality. Discusses rhetorical strategies that aim to increase awareness of social problems; to educate the public about different perspectives on contemporary issues; and to persuade readers of the value of particular positions on, or solutions to, social problems. Students analyze selected texts and photographs, as well as documentary and feature films, that represent or dramatize social problems or issues. Students also write essays about social and ethical issues of their own choice. Limited to 18.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Walsh</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Walsh</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.012"></a>
<p><h3>21W.012 Writing and Rhetoric: Food for Thought
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.011">21W.011</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.013">21W.013</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.014">21W.014</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.015">21W.015</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.016">21W.016</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores many of the issues that surround food as both material fact and personal and cultural symbol. Includes non-fiction works on topics such as family meals, food's ability to awaken us to "our own powers of enjoyment" (M.F.K. Fisher), and eating as an "agricultural act" (W. Berry). Students read Michael Pollan's best-selling book <i>In Defense of Food</i> and discuss the issues it raises about America's food supply and eating habits, as well as the rhetorical strategies it employs. Assignments include narratives, analytical essays, and research-based essays. Limited to 18.
<br><I>S. Carlisle</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.013"></a>
<p><h3>21W.013 Writing and Rhetoric: Introduction to Contemporary Rhetoric
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.011">21W.011</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.012">21W.012</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.014">21W.014</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.015">21W.015</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.016">21W.016</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers how rhetoric shapes current events in politics, science, and society.  Students study rhetoric as a theoretical framework for developing persuasive arguments, as a method of analyzing written, oral, and visual texts, and as a mode of human inquiry.  Assignments include analytical, persuasive, and research-based essays, as well as oral presentations, group discussions, and debates.  Readings drawn from political speeches, scientific arguments, and popular media. Limited to 18.
<br><I>E. Harrison Lepera</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.014"></a>
<p><h3>21W.014 Writing and Rhetoric: Exploring Visual Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.011">21W.011</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.012">21W.012</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.013">21W.013</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.015">21W.015</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.016">21W.016</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the rhetoric of visual media and the meaning of the digital revolution. Students analyze readings and films and discuss the power of media in defining social issues and shaping ideas of self, family, and community. They also write essays that sharpen skills in analyzing visual rhetoric, developing and supporting arguments, and using sources. Limited to 18.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.015"></a>
<p><h3>21W.015 Writing and Rhetoric: Writing about Sports
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.011">21W.011</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.012">21W.012</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.013">21W.013</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.014">21W.014</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.016">21W.016</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the role of sports in our individual lives and American culture at large. Considers a broad range of issues, such as heroism and ethical conundrums, gender equality, steroids, and the proper role of sports in college life.  Examples of high-quality, descriptive and analytic sports writing serve as the focus for class discussion and as models for student essays. Limited to 18.
<br><I>K. Boiko</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.016"></a>
<p><h3>21W.016 Writing and Rhetoric: Designing Meaning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.011">21W.011</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.012">21W.012</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.013">21W.013</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.014">21W.014</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.015">21W.015</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores how we use rhetoric in text, visuals, and other modes to make meaning.  Uses analysis, composition, and debate about rhetorical strategies to develop theoretical and empirical knowledge of how design choices shape our texts and our understanding of the world.  In lab, students experiment with rhetorical strategies and assess their effects. Limited to 18.
<br><I>S. Lane</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.021"></a>
<p><h3>21W.021 Writing and Experience: MIT Inside, Live
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.022">21W.022</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.026">21W.026</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Acting as participant-observers, students investigate MIT's history and culture through visits to the Institute's archives and museums, relevant readings, and depictions of MIT in popular culture. Students chronicle their experiences and insights through a variety of writing projects, culminating in the completion of a portfolio. Limited to 18.
<br><I>J. Graziano</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.022"></a>
<p><h3>21W.022 Writing and Experience: Reading and Writing Autobiography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.021">21W.021</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.026">21W.026</A>
<br><a href="http://writing.mit.edu/academics/undergraduate/first-year">http://writing.mit.edu/academics/undergraduate/first-year</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-169</a>) or <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-162</a>) or <i>TR3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-169</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Draws on a range of autobiographical writing as examples for students to analyze. Students write essays that focus on their own experience, exploring topics such as intellectual growth and development, the childhood and high school years, life at MIT, the influence of place upon one's personality and character, and the role politics and religion play in one's life. Emphasizes clarity, specificity, and structure; investigates various modes of writing (narrative, analytical, expository) and their suitability for different purposes. Limited to 18.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Harrison Lepera, N. Jackson, S. Carlisle</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Harrison Lepera, S. Carlisle, A. Walsh</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.026"></a>
<p><h3>21W.026 Writing and Experience: The Hero in the Postmodern World
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.021">21W.021</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.022">21W.022</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students examine and analyze concepts of the hero - from ancient Greece through the writings of Jung and Joseph Campbell - using the lens of postmodernist thought and critical theory, which largely reject the concept of a hero as role model or ideal. Studies the flaws of the great leaders of earlier times and discusses how the image of the hero influences world view, informs choices, and functions as metaphor in ethical dilemmas. Explores the characteristics that define a hero and how they have changed over time. Considers whether or not certain figures meet the definition of a hero, whether their deeds remain compelling, and whether they still deserve a place in cultural dialog. Students read essays, fiction, and plays depicting heroes in both literature and history, and use workshops and revision to turn ideas and experience into powerful written communication. Limited to 18.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.031"></a>
<p><h3>21W.031 Science Writing and New Media: Explorations in Communicating about Science and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.032">21W.032</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.034">21W.034</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.035">21W.035</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.036">21W.036</A>
<br><a href="http://writing.mit.edu/academics/undergraduate/first-year">http://writing.mit.edu/academics/undergraduate/first-year</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR12.30-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-180</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines principles of good writing, focusing on those associated with scientific and technical writing. Considers the effects of new media as an avenue for communicating about science. Students discuss scientific articles and essays and work in small groups to critique each other's writing. Assignments include a critical review, a science essay for the general public, and a research or service project proposal. Students choose topics that reflect their background and interests. Formal and informal presentations and group discussions develop oral communication skills. Limited to 18.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Melvold</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Melvold</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.032"></a>
<p><h3>21W.032 Science Writing and New Media: Introduction to Digital Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.031">21W.031</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.034">21W.034</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.035">21W.035</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.036">21W.036</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on digital media production and associated written and oral reports. Working individually and in small, collaborative teams, students create a variety of digital media projects throughout the term, culminating in a larger final project of their choosing. Assignments include audio and video essays, website design, games and interactive fiction, mobile technology, and readings. Students write bi-weekly short essays analyzing their digital projects, as well as a proposal, progress report and completion report for the final project. Limited to 18.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.034"></a>
<p><h3>21W.034 Science Writing and New Media: Perspectives on Medicine and Public Health
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.031">21W.031</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.032">21W.032</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.035">21W.035</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.036">21W.036</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Public health topics, such as AIDS, asthma, malaria control, obesity, and sleep deprivation, provide a unifying focus as students explore diverse modes of science writing. Readings include essays by such writers as Atul Gawande, Danielle Ofri, Jerome Groopman, and William Carlos Williams, as well as peer-reviewed journal articles.  Assignments include a critical review, a scientific literature review, a brochure suitable for general distribution, an autobiographical narrative, a resume, a job application letter, and oral presentations. Limited to 18.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.035"></a>
<p><h3>21W.035 Science Writing and New Media: Elements of Science Writing for the Public
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.031">21W.031</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.032">21W.032</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.034">21W.034</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.036">21W.036</A>
<br><a href="http://writing.mit.edu/academics/undergraduate/first-year">http://writing.mit.edu/academics/undergraduate/first-year</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-253</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to writing about science (including medicine, technology, and engineering) for general readers. Emphasizes background research as a foundation for strong science writing. Students read works by accomplished science writers.  Each assignment focuses on a different popular form, such as news article, interview, essay, and short feature. Limited to 18.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Berezin, A. Carleton</I><br>Spring: <I>K. Boiko</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=21W.035');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.036"></a>
<p><h3>21W.036 Science Writing and New Media: Writing and the Environment
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.031">21W.031</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.032">21W.032</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.034">21W.034</A>, <A HREF="m21Wa.html#21W.035">21W.035</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops written and oral communication skills through the study and practice of environmental science writing.  Covers a wide range of genres, including such standard forms as the scientific literature review. Students adapt the content of their papers and oral presentations to the distinctive needs of specific audiences. Assignments provide thematic coherence and a basis for independent student research. Limited to 18.
<br><I>C. Taft</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.041"></a>
<p><h3>21W.041[J] Writing About Literature
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.000">21L.000[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive focus on the reading and writing skills used to analyze literary texts such as poems by Emily Dickinson, Shakespeare or Langston Hughes; short stories by Chekhov, Joyce, or Alice Walker; and a short novel by Melville or Toni Morrison. Designed not only to prepare students for further work in writing and literary and media study, but also to provide increased confidence and pleasure in their reading, writing, and analytical skills. Students write or revise essays weekly. Enrollment limited.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.042"></a>
<p><h3>21W.042[J] Writing with Shakespeare
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cihw.gif" alt="Communication Intensive Writing" title="Communication Intensive Writing" width="32" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.010">21L.010[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on writing and speaking using Shakespeare as a model and means for mastery of English language skills. Emphasizes the development of students' ability to write clearly and effectively in a range of genres with an awareness of audience. Designed to increase students' confidence and pleasure in verbal communication and analysis of language. Students write frequently, give and receive feedback, improve their work through revision, and participate actively in class discussions and presentations. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>D. Henderson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h3><br>Advanced</h3>
<a name="21W.735"></a>
<p><h3>21W.735 Writing and Reading the Essay
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Writing sample and permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exploration of formal and informal modes of writing nonfiction prose. Extensive practice in composition, revision, and editing. Reading in the literature of the essay from the Renaissance to the present, with an emphasis on modern writers. Classes alternate between discussion of published readings and workshops on student work. Individual conferences. Limited to 18.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.740"></a>
<p><h3>21W.740 Writing Autobiography and Biography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Writing an autobiography is a vehicle for improving one's style while studying the nuances of the language. Literary works are read with an emphasis on different forms of autobiography. Students examine various stages of life, significant transitions, personal struggles, and memories translated into narrative prose, and discuss: what it means for autobiographer and biographer to develop a personal voice; and the problems of reality and fiction in autobiography and biography.
<br><I>K. Manning</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.741"></a>
<p><h3>21W.741[J] Black Matters:  Introduction to Black Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassAH.gif" alt="Arts + Humanities" title="Arts + Humanities" width="35" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24b.html#24.912">24.912[J]</A>, <A HREF="m21Ha.html#21H.106">21H.106[J]</A>, <A HREF="m21La.html#21L.008">21L.008[J]</A>, <A HREF="mWGSa.html#WGS.190">WGS.190[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary survey of people of African descent that draws on the overlapping approaches of history, literature, anthropology, legal studies, media studies, performance, linguistics, and creative writing. Connects the experiences of African-Americans and of other American minorities, focusing on social, political, and cultural histories, and on linguistic patterns. Includes lectures, discussions, workshops, and required field trips that involve minimal cost to students.
<br><I>M. DeGraff, D. Fox Harrell</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.742"></a>
<p><h3>21W.742[J] Writing about Race
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mWGSa.html#WGS.231">WGS.231[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The issue of race and racial identity have preoccupied many writers throughout the history of the US. Students read Jessica Abel, Diana Abu-Jaber, Lynda Barry, Felicia Luna Lemus, James McBride, Sigrid Nunez, Ruth Ozeki, Danzy Senna, Gloria Anzaldua, Judith Ortiz Cofer, Carmit Delman, Stefanie Dunning, Cherrie Moraga, Hiram Perez and others, and consider the story of race in its peculiarly American dimensions. The reading, along with the writing of members of the class, is the focus of class discussions. Oral presentations on subjects of individual interest are also part of the class activities. Students explore race and ethnicity in personal essays, pieces of cultural criticism or analysis, or (with permission of instructor) fiction. All written work is read and responded to in class workshops and subsequently revised. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>K. Ragusa</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.743"></a>
<p><h3>21W.743 Voice and Meaning: Speaking to Readers through Memoir
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the memoir genre with particular attention to the relationships between form and content, fact and truth, self and community, art and "healing," coming to voice and breaking silence. Readings include works by Nick Flynn, Meena Alexander, Art Spigelman, James McBride, Ruth Ozeki, and Cheryl Strayed, with a focus on the ways in which these writers make meaning out of specific events or moments in their own lives as a way of engaging with larger questions of family, race, history, loss, and survivorship. Drawing on lessons taken from these works, students write a short memoir of their own. Limited to 18.
<br><I>K. Ragusa</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=21W.743');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.744"></a>
<p><h3>21W.744 The Art of Comic Book Writing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students create short scripts and full-length comic book narratives across a variety of genres, while analyzing a wide range of comics (corporate and independent, print and web). Focuses on scripts; drawing skills not required, but illustrations or storyboards are welcome. Special attention to questions of gender, race, ethnicity, and sexuality in both critical and creative work. Limited to 13.
<br><I>M. Liu</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.745"></a>
<p><h3>21W.745 Advanced Essay Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students with experience in writing essays and nonfiction prose. Focuses on negotiating and representing identities grounded in gender, race, class, nationality, and sexuality in prose that is expository, exploratory, investigative, persuasive, lyrical, or incantatory. Authors include James Baldwin, Minnie Bruce Pratt, Audre Lorde, Richard Rodriguez, Alice Walker, John Edgar Wideman, Diana Hume George, bell hooks, Margaret Atwood, Patricia J. Williams, and others. Designed to help students build upon their strengths as writers and to expand their repertoire of styles and approaches in essay writing. Approved for credit in Women's and Gender Studies when content meets the requirements for subjects in that program. Limited to 18.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.747"></a>
<p><h3>21W.747 Rhetoric
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>) or <i>TR2-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-136</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students with a special interest in learning how to make forceful arguments in written form. Studies the forms and structures of argumentation, including organization of ideas, awareness of audience, methods of persuasion, evidence, factual vs. emotional argument, figures of speech, and historical forms and uses of arguments. Limited to 18 per section.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Strang</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Strang, A. Karatsolis</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=21W.747');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.748"></a>
<p><h3>21W.748 Apocalyptic Storytelling
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.848">CMS.848</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the critical making of apocalyptic, post-apocalyptic and dystopian stories across various narrative media.  Considers the long history of Western apocalypticism as well as the uses and abuses of apocalypticism across time.  Examines a wide variety of influential texts in order to enhance students' creative and theoretical repertoires.  Students create their own apocalyptic stories and present on selected texts.  Investigates conventions such as plague, zombies, nuclear destruction, robot uprising, alien invasion, environmental collapse, and supernatural calamities. Considers questions of race, gender, sexuality, colonialism, trauma, memory, witness, and genocide. Intended for students with prior creative writing experience. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 15.
<br><I>J. Diaz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.754"></a>
<p><h3>21W.754[J] Playwriting I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Mb.html#21M.604">21M.604[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the craft of writing for the theater, with special attention to the "play" in playwriting. Through weekly assignments and in-class exercises, students explore scene structure, action, events, voice, and dialogue. In workshop format, students present individual work for feedback and are encouraged to bring a sense of fun, joy and playfulness to their writing. Readings include published plays, which provide exposure to a variety of styles, voices, and structures. Emphasizes process, risk taking, and finding one's own voice and vision.
<br><I>K. Urban</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.755"></a>
<p><h3>21W.755 Writing and Reading Short Stories
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>) or <i>W1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=14">14N-325</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An introduction to writing fiction. Students write their own stories and study essays and short stories by contemporary authors from around the world. Discussion focuses on students' writing and on assigned works in their historical and social contexts.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Lewitt, M. Nathan</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Lewitt, M. Nathan</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=21W.755');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.756"></a>
<p><h3>21W.756 Writing and Reading Poems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examination of the formal structural and textual variety in poetry. Extensive practice in the making of poems and the analysis of both students' manuscripts and texts from 16th- through 20th-century literature. Attempts to make relevant the traditional elements of poetry and their contemporary alternatives. Weekly writing assignments, including some exercises in prosody.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.757"></a>
<p><h3>21W.757 Fiction Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m21Wa.html#21W.755">21W.755</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intermediate class for students with some experience in writing fiction. Students write short stories and complete other writing exercises. Readings include short story collections by contemporary writers such as Sandra Cisneros, Benjamin Percy, Leila Lalami, Laura Pritchett, Bret Anthony Johnston, and Edward P. Jones. Discussions focus on sources of story material, characterization, setting, architecture, point of view, narrative voice, and concrete detail.
<br><I>H. Lee</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.758"></a>
<p><h3>21W.758 Genre Fiction Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students read texts in genres such as fantasy, science fiction, historical fiction, noir, and horror, typically focusing on one genre exclusively in a given semester. Formats may include short stories, novels, films, TV shows and other narrative media. Considers genre protocols and how to write within the restrictions and freedoms associated with each genre. Students write fiction within a genre (or "between" genres) for roundtable workshopping. Intended for students with prior creative writing experience. Limited to 15.
<br><I>S. Lewitt</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.759"></a>
<p><h3>21W.759 Writing Science Fiction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students write and read science fiction and analyze and discuss stories written for the class. For the first eight weeks, readings in contemporary science fiction accompany lectures and formal writing assignments intended to illuminate various aspects of writing craft as well as the particular problems of writing science fiction. The rest of the term is given to roundtable workshops on students' stories.
<br><I>S. Lewitt</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.760"></a>
<p><h3>21W.760 Creative Writing and Visual Culture: Writing in the Museum
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Critically explores how and why objects are collected and consumed, drawing upon visual culture and museum and cultural studies. Students engage in forms of creative writing that imitate museums, enact curatorial gestures, and/or try to dismantle such structures. They also curate their own writing into a chapbook, blog, or other creative form. Readings cover a range of genres. Includes visits to actual and virtual galleries.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.761"></a>
<p><h3>21W.761 (un)Writing the Book
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the material and historical components of books, dissecting and regenerating individual and collective writings into new forms. Students engage in weekly creative experiments and other exercises, handle rare books on field trips to Special Collections, and edit collaborative chapbooks. Examines the history and mystery of the book, considering where this technology has come from and envisioning where it might go.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.762"></a>
<p><h3>21W.762 Poetry Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students with some previous experience in poetry writing. Frequent assignments stress use of language, diction, word choice, line breaks, imagery, mood, and tone. Considers the functions of memory, imagination, dreams, poetic impulses. Throughout the term, students examine the work of published poets. Revision stressed.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Barrett</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Barrett</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.769"></a>
<p><h3>21W.769[J] Playwrights' Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Mb.html#21M.785">21M.785[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m21Mb.html#21M.789">21M.789</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m21Mb.html#21M.604">21M.604</a>, <a href="m21Wa.html#21W.754">21W.754</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W97">W97-267</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continued work in the development of play scripts for the theater. Writers work on sustained pieces in weekly workshop meetings, individual consultation with the instructor, and in collaboration with student actors, directors, and designers. Fully developed scripts eligible for inclusion in the Playwrights' Workshop production. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Enrollment may be limited.
<br><I>K. Urban</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=21W.769&Source=21M.785');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.770"></a>
<p><h3>21W.770 Advanced Fiction Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students with some experience in writing fiction. Write longer works of fiction and short stories which are related or interconnected. Read short story collections by individual writers, such as Sandra Cisneros, Raymond Carver, Edward P. Jones, and Tillie Olsen, and discuss them critically and analytically, with attention to the ways in which the writers' choices about component parts contribute to meaning. In-class exercises and weekly workshops of student work focus on sources of story material, characterization, structure, narrative voice, point of view and concrete detail. Concentration on revision.
<br><I>H. Lee</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=21W.770');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.771"></a>
<p><h3>21W.771 Advanced Poetry Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Prior manuscript submission required
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-265</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For students experienced in writing poems. Regular reading of published contemporary poets and weekly submission of manuscripts for class review and criticism. Students expected to do a substantial amount of rewriting and revision. Classwork supplemented with individual conferences.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Funkhouser</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Funkhouser</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21W.773"></a>
<p><h3>21W.773 Writing Longer Fiction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: A fiction workshop or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed for students who have some experience in writing fiction and want to try longer forms like the novella and novel. Students interested in writing a novel are expected to produce at least two chapters and an outline of the complete work. Readings include several novels from Fitzgerald to the present, and novellas from Gogol's <I>The Overcoat</I> to current examples. Students discuss one another's writing in a roundtable workshop, with a strong emphasis on revision.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
<hr width="90%" align="center">

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 21G: Global Studies and Languages<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/"><i>Course 21G Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course21G.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp;
