<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Edgerton Center<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/edgerton/"><i>EC Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=EC&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++EC&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>EC.00-EC.UR</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>The Edgerton Center specializes in experiential learning and offers interactive subjects in electronics, high-speed photography, and video production.   The center is also the home of D-Lab classes (see <a href="mECa.html#EC.700">EC.700</a>-<a href="mECa.html#EC.792">EC.792</a>).
<h2>Seminars</h2>
<a name="EC.050"></a>
<p><h3>EC.050 Re-create Experiments from History: Inform the Future from the Past
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.090">EC.090</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-3-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-410</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T4,R3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-410</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides perspective for thinking about the future through the study of historical physical science and historically significant experiments. Designed to build awareness of the unexpected through both observation of the sky and lab activities that focus on light, electricity, and motion. Labs are complemented by museum and site visits; readings include accounts by Galileo, Archimedes, and other historical observers. Individual and team assignments provide opportunities to develop skills in observation, exploration, and evaluation. Students must keep an observing notebook and write a reflective paper; students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Cavicchi</I><br>IAP: <I>E. Cavicchi</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Cavicchi</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.074"></a>
<p><h3>EC.074 The Start-up Experience at MIT
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores some of the critical actions in starting up a technology-based business, including concept generation, searching prior art and patents, protecting intellectual property, founders agreements, forming and building teams, and work-life balance. Students review case studies and complete exercises that develop practicable knowledge in these areas.  Each student keeps an "idea log book," which includes critical assessments of each case study, to be presented at the end of the term. First in a two-part series (seminars do not have to be taken sequentially; see EC.075 in spring term). Preference to undergraduates; open to graduate students with permission of advisor.
<br><I>J. Hadzima</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.075"></a>
<p><h3>EC.075 Starting Up New Technology-Based Business Enterprises at MIT
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (7-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-402</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar participants define and study the development stages of new enterprises at MIT, from the exciting moment a new idea for a tech product or service is realized, through to selling, customer support, and the next new idea. Follows the history of successful MIT spin-off companies with attention to the people (and their ideas) behind the start-up. Students attend MIT technology and science start-up case presentations given by individuals and teams working from zero-stage, and by partners in going concerns of historical relevance to the Institute and the economy.  Second in a two-part series (seminars do not have to be taken sequentially; see EC.074 in fall term).
<br><I>J. Hadzima</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.090"></a>
<p><h3>EC.090 Re-create Experiments from History: Inform the Future from the Past
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.050">EC.050</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-3-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-410</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T4,R3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-410</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides perspective for thinking about the future through the study of historical physical science and historically significant experiments. Designed to build awareness of the unexpected through both observation of the sky and lab activities that focus on light, electricity, and motion. Labs are complemented by museum and site visits; readings include accounts by Galileo, Archimedes, and other historical observers. Individual and team assignments provide opportunities to develop skills in observation, exploration, and evaluation. Students must keep an observing notebook and write a reflective paper; students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Electronics and Programming</h2>
<a name="EC.110"></a>
<p><h3>EC.110[J] Introduction to Digital Electronics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.072">6.072[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-3-3 [P/D/F]
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design your own circuits for times when off-the-shelf solutions are not available. Seminar begins with assembly of a utility board. Weekly labs cover digital logic gates, memory elements, and finite-state machine design. Seminar concludes with a team-based design project. Preference given to freshmen. Maximum of 10 students per term, lottery at the first class session if oversubscribed .
<br><I>J. Bales</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.120"></a>
<p><h3>EC.120[J] Electronics Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.070">6.070[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-409</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intuition-based introduction to electronics, electronic components and test equipment such as oscilloscopes, meters (voltage, resistance inductance, capacitance, etc.), and signal generators. Emphasizes individual instruction and development of skills, such as soldering, assembly, and troubleshooting. Students design, build, and keep a small electronics project to put their new knowledge into practice. Intended for students with little or no previous background in electronics. Enrollment may be limited.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Bales</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Bales</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Imaging and Visualization</h2>
<a name="EC.210"></a>
<p><h3>EC.210 Visualization for Mathematics, Science, and Technology Education
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles and techniques for visual communication of educational concepts in mathematics, the natural sciences, and engineering. Students complete interactive assignments and class activities in visual arts media, such as photography, illustration, stop-motion and computer animation, and web graphics. A final project in a visual arts medium of the student's choice must meet professional aesthetic standards for visualization; it must also be applicable for teaching and learning concepts in mathematics, science, or engineering in a formal or informal setting. Coursework requires use of production equipment (e.g., photo and video cameras) and software tools (Adobe Creative Suite, Final Cut Studio, and Maya) at the New Media Center. Limited to 18.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Media and Production</h2>
<a name="EC.305"></a>
<p><h3>EC.305 Digital and Darkroom Imaging
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with EC.A305)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.310">EC.310</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students use both film and digital photography to develop a creative imaging project of their own choice. Develops skills in the use of image editing software to enhance, select, and combine images that the student has taken. Uses the darkroom to develop film for scanning and for chemical enlargement. Discusses topics such as the camera, composition, lighting, modes and formats, image compression, and halftone and dye sublimation printing. Students are expected to produce a duplicate set of black and white and/or color prints, along with a writeup and digital copy as the project output.
<br><I>T. Mislick</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.310"></a>
<p><h3>EC.310 Creative Imaging
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-1-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.305">EC.305</A>, EC.A305
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-402</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on film and digital photography. Develops skill in the use of chemical darkrooms, scanners, digital printers and cameras to create striking still images capable of evoking strong emotional and intellectual responses from a viewer. Emphasizes the interplay between classical chemical and digital techniques and how they can be used to control the use of lighting, color, depth, and composition in an image. Students present their intermediate assignments to the class for critical discussion; at the end of the term, they submit a substantive project presenting their own creative images for critique and evaluation.
<br><I>T. Mislick</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Engineering and Design</h2>
<h2>Culture and International Experience</h2>
<h2>D-Lab</h2>
<a name="EC.700"></a>
<p><h3>EC.700 D-Lab: Field Study
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: One D-Lab subject, permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides the opportunity to gain direct fieldwork experience in a global context. Subject spans three-four weeks in which students continue work from a prior D-Lab subject. Students work directly with international community partners to find solutions to real world problems, focusing on one or more issues in education, design, or public service. Group presentations and written reflection required.
<br><I>A. Smith</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.701"></a>
<p><h3>EC.701[J] D-Lab: Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.025">11.025[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m11c.html#11.472">11.472[J]</A>, <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.781">EC.781[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Issues in international development, appropriate technology and project implementation addressed through lectures, case studies, guest speakers and laboratory exercises. Students form project teams to partner with community organizations in developing countries, and formulate plans for an optional IAP site visit. (Previous field sites include Ghana, Brazil, Honduras and India.) Recitation sections focus on specific project implementation, and include cultural, social, political, environmental and economic overviews of the target countries as well as an introduction to the local languages. Enrollment limited by lottery; must attend first class session.
<br><I>S. Hsu</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.702"></a>
<p><h3>EC.702[J] Cross-Cultural Investigations: Technology and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.801">21A.801[J]</A>, <A HREF="mSTSa.html#STS.071">STS.071[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.792">EC.792[J]</A>, <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.839">21A.839[J]</A>, <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.481">STS.481[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Enhances cross-cultural understanding through discussion of practical, ethical, and epistemological issues in conducting social science and applied research in foreign countries or unfamiliar communities. Includes research practicum to help students develop interviewing, participant-observation, and other qualitative research skills, as well as critical discussion of case studies. Open to all interested students, but intended particularly for those planning to undertake exploratory research or applied work abroad. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.711"></a>
<p><h3>EC.711[J] D-Lab: Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.651">2.651[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.791">EC.791</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-350</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-350</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an overview of thermodynamics and heat transfer through an international development context to impart energy literacy and common sense applications. Students survey various alternative energy technologies and strategies for implementation in developing countries. Focuses on compact, robust, low-cost systems for generating electrical power and meeting household-level needs. Labs reinforce lecture material through deconstruction, system assembly, and sensor installation to track performance. Team projects involve activities, such as researching community needs, assessing the suitability of specific technologies, continuing the development of ongoing projects, and assessing the efficacy and impacts of existing projects. Optional summer fieldwork may be available. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Enrollment limited by lottery; must attend first class session.
<br><I>S. Hsu</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.713"></a>
<p><h3>EC.713[J] D-Lab Schools: Building Technology Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m4d.html#4.411">4.411[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-3-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the design, analysis, and application of technologies that support the construction of less expensive and better performing schools in developing countries. Prepares students to design or retrofit school buildings in partnership with local communities and NGOs. Strategies covered include daylighting, passive heating and cooling, improved indoor air quality via natural ventilation, appropriate material selection, and structural design. Investigations are based on application of engineering fundamentals, experiments and simulations. Case studies illustrate the role of technologies in reducing barriers to improved education.
<br><I>L. Norford</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.714"></a>
<p><h3>EC.714 D-Lab: Earth
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Multidisciplinary seminar explores the interacting systems of global biodiversity and human well-being to address how low-income communities can both preserve and use their natural resources sustainably.  Includes guest lectures, experiential activities, and projects. Covers topics such as reforestation, nutrient cycles, poaching, climate change, eco-tourism, governance, ecological measurement and sustainable design.  Potential opportunities for travel.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.715"></a>
<p><h3>EC.715 D-Lab: Water, Sanitation, Hygiene and Environmental Innovations for the Common Good
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m11c.html#11.474">11.474</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on disseminating Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) or water/environment innovations in developing countries and underserved communities worldwide. Structured around field-based learning, case studies, lectures and videos in which teams propose an idea and are mentored through the process of bringing that innovation to fruition. Emphasizes core WASH and water/environment principles, culture-specific solutions, tools for start-ups, appropriate and sustainable technologies, behavior change, social marketing, building partnerships, and the theory and practice of innovation diffusion. Term project entails entering the IDEAS or other competition(s) while implementing a WASH or water/environment innovation in a specific locale. Guest lectures on specific real-world WASH and water/environment projects which have been disseminated by MIT faculty, students, alumni, and others. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 30.
<br><I>S. Murcott</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.716"></a>
<p><h3>EC.716 D-Lab: Waste
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.786">EC.786</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses a multi-disciplinary approach to understand global challenges related to waste. Discusses cradle-to-cradle design, upcycling, diminishment of environmental impacts, and enterprise opportunities for marginalized populations. Studies zero-waste strategies worldwide; examines different models of collection, recycling, waste management, and businesses developed in low-income settings; and researches public policy that supports sustainable, integrated waste management systems. Teams develop solutions around waste-related challenges, in partnership with wastepickers, municipal governments, and private sector and community organizations. Includes guest speakers and field trips, as well as opportunities for IAP or summer travel. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.717"></a>
<p><h3>EC.717 D-Lab: Education and Learning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.787">EC.787</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-310</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores pedagogical concepts and skills to nurture creativity in youth. Through an overview of core teaching skills that emphasize experiential and project-based learning, provides the necessary background to develop methods of fostering design thinking, science, engineering, global learning, community activism, and more. Explores learning in the international development context to overcome challenges, such as limited resources, language barriers, large class sizes, and entrenched pedagogy. Local fieldwork and classroom visits required throughout the semester and may be available in the summer. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br><I>L. Nam</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.718"></a>
<p><h3>EC.718 D-Lab: Gender
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.798">EC.798</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores gender roles, illuminates the power dynamics and root causes of inequality, and provides a framework for understanding gender dynamics. Develops skills to conduct a gender analysis and integrate gender-sensitive strategies into large- and small-scale development solutions. Prompts critical discussion about social, economic, and political conditions that shape gender in development (particularly design and implementation of appropriate technology) as well as agricultural and job creation initiatives. In project development workshops students apply key tools to real-life situations, e.g., providing a gender analysis and making recommendations on how to incorporate gender considerations into an existing organization; developing programs in low-income communities; or building a gender component to be incorporated in a new initiative. Opportunities may be available for international fieldwork over IAP. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 12; must attend first class session.
<br><I>K. Mytty</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.719"></a>
<p><h3>EC.719 D-Lab: Water, Climate Change, and Health
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.789">EC.789</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-350</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses mitigation and adaptation to climate change as it pertains to water and health. Focuses on regions where water-borne illness, malnutrition, and vector-borne diseases - problems that will worsen with increasing temperatures and urban overcrowding - represent the top three causes of morbidity and mortality. Includes readings, workshops and films that address water, climate change and health challenges and explore solutions. Field trips include coastal watershed restoration, flood protection, carbon sequestration, and zero-carbon sites in the Boston area. Students complete a term project and/or teach a class, setting the stage for a life-long commitment to communicating climate science to a broad public. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>S. Murcott</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.720"></a>
<p><h3>EC.720[J] D-Lab: Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.722">2.722[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.670">2.670</a> or permission of the instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-350</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses problems faced by underserved communities with a focus on design, experimentation, and prototyping processes. Particular attention placed on constraints faced when designing for developing countries.  Multidisciplinary teams work on long-term projects in collaboration with community partners, field practitioners, and experts in relevant fields. Topics covered include design for affordability, manufacture,  sustainability, and strategies for working effectively with community partners and customers. Students may continue projects begun in EC.701. Enrollment limited by lottery; must attend first class session.
<br><I>S. Grama</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.721"></a>
<p><h3>EC.721 D-Lab: Mobility Technology for, by, and with People with Disabilities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students improve wheelchair technology in developing countries by applying sound engineering practices to create appropriate devices. Lectures focus on wheelchair usage, social stigmas, and manufacturing constraints. Includes lectures by third-world community partners, US wheelchair organizations, and MIT faculty. Multidisciplinary student teams conduct term-long wheelchair projects relating to hardware design. Funded opportunities available for travel to implement class projects at wheelchair workshops in the field.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.722"></a>
<p><h3>EC.722 Prosthetics for the Developing World
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the fundamentals of human walking. Provides an overview of different types of gait disabilities and the available technologies that address them. Presents patient perspective as well as current areas of research. Topics focus on lower-limb disabilities, such as polio and above- and below-knee amputation. Covers both developed and developing world techniques for overcoming these disabilities. Includes a term project in which teams of 3 to 5 students manufacture a prototype. Teams meet outside of class and work with a TA (project mentor) to research, design, prototype, and test a solution. Projects focus on low-cost orthotic and prosthetic knee designs for the developing world, as specified by partner organizations in India and Guatemala.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.724"></a>
<p><h3>EC.724 D-Lab: Smallholder Agriculture
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.784">EC.784</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-310</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an overview of the scientific, social, and economic context of smallholder farmers in developing countries. Includes scientific basis and environmental impacts of agriculture, the dynamics of smallholder farming, social and business systems, and focuses on the experience of farmers themselves. Also includes guest experts, experiential activities, and term projects with community partners. Opportunities for summer fieldwork may be available. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 15.
<br><I>G. Jones</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.729"></a>
<p><h3>EC.729[J] D-Lab: Design for Scale
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.729">2.729[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on product development of technologies for people in less industrialized markets. Students work in interdisciplinary teams to develop previously established prototypes or technologies towards manufacturing-ready product designs. Topics are presented within the context of the developing world and include technology feasibility and scalability assessment; value chain analysis; product specification; design for affordability, manufacturability, usability, and desirability; and product testing and manufacturing at various scales. Lessons are experiential and case study-based; taught by instructors with field experience and by industry experts from product development consulting firms and the consumer electronics industry.
<br><I>H. Quintus-Bosz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.731"></a>
<p><h3>EC.731[J] Development Ventures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15b.html#15.375">15.375[J]</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.665">MAS.665[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar on founding, financing, and building entrepreneurial ventures in developing nations. Challenges students to craft enduring and economically viable solutions to the problems faced by these countries.  Cases illustrate examples of both successful and failed businesses, and the difficulties in deploying and diffusing products and services through entrepreneurial action.  Explores a range of established and emerging business models, as well as new business opportunities enabled by innovations emerging from MIT labs and beyond.  Students develop a business plan executive summary suitable for submission in the MIT $100K Entrepreneurship Competition's Accelerate Contest or MIT IDEAS.
<br><I>A. Pentland</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.733"></a>
<p><h3>EC.733[J] D-Lab: Supply Chains
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15c.html#15.772">15.772[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces concepts of supply chain design and planning with a focus on supply chains for products destined to improve quality of life in developing countries. Topics include demand estimation, process analysis and improvement, facility location and capacity planning, inventory management, and supply chain coordination. Also covers issues specific to emerging markets, such as sustainable supply chains, choice of distribution channels, and how to account for the value-adding role of a supply chain. Students conduct D-Lab-based projects on supply chain design or improvement.
<br><I>S. Graves</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.740"></a>
<p><h3>EC.740 D-Lab: Inclusive  Economies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-350</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the ideas behind and actions toward alternatives to the corporate-driven globalization economic model. Begins with review and analysis of the worldviews that led to the current system and the theoretical and empirical arguments embraced by its critics. Examines concepts and case studies for developing new opportunities, including circular and local economies. Concludes with an experiential component in which students apply the concepts to develop a strategy (economic, policy, or other) for building on and contributing to a sustainable and inclusive local economy in a mid-sized city in Nicaragua. Potential opportunities for travel over summer. Limited to 12.
<br><I>E. Mcdonald</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.746"></a>
<p><h3>EC.746[J] Design for Complex Environmental Issues: Building Solutions and Communicating Ideas
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.016">1.016[J]</A>, 2.00C[J])
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-168</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students work in small groups, under the guidance of researchers from MIT, to pursue specific aspects of the  year's Terrascope problem. Teams design and build prototypes, graphic displays and other tools to communicate their findings and display them in a Bazaar of Ideas open to the MIT community.  Some teams develop particular solutions, others work to provide deeper understanding of the issues, and others focus on ways to communicate these ideas with the general public. Students' work is evaluated by independent experts. Offers students an opportunity to develop ideas from the fall semester and to work in labs across MIT. Limited to first-year students.
<br><I>A. W. Epstein, S. L. Hsu</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.750"></a>
<p><h3>EC.750 Humanitarian Innovation: Design for Relief, Rebuilding, and Recovery
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.785">EC.785</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-305</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the role innovation can and does play in how humanitarian aid is provided, and how it can impact people, products, and processes. Provides a fundamental background in the history and practice of humanitarian aid. Considers the various ways that design can be used to enhance aid, such as product and system design for affected populations, co-creation with affected populations, and capacity building to promote design by refugees and the displaced. Case studies and projects examine protracted displacement as well as recovery and resettlement, including efforts in Colombia, Lebanon, Nepal, Sudan, and Uganda. Potential for students to travel over the summer to partner communities.
<br><I>A. Smith</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.770"></a>
<p><h3>EC.770 D-Lab: Independent Project
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for independent study under regular supervision by a staff member. Projects require prior approval, as well as a written proposal and final report.  Students work with international community partners to continue developing projects, focusing on one or more issues in education, design, or public service. Final presentations and written reflection required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Hsu</I><br>IAP: <I>S. Hsu</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Hsu</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.780"></a>
<p><h3>EC.780 D-Lab: Independent Project
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for independent study under regular supervision by a staff member. Projects require prior approval, as well as a written proposal and final report. Students work with international community partners to continue developing projects, focusing on one or more issues in education, design, or public service. Final presentations and written reflection required. May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Hsu</I><br>IAP: <I>S. Hsu</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Hsu</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.781"></a>
<p><h3>EC.781[J] D-Lab: Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.472">11.472[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m11a.html#11.025">11.025[J]</A>, <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.701">EC.701[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Issues in international development, appropriate technology and project implementation addressed through lectures, case studies, guest speakers and laboratory exercises. Students form project teams to partner with community organizations in developing countries, and formulate plans for an optional IAP site visit. (Previous field sites include Ghana, Brazil, Honduras and India.) Recitation sections focus on specific project implementation, and include cultural, social, political, environmental and economic overviews of the target countries as well as an introduction to the local languages. Enrollment limited by lottery; must attend first class session.
<br><I>S. Hsu</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.784"></a>
<p><h3>EC.784 D-Lab: Smallholder Agriculture
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.724">EC.724</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-310</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an overview of the scientific, social, and economic context of smallholder farmers in developing countries. Includes scientific basis and environmental impacts of agriculture, the dynamics of smallholder farming, social and business systems, and focuses on the experience of farmers themselves. Also includes guest experts, experiential activities, and term projects with community partners. Opportunities for summer fieldwork may be available. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 15.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.785"></a>
<p><h3>EC.785 Humanitarian Innovation: Design for Relief, Rebuilding, and Recovery
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.750">EC.750</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-305</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the role innovation can and does play in how humanitarian aid is provided, and how it can impact people, products, and processes. Provides a fundamental background in the history and practice of humanitarian aid. Considers the various ways that design can be used to enhance aid, such as product and system design for affected populations, co-creation with affected populations, and capacity building to promote design by refugees and the displaced. Case studies and projects examine protracted displacement as well as recovery and resettlement, including efforts in Colombia, Lebanon, Nepal, Sudan, and Uganda. Potential for students to travel over the summer to partner communities.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.786"></a>
<p><h3>EC.786 D-Lab: Waste
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.716">EC.716</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses a multi-disciplinary approach to understand global challenges related to waste. Provides a platform for initiatives such as cradle-to-cradle design, upcycling, diminishment of environmental impacts, and enterprise opportunities for marginalized populations. Studies zero-waste strategies worldwide; examines different models of collection, recycling, waste management, and businesses developed in low-income settings; and researches public policy that supports sustainable, integrated waste management systems. Teams engage in development of solutions around waste-related challenges, in partnership with wastepickers, municipal governments, and private sector and community organizations. Includes guest speakers and field trips, as well as opportunities for IAP or summer travel. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.787"></a>
<p><h3>EC.787 D-Lab: Education and Learning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.717">EC.717</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-3-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-310</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores pedagogical concepts and skills to nurture creativity in youth. Through an overview of core teaching skills that emphasize experiential and project-based learning, class provides the necessary background to develop methods of fostering design thinking, science, engineering, global learning, community activism, and more. Explore learning in the international development context to overcome challenges such as limited resources, language barriers, large class sizes, and entrenched pedagogy. Local fieldwork and classroom visits required throughout the semester and may be available in the summer. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.788"></a>
<p><h3>EC.788 D-Lab: Field Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Combines hands-on methods for conducting field research with exploration of questions that continue to challenge practitioners, donors, policymakers and researchers in international development. Designed for students preparing to conduct field-based research for theses, product design project, or development ventures. Practices key research skills particularly applicable to conducting research involving people and communities in the context of development. Limited to 16.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.789"></a>
<p><h3>EC.789 D-Lab: Water, Climate Change, and Health
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.719">EC.719</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-350</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses mitigation and adaptation to climate change as it pertains to water and health. Focuses on regions where water-borne illness, malnutrition, and vector-borne diseases - problems that will worsen with increasing temperatures and urban overcrowding - represent the top three causes of morbidity and mortality. Includes readings, workshops and films that address water, climate change and health challenges and explore solutions. Field trips include coastal watershed restoration, flood protection, carbon sequestration, and zero-carbon sites in the Boston area. Students complete a term project and/or teach a class, setting the stage for a life-long commitment to communicating climate science to a broad public. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.790"></a>
<p><h3>EC.790 D-Lab: Field Study
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: One D-Lab subject, permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides the opportunity to gain direct fieldwork experience in a global context. Subject spans three-four weeks in which students continue work from a prior D-Lab subject. Students work directly with international community partners to find solutions to real world problems, focusing on one or more issues in education, design, or public service. Group presentations and written reflection required.
<br><I>S. Hsu</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.791"></a>
<p><h3>EC.791 D-Lab: Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.651">2.651[J]</A>, <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.711">EC.711[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-350</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-350</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an overview of thermodynamics and heat transfer through an international development context to impart energy literacy and common sense applications. Students survey various alternative energy technologies and strategies for implementation in developing countries. Focuses on compact, robust, low-cost systems for generating electrical power and meeting household-level needs. Labs reinforce lecture material through deconstruction, system assembly, and sensor installation to track performance. Team projects involve activities, such as researching community needs, assessing the suitability of specific technologies, continuing the development of ongoing projects, and assessing the efficacy and impacts of existing projects. Optional summer fieldwork may be available. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Enrollment limited by lottery; must attend first class session.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.792"></a>
<p><h3>EC.792[J] Cross-Cultural Investigations: Technology and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.839">21A.839[J]</A>, <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.481">STS.481[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.702">EC.702[J]</A>, <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.801">21A.801[J]</A>, <A HREF="mSTSa.html#STS.071">STS.071[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Enhances cross-cultural understanding through discussion of practical, ethical, and epistemological issues in conducting social science and applied research in foreign countries or unfamiliar communities. Includes research practicum to help students develop interviewing, participant-observation, and other qualitative research skills, as well as critical discussion of case studies. Open to all interested students, but intended particularly for those planning to undertake exploratory research or applied work abroad. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EC.798"></a>
<p><h3>EC.798 D-Lab: Gender
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.718">EC.718</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores gender roles, illuminates the power dynamics and root causes of inequality, and provides a framework for understanding gender dynamics. Develops skills to conduct a gender analysis and integrate gender-sensitive strategies into large- and small-scale development solutions. Prompts critical discussion about social, economic, and political conditions that shape gender in development (particularly design and implementation of appropriate technology) as well as agricultural and job creation initiatives. In project development workshops students apply key tools to real-life situations, e.g., providing a gender analysis and making recommendations on how to incorporate gender considerations into an existing organization; developing programs in low-income communities; or building a gender component to be incorporated in a new initiative. Opportunities may be available for international fieldwork over IAP. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 12; must attend first class session.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->

<h2>Special Subjects</h2>
<a name="EC.S00"></a>
<p><h3>EC.S00 Special Subject at the Edgerton Center
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar combining lectures and lab run by students and academic staff at the Edgerton Center. Students explore specialized electronics, robotics, or mechanical design and fabrication topics not offered in the regular curriculum; classes range from beginner level to more advanced. Some offerings may be taught in an intensive fashion (meeting for up to several times a week for four weeks). Up to three sequential seminars may be offered per semester, covering a different topic each time. Students can take one or all of the seminars.
<br>Staff<br>
<a name="EC.S01"></a>
<p><h3>EC.S01 Special Subject at the Edgerton Center
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar combining lectures and lab run by students and academic staff at the Edgerton Center. Students explore specialized electronics, robotics, or mechanical design and fabrication topics not offered in the regular curriculum; classes range from beginner level to more advanced. Some offerings may be taught in an intensive fashion (meeting for up to several times a week for four weeks). Up to three sequential seminars may be offered per semester, covering a different topic each time. Students can take one or all of the seminars.
<br>Staff<br>
<a name="EC.S02"></a>
<p><h3>EC.S02 Special Subject at the Edgerton Center
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar combining lectures and lab run by students and academic staff at the Edgerton Center. Students explore specialized electronics, robotics, or mechanical design and fabrication topics not offered in the regular curriculum; classes range from beginner level to more advanced. Some offerings may be taught in an intensive fashion (meeting for up to several times a week for four weeks). Up to three sequential seminars may be offered per semester, covering a different topic each time. Students can take one or all of the seminars.
<br>Staff<br>
<a name="EC.S03"></a>
<p><h3>EC.S03 Special Subject at the Edgerton Center

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Engineering Management<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=EM&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++EM&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>EM.00-EM.THG</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>System Design and Management</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://sdm.mit.edu"><i>SDM Home</i></a></b>
<a name="EM.411"></a>
<p><h3>EM.411 Foundations of System Design and Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-2-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the foundations of systems architecture, systems engineering and project management in an integrated format, through a synchronized combination of in-class discussion, industrial guest speakers, team projects, and individual assignments. Topics include stakeholder analysis, project planning and monitoring, requirements definition, concept generation and selection, complexity management, system integration, verification and validation, cost modeling, systems safety, organizational design and effective teamwork, risk management, and leadership styles. Restricted to students in the SDM program.
<br><I>B. Moser</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EM.412"></a>
<p><h3>EM.412 Foundations of System Design and Management II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mEMa.html#EM.411">EM.411</a>
<br>Units: 2-1-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Deepens the foundations of systems architecture, systems engineering and project management introduced in ESD.411 though a synchronized combination of lectures, recitations, opportunity sets, guest speakers, and team projects. Topics emphasize the transition from early conceptual design to detailed design and system integration. Features a technology showcase and project forum where students, faculty and company sponsors meet to discuss and select projects for ESD.413. Includes team-based exercises and design challenges. Restricted to students in the SDM program.
<br><I>B. Moser</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EM.413"></a>
<p><h3>EM.413 Foundations of System Design and Management III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mEMa.html#EM.412">EM.412</a>
<br>Units: 4-2-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-390</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-390</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-390</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents advanced concepts in systems architecture, systems engineering and project management in an integrated manner through lectures, recitations, opportunity sets, guest lectures, and a semester-long team project. Topics emphasize complexity management, systems integration, verification, validation, and lifecycle management. Specific lifecycle properties addressed include quality, safety, robustness, resilience, flexibility and evolvability of systems over time. Additional topics include monitoring and control, the rework cycle, managing portfolios and programs of projects in a multi-cultural and global context, and managing product families and platforms. Restricted to students in the SDM program.
<br><I>B. Moser</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Integrated Design and Management</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://idm.mit.edu"><i>IDM Home</i></a></b>
<a name="EM.441"></a>
<p><h3>EM.441 Integrated Design Lab I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-6-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents fundamentals of the integrated design and product development process. Covers methods relevant at each stage of the process; students apply them in a series of design projects. Topics include stakeholder identification, customer engagement and ethnographic methods, concept generation and selection, project planning, manufacturing methods, supply systems, cost modeling, sustainability, and safety. Restricted to Integrated Design and Management (IDM) students.
<br><I>M. Kressy</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EM.442"></a>
<p><h3>EM.442 Integrated Design Lab II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mEMa.html#EM.441">EM.441</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-6-7
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>MW11-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N52">N52-342C</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents advanced topics in integrated design and product development. Students pursue a product development project as a case study for understanding how teams work together to define and test a new product. Provides exposure to the state-of-the-art in product definition, product architectures, market testing, competitive analysis, product planning strategy, business case construction, and life cycle design. Students apply their previously acquired product development knowledge and engage in ongoing reflection in an action-oriented setting. Restricted to Integrated Design and Management (IDM) students.
<br><I>M. Kressy</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Internship and Thesis</h2>
<a name="EM.451"></a>
<p><h3>EM.451 Internship Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides insight into the challenges of an organization that develops products or systems. Before enrolling each student must have a department approved internship opportunity. At the end of the internship, students deliver a report, for evaluation by the sponsoring faculty member, documenting ways that the organization addresses product or system development issues and applies the methods taught in the SDM or IDM core. Intended for students who have completed the SDM or IDM core course sequence.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Rubin</I><br>IAP: <I>J. Rubin</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Rubin</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EM.S20"></a>
<p><h3>EM.S20 Special Subject in Engineering Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for study of advanced topics in Engineering Management not otherwise included in the curriculum at MIT. Offerings are initiated by faculty on an ad-hoc basis subject to department approval.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="EM.S21"></a>
<p><h3>EM.S21 Special Subject in Engineering Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)

</p><!--end-->

<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="ES.181A"></a>
<p><h3>ES.181A Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
