<h2>ESG Writing Program</h2>
<a name="ES.333"></a>
<p><h3>ES.333[J] Production of Educational Videos:  Skills for Communicating Academic and Professional Content
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.333">CMS.333[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-618</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops communication and media skills through the production of educational videos. Students conceive, plan, script, shoot and edit video content to teach elements of MIT's curriculum. Each student creates a series of short videos that concisely explains and contextualizes specific problems of importance to disciplines at MIT, especially physics, math, chemistry, biology, or the humanities. The resulting videos present these problems through compelling use of illustrations, demonstrations, animations, and commentary, all from the student's perspective. Empowers students specifically to communicate their MIT expertise to communities of learners and generally to reach broad audiences with quality, accessible online content. Limited to 12; preference to students in ESG.
<br><I>D. Custer</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ES.729"></a>
<p><h3>ES.729[J] Engineering Communication in Context
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassT.gif" alt="HASS Elective" title="HASS Elective" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as 21W.729[J])
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces writing, graphics, meetings, reading, oral presentation, collaboration, and design as tools for product development. Students work in teams to conceive, design, prototype, and evaluate energy-related mechanical engineering products. Instruction focuses on communication tasks that are integral to the design process, including design notebooks, email, informal and formal presentations, meeting etiquette, literature searches, white papers, proposals, and reports. Other assignments address the cultural situation of engineers and engineering in the world at large. Limited to 18; preference to ESG students.
<br><I>D. Custer</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>ESG HASS Subjects</h2>
<a name="ES.112"></a>
<p><h3>ES.112 Philosophy of Love
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-621</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the nature of love through works of philosophy, literature, film, poetry, and individual experience. Investigates the distinction among eros, philia, and agape. Students discuss ideas of love as a feeling, an action, a species of 'knowing someone,' or a way to give or take. Authors include Plato, Kant, Buber, D. H. Lawrence, Rumi, and Aristotle. Preference to students in  ESG and Concourse.
<br><I>L. Perlman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ES.113"></a>
<p><h3>ES.113 Ancient Greek Philosophy and Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the relationship between ancient Greek philosophy and mathematics. Investigates how ideas of definition, reason, argument and proof, rationality/irrationality, number, quality and quantity, truth, and even the idea of an idea were shaped by the interplay of philosophic and mathematical inquiry. Examines how discovery of the incommensurability of magnitudes challenged the Greek presumption that the cosmos is fully understandable. Explores the influence of mathematics on ancient Greek ethical theories. Authors: Euclid, Plato, Aristotle, Nicomachus, Theon of Smyrna, Bacon, Descartes, Dedekind, and Newton. Preference to students in Concourse and ESG.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>ESG Seminars</h2>
<a name="ES.010"></a>
<p><h3>ES.010 Chemistry of Sports: Understanding How Exercise Affects Your Body
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-1-3 [P/D/F]
<br><a href="http://esg.mit.edu/learninginnovation/undergraduate-seminars/">http://esg.mit.edu/learninginnovation/undergraduate-seminars/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-619</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students apply chemistry knowledge to physical fitness through the study of three sports: swimming, cycling, and running. Classroom component focuses on nutrition, exercise, anatomy, physiology, and the chemistry of supplements and sports equipment. Laboratory component focuses on training for and completion of triathlon competition. Students may earn up to 2 PE points during the term by attending supervised triathlon training workouts. Preference to students in ESG.
<br><I>P. Christie</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="ES.011"></a>
<p><h3>ES.011 Kitchen Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-1-3 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An experimental and "hands-on" approach to applied chemistry in cooking. Students perform experiments to illustrate chemical principles, such as extraction, denaturation, and phase changes. Preference to students in ESG.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>ESG Teaching and Research</h2>
<a name="ES.200"></a>
<p><h3>ES.200 ESG Undergraduate Teaching
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=24">24-618</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An opportunity to assist in the teaching of subjects in ESG in biology, chemistry, humanities and social sciences, mathematics, and physics. Student instructors may be involved in grading, running problemsolving sessions, or teaching classes depending on experience and interest. Qualified students may also develop and teach undergraduate seminars under the supervision of an appropriate faculty or staff member. Student instructors meet weekly with staff to discuss their teaching and cover a variety of topics related to effective teaching techniques. Limited to students in ESG.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Christie</I><br>Spring: <I>G. Stoy</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<a name="ES.S30"></a>
<p><h3>ES.S30 Special Seminar in Engineering and Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]

<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Health Sciences and Technology<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://hst.mit.edu"><i>HST Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=HST&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+HST&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>HST.00-HST.599</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="mHSTb.html">HST.600-HST.999 plus UROP and Thesis</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>IMPORTANT NOTES regarding preclinical subjects (<a href="mHSTa.html#HST.011">HST.011</a>-<a href="mHSTa.html#HST.176">HST.176</a> and <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.191">HST.191</a>):<br><br><br>Students not enrolled in an HST graduate degree program are limited to two HST preclinical courses and must provide justification for enrolling in these courses.   This action must be approved by the course director and the students advisor.<br><br><br>These subjects are scheduled according to the Harvard Medical School academic calendar, which differs from the MIT calendar.  Students whose graduation depends upon completing one or more of these subjects should take particular care regarding the schedule.
<a name="HST.010"></a><a name="HST.011"></a>
<h3>HST.011 Human Functional Anatomy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.010">HST.010</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-11-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures, detailed laboratory dissections, and prosections provide a thorough exploration of the gross structure and function of the human body. Fundamental principles of bioengineering are employed to promote analytical approaches to understanding the body's design. The embryology of major organ systems is presented, together with certain references to phylogenetic development, as a basis for comprehending anatomical complexity. Correlation clinics stress both normal and abnormal functions of the body and present evolving knowledge of genes responsible for normal and abnormal anatomy. Lecturers focus on current problems in organ system research. Only HST students may register under HST.010, graded P/D/F. Lab fee. Enrollment restricted to graduate students.
<br><I>L. Gehrke</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.015"></a>
<p><h3>HST.015 MATLAB for Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical introduction to use of quantitative methods in medicine and health research. Each session covers a different topic in quantitative techniques, provides an application to medicine, and includes a modeling activity using MATLAB. Students also complete problem sets. Restricted to first year HST MD students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.020"></a><a name="HST.021"></a>
<h3>HST.021 Musculoskeletal Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.020">HST.020</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of Instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Growth and development of normal bone and joints, the biophysics of bone and response to stress and fracture, calcium and phosphate homeostasis and regulation by parathyroid hormone and vitamin D, and the pathogenesis of metabolic bone diseases and disease of connective tissue, joints, and muscles, with consideration of possible mechanisms and underlying metabolic derangements. Only HST students may register under HST.020, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited; restricted to medical and graduate students.
<br><I>M. Bouxsein, B. Shore, D. Solomon</I><br><b>HST.020:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>HST.021:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.030"></a><a name="HST.031"></a>
<h3>HST.031 Human Pathology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.030">HST.030</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-3-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.034">HST.034</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.035">HST.035</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the functional structure of normal cells and tissues, pathologic principles of cellular adaptation and injury, inflammation, circulatory disorders, immunologic injury, infection, genetic disorders, and neoplasia in humans. Lectures, conferences emphasizing clinical correlations and contemporary experimental biology. Laboratories with examination of microscopic and gross specimens, and autopsy case studies emphasizing modern pathology practice. Only HST students may register under HST.030, graded P/D/F. Lab fee. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. N. Mitchell, R. Padera</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.034"></a><a name="HST.035"></a>
<h3>HST.035 Pathology of Human Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.034">HST.034</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-2-10
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.030">HST.030</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.031">HST.031</A>
<br><b>HST.034:</b> Begins 1/30. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-11</i> (MEC-250) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=MHS SKILLS">MHS SKILLS</a>) or <i>R11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=MHS SKILLS">MHS SKILLS</a>)<!--s--><br><b>HST.035:</b> Begins 1/30. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-11</i> (MEC-250) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=MHS SKILLS">MHS SKILLS</a>) or <i>R11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=MHS SKILLS">MHS SKILLS</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a comprehensive overview of human pathology with emphasis on mechanisms of disease and modern diagnostic technologies. Topics include general mechanisms of disease (inflammation, infection, immune injury, transplantation, genetic disorders and neoplasia); pathology of lipids, enzymes, and molecular transporters; pathology of major organ systems; and review of diagnostic tools from surgical pathology to non-invasive techniques such as spectroscopy, imaging, and molecular markers of disease. The objectives of this subject are achieved by a set of integrated lectures and laboratories, as well as a student-driven term project leading to a formal presentation on a medical, socioeconomic, or technological issue in human pathology. Only HST students enrolled in specific degree programs may register under HST.034, graded P/D/F. Credit cannot also be received for HST.030 or HST.031.
<br><I>S. Lovitch</I><br><b>HST.034:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>HST.035:</b> No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.040"></a><a name="HST.041"></a>
<h3>HST.041 Mechanisms of Microbial Pathogenesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.040">HST.040</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-2-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Deals with the mechanisms of pathogenesis of bacteria, viruses, and other microorganisms. Approach spans mechanisms from molecular to clinical aspects of disease. Topics selected for intrinsic interest and cover the demonstrated spectrum of pathophysiologic mechanisms. Only HST students may register under HST.040, graded P/D/F. Lab fee. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>C. Crumpacker II, H. Simon</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.060"></a><a name="HST.061"></a>
<h3>HST.061 Endocrinology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.060">HST.060</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>HST.060:</b> Begins Feb 8. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1.30-4.30</i> (MEC-209)<!--s--><br><b>HST.061:</b> Begins Feb 8. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>R1.30-4.30</i> (MEC-209)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Physiology and pathophysiology of the human endocrine system. Three hours of lecture and section each week concern individual parts of the endocrine system. Topics include assay techniques, physiological integration, etc. At frequent clinic sessions, patients are presented who demonstrate clinical problems considered in the didactic lectures. Only HST students may register under HST.060, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>D. Breault, W. Kettyle, V. Navarro</I><br><b>HST.060:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>HST.061:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.070"></a><a name="HST.071"></a>
<h3>HST.071 Human Reproductive Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.070">HST.070</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures and clinical case discussions designed to provide the student with a clear understanding of the physiology, endocrinology, and pathology of human reproduction. Emphasis is on the role of technology in reproductive science. Suggestions for future research contributions in the field are probed. Students become involved in the wider aspects of reproduction, such as prenatal diagnosis, in vitro fertilization, abortion, menopause, contraception and ethics relation to reproductive science. Only HST students may register under HST.070, graded P/D/F.
<br><I>A. Koniaris, D. Page, O. Pourquie</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.080"></a><a name="HST.081"></a>
<h3>HST.081 Hematology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.080">HST.080</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-1-3
<br><b>HST.080:</b> Begins Feb 7. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF8-10</i> (MEC-209)<!--s--><br><b>HST.081:</b> Begins Feb 7. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF8-10</i> (MEC-209)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive survey of the biology, physiology and pathophysiology of blood with systematic consideration of hematopoiesis, white blood cells, red blood cells, platelets, coagulation, plasma proteins, and hematologic malignancies. Emphasis given equally to didactic discussion and analysis of clinical problems. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>N. Berliner</I><br><b>HST.080:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>HST.081:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.090"></a><a name="HST.091"></a>
<h3>HST.091 Cardiovascular Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.090">HST.090</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.030">HST.030</a> or <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.031">HST.031</a>; permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-3-8
<br><b>HST.090:</b> Begins 2/5. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M8.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s--><br><b>HST.091:</b> Begins 2/5. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M8.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Normal and pathologic physiology of the heart and vascular system. Emphasis includes hemodynamics, electrophysiology, gross pathology, and clinical correlates of cardiovascular function in normal and in a variety of disease states. Special attention given to congenital, rheumatic, valvular heart disease and cardiomyopathy. Only HST students may register under HST.090, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>E. Edelman</I><br><b>HST.090:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>HST.091:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.100"></a><a name="HST.101"></a>
<h3>HST.101 Respiratory Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.100">HST.100</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>HST.100:</b> Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12.30 (ENDS MAR 30)</i> (MEC-209) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9-11 (BEGINS APR 2)</i> (MEC-209)<!--s--><br><b>HST.101:</b> Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12.30 (ENDS MAR 30)</i> (MEC-209) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9-11 (BEGINS APR 2)</i> (MEC-209)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures, seminars, and laboratories cover the histology, cell biology, and physiological function of the lung with multiple examples related to common diseases of the lung.  A quantitative approach to the physics of gases, respiratory mechanics, and gas exchange is provided to explain pathological mechanisms. Use of medical ventilators is discussed in lecture and in laboratory experiences. For MD candidates and other students with background in science. Only HST students may register under HST.100, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Drazen, S. Loring, C. Hardin</I><br><b>HST.100:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=HST.100');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font><br><b>HST.101:</b> <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=HST.101');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.110"></a><a name="HST.111"></a>
<h3>HST.111 Renal Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.110">HST.110</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>HST.110:</b> Begins Feb 6. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8-10.30 (ENDS MAR 30)</i> (MEC-209) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11-12.30 (BEGINS APR 2)</i> (MEC-209)<!--s--><br><b>HST.111:</b> Begins Feb 6. Final exam at harvard. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8-10.30 (ENDS MAR 30)</i> (MEC-209) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR11-12.30 (BEGINS APR 2)</i> (MEC-209)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers the normal physiology of the kidney and the pathophysiology of renal disease. Renal regulation of sodium, potassium, acid, and water balance are emphasized as are the mechanism and consequences of renal failure. Included also are the pathology and pathophysiology of clinical renal disorders such as acute and chronic glomerulonephritis, pyelonephritis, and vascular disease. New molecular insights into transporter mutations and renal disease are discussed. Only HST students may register under HST.110, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Seifter, A. Lam</I><br><b>HST.110:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>HST.111:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.120"></a><a name="HST.121"></a>
<h3>HST.121 Gastroenterology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.120">HST.120</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents the anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, biophysics, and bioengineering of the gastrointestinal tract and associated pancreatic, liver, and biliary systems. Emphasis on the molecular and pathophysiological basis of disease where known. Covers gross and microscopic pathology and clinical aspects. Formal lectures given by core faculty, with some guest lectures by local experts. Selected seminars conducted by students with supervision of faculty. Only HST students may register under HST.120, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Rutherford, S. Flier</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.130"></a><a name="HST.131"></a>
<h3>HST.131 Neuroscience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.130">HST.130</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive study of neuroscience where students explore the brain on levels ranging from molecules and cells through neural systems, perception, memory, and behavior. Includes some aspects of clinical neuroscience, within neuropharmacology, pathophysiology, and neurology. Lectures supplemented by conferences and labs. Labs review neuroanatomy at the gross and microscopic levels. Only HST students may register under HST.130, graded P/D/F. Limited to 50.
<br><I>J. Assad, M. Frosch</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.140"></a><a name="HST.141"></a>
<h3>HST.141 Molecular Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.140">HST.140</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Conducted as a seminar to study a variety of human diseases and the underlying molecular, genetic, and biochemical basis for the pathogenesis and pathophysiology of the disorders. Lectures by faculty and seminars conducted by students, with tutorials and supervision by faculty. Patients presented when feasible. Appropriate for students who have had a course in biochemistry and/or molecular biology.
<br><I>I. M. London, V. Sankaran, S. Agarwal</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.146"></a><a name="HST.147"></a>
<h3>HST.147 Human Biochemistry and Metabolic Diseases
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First-year graduate level intensive subject in human biochemistry and physiological chemistry that focuses on intermediary metabolism, structures of key intermediates and enzymes important in human disease. Subject is divided into four areas: carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids and nucleic acids. The importance of these areas is underscored with examples from diseases and clinical correlations.  Preparatory sessions meet in August. Only HST students may register under HST.146, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>S. Biddinger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.150"></a><a name="HST.151"></a>
<h3>HST.151 Principles of Pharmacology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.150">HST.150</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 6-0-6
<br><b>HST.150:</b> Meets during iap. 1/8 to 1/26. Final exam at harvard. Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9-12</i> (MEC-250)<!--s--><br><b>HST.151:</b> Meets during iap. 1/8 to 1/26. Final exam at harvard. Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9-12</i> (MEC-250)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An introduction to pharmacology. Topics include mechanisms of drug action, dose-response relations, pharmacokinetics, drug delivery systems, drug metabolism, toxicity of pharmacological agents, drug interactions, and substance abuse. Selected agents and classes of agents examined in detail. Course follows HMS calendar. Restricted to HST MD & HST PhD students.
<br>IAP: <I>C. Rosow, S. Forman</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Rosow, S. Forman</I><br><b>HST.150:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>HST.151:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.160"></a><a name="HST.161"></a>
<h3>HST.161 Genetics in Modern Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.160">HST.160</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a foundation for understanding the relationship between molecular biology, genetics, and medicine.  Starts with an introduction to molecular genetics, and quickly transitions to the genetic basis of diseases, including chromosomal, mitochondrial and epigenetic disease. Translation of clinical understanding into analysis at the level of the gene, chromosome, and molecule; the concepts and techniques of molecular biology and genomics; and the strategies and methods of genetic analysis. Includes diagnostics (prenatal and adult), cancer genetics, and the development of genetic therapies (RNA, viral, and genome editing).  The clinical relevance of these areas is underscored with patient presentations. Only HST students may register under HST.160, graded P/D/F.
<br><I>W. Goessling, S. Garg, S. Nassim</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.162"></a><a name="HST.163"></a>
<h3>HST.163 Molecular Diagnostics and Bioinformatics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.162">HST.162</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.160">HST.160</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction of molecular diagnostic methods in medicine and relevant bioinformatics methods. Discussion of principles of molecular testing for diagnosis of somatic and germline diseases using FISH, classical genotyping, array CGH, next generation sequencing, and other technologies. Case conferences emphasize clinical correlation and integration of information from multiple diagnostic tests. Bioinformatics lectures, problem sets, and laboratory sessions will introduce key concepts in biological sequence analysis and provide experience with bioinformatics tools. HST.015 and HST.191 recommended. Only HST students may register under HST.162, P/D/F. Enrollment limited, preference to HST students.
<br><I>G. Gerber, L. Le</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.164"></a><a name="HST.165"></a>
<h3>HST.165 Principles of Biomedical Imaging
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.164">HST.164</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reviews fundamental principles and techniques underlying modern biomedical imaging, as well as their application in modern medicine. Particular emphasis on magnetic resonance; also covers ultrasound, computed tomography, positron emission tomography and optical techniques. Didactic lectures accompanied by problem sets and experiments with portable magnetic resonance systems and ultrasound systems. Focuses on the quantitative aspects of biomedical imaging and requires a knowledge of differential equations, MATLAB, and intermediate-level physics. Only HST students may register under HST.164, P/D/F. Restricted to HST students.
<br><I>S. Huang, D. Sosnovik</I><br><b>HST.164:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>HST.165:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.175"></a><a name="HST.176"></a>
<h3>HST.176 Cellular and Molecular Immunology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.175">HST.175</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>
<br>Units: 6-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers cells and tissues of the immune system, lymphocyte development, the structure and function of antigen receptors, the cell biology of antigen processing and presentation including molecular structure and assembly of MHC molecules, lymphocyte activation, the biology of cytokines, leukocyte-endothelial interactions, and the pathogenesis of immunologically mediated diseases. Consists of lectures and tutorials in which clinical cases are discussed with faculty tutors. Details of each case covering a number of immunological issues in the context of disease are posted on a student website. Only HST students may register under HST.175, graded P/D/F. Limited to 45.
<br><I>S. Pillai, B. Cherayil</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.190"></a><a name="HST.191"></a>
<h3>HST.191 Introduction to Biostatistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.190">HST.190</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides training on how to comprehend, critique and communicate findings from biomedical literature. Considers how to assess the importance of chance in the interpretation of experimental data. Topics include probability theory, chi-squared and t-tests, ANOVA, linear and logistic regression, survival analysis, and statistical analysis using MATLAB. Includes critical reading of studies published in medical literature. Only HST students may register under HST.190, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited; restricted to medical and graduate students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.192"></a>
<p><h3>HST.192 Medical Decision Analysis and Probabilistic Medical Inference
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Teaches the essentials of quantitative diagnostic reasoning and medical decision analysis. Guides participants through the process of choosing an appropriate contemporary medical problem in which risk-benefit tradeoffs play a prominent role, conducting a decision analysis, and ultimately publishing the results in a medical journal.  Topics include decision trees, influence diagrams, Markov decision models and Monte Carlo simulation, methods for quantifying patient values, Bayesian inference, decision thresholds, and the cognitive science of medical decision making. HST.191 recommended. Limited to 8; preference to HST students.
<br><I>M. B. Westover, M. Bianchi</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.194"></a><a name="HST.195"></a>
<h3>HST.195 Clinical Epidemiology
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.194">HST.194</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.190">HST.190</a>
<br>Units: 1-0-1
<br><b>HST.194:</b> Six meetings in total. Begins 1/29. Meets 2/12 to 3/19. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>M1-4</i> (MEC-209)<!--s--><br><b>HST.195:</b> Six meetings in total. Begins 1/29. Meets 2/12 to 3/19. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>M1-4</i> (MEC-209)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces methods for the generation, analysis, and interpretation of data for clinical research. Major topics include the design of surveys, predictive models, randomized trials, clinical cohorts, and analyses of electronic health records. Prepares students to formulate well-defined research questions, design data collection, evaluate algorithms for clinical prediction, design studies for causal inference, and identify and prevent biases in clinical research. Emphasizes critical thinking and practical applications, including daily assignments based on articles published in major clinical journals and the discussion of a case study each week. Trains students to comprehend, critique, and communicate findings from the biomedical literature. Familiarity with regression modeling and basic statistical theory is a prerequisite. Only HST students may register under HST.194, graded P/D/F. Enrollment limited; restricted to medical and graduate students.
<br><I>M. Hernan</I><br><b>HST.194:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>HST.195:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.196"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="HST.200"></a>
<p><h3>HST.200 Introduction to Clinical Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 9-19-12 [P/D/F]
<br>Class begins 1/02. Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TRF8-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=BW ">BW - HOSPITAL</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive preparation for clinical clerkships that introduces the basic skills involved in examination of the patient in addition to history taking and the patient interview. Provides exposure to clinical problems in medicine, surgery, and pediatrics. Students report their findings through history taking and oral presentations. Restricted to MD program students.
<br>IAP: <I>W. Goessling</I><br>Spring: <I>W. Goessling</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.201"></a>
<p><h3>HST.201 Introduction to Clinical Medicine and Medical Engineering I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-20-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develop skills in patient interviewing and physical examination; become proficient at organizing and communicating clinical information in both written and oral forms; begin integrating history, physical, and laboratory data with pathophysiologic principles; and become familiar with the clinical decision-making process and broad economic, ethical, and sociological issues involved in patient care. There are two sections: one at Mount Auburn Hospital and one at West Roxbury VA Hospital, subsequent registration into HST.202 must be continued at the same hospital as HST.201. Restricted to MEMP students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.202"></a>
<p><h3>HST.202 Introduction to Clinical Medicine and Medical Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.201">HST.201</a>
<br>Units: 0-20-0 [P/D/F]
<br>MT auburn or. W roxbury va hospital. Schedule tbd. TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Strengthens the skills developed in HST.201 through a six-week clerkship in medicine at a Harvard-affiliated teaching hospital. Students serve as full-time members of a ward team and participate in longitudinal patient care. In addition, students participate in regularly scheduled teaching conferences focused on principles of patient management. Restricted to MEMP students.
<br>Fall: <I>R. G. Mark, J. Strymish, N. Price</I><br>IAP: <I>R. G. Mark, J. Strymish, N. Price</I><br>Spring: <I>R. G. Mark, J. Strymish, N. Price</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.211"></a>
<p><h3>HST.211 Biomedical Inventions: Clinical Introduction
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with an understanding of modern biomedicine. Explores the clinical areas where medical practice and biomedical enterprise intersect. Hear and interact with academic physicians engaged in care and treatment of patients, in the wards, ICUs, ORs and outpatient areas, and develop the knowledge base needed to obtain elective clinical experiences. Learn to interact with patients and clinicians. Focus is on the various needs of medical specialties, both device, IT and pharma to better treat common medical diseases.
<br><I>HST Faculty</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.212"></a>
<p><h3>HST.212 Biomedical Inventions: Clinical Experience and Selected Success Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.211">HST.211</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with a survey of key biomedical research needs by lecture-discussions and facilitating interaction with academic-clinicians and scientists active in medical care/research. Both drug and technology development in the various medical and surgical specialties are examined. Students develop the knowledge base needed to obtain elective clinical experiences. Unsolved clinical problems are sought by each student in a biomedical area of their interest and presented to the class. Interactions with academic physicians who have successfully developed technologies and drugs that are approved by the FDA and in widespread clinical use. How, where, when and why biomedical enterprise and medical practice can successfully intersect is explored. Students can interact with academic physicians engaged in the development of novel technology and drugs, analyze successes and autopsy failed biomedical enterprises.
<br><I>HST Faculty</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.220"></a>
<p><h3>HST.220 Introduction to the Care of Patients
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br>Begins in iap. TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elective subject for HST/MD candidates only. Provides an introduction to the care of patients through opportunities to observe and participate in doctor-patient interaction in an outpatient, office-based environment, and through patient-oriented seminars. Students are exposed to some of the practical realities of providing patient care. Topics include basic interviewing, issues of ethics and confidentiality, and other aspects of the doctor-patient relationship. Requirements include regular attendance, and a short paper on patient care. Limited to 15.
<br>IAP: <I>H. Heller, MIT Medical Department Staff</I><br>Spring: <I>H. Heller, MIT Medical Department Staff</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.240"></a>
<p><h3>HST.240 Translational Medicine Preceptorship
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mHSTa.html#HST.035">HST.035</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-0
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Individually designed preceptorship joins together scientific research and clinical medicine. Students devote approximately half of their time to clinical experiences, and the remaining part to scholarly work in basic or clinical science. The two might run concomitantly or in series. Follow a clinical preceptor's daily activity, including aspects of patient care, attending rounds, conferences, and seminars. Research involves formal investigation of a focused and directed issue related to selected clinical area. Final paper required. Limited to students in the GEMS Program.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Edelman</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Edelman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="HST.299"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
