<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Aerospace Studies<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://afrotc.mit.edu"><i>AS Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=AS&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++AS&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>AS.00-AS.999</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>ROTC subjects do not carry academic credit at MIT, but they can be counted toward the PE Requirement.  Up to two points per year with a maximum of four points.
<h2>Aerospace Studies</h2>
<a name="AS.101"></a>
<p><h3>AS.101 The Foundations of the United States Air Force
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.111">AS.111</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey designed to introduce students to the United States Air Force and Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps. Featured topics include: mission and organization of the Air Force, officership and professionalism, military customs and courtesies, Air Force officer opportunities, group leadership problems, and an introduction to communication skills.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.102"></a>
<h3>AS.102 The Foundations of the United States Air Force
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.101">AS.101</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.112">AS.112</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-1
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey designed to introduce students to the United States Air Force and Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps. Topics include mission and organization of the Air Force, officership and professionalism, military customs and courtesies, Air Force officer opportunities, group leadership problems, and an introduction to communication skills. AS.102 is a continuation of AS.101.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.111"></a>
<p><h3>AS.111 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.101">AS.101</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First-year General Military Course. Includes a study of Air Force customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and military commands. Also includes studying the environment of an Air Force officer and learning about areas of opportunity available to commissioned officers, as well as interviews, guidance, and information to increase the understanding, motivation, and performance of other cadets.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.112"></a>
<h3>AS.112 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.111">AS.111</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.102">AS.102</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Includes a study of Air Force customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and military commands. Also includes studying the environment of an Air Force officer and learning about areas of opportunity available to commissioned officers, as well as interviews, guidance, and information to increase the understanding, motivation, and performance of other cadets. AS.112 is a continuation of AS.111.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.201"></a>
<p><h3>AS.201 The Evolution of USAF Air and Space Power
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.102">AS.102</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.211">AS.211</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey designed to facilitate the transition from Air Force ROTC cadet to Air Force ROTC officer candidate. Featured topics include: Air Force heritage and leaders, Quality Air Force, an introduction to ethics and values, introduction to leadership, group leadership problems, and continuing application of communication skills. AS.202 is a continuation of AS.201.
<br><I>T. Hubbard</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.202"></a>
<h3>AS.202 The Evolution of USAF Air and Space Power
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.201">AS.201</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.212">AS.212</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-1
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-147</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey designed to facilitate the transition from Air Force ROTC cadet to Air Force ROTC officer candidate. Topics include Air Force heritage and leaders, Quality Air Force, an introduction to ethics and values, introduction to leadership, group leadership problems, and continuing application of communication skills. AS.202 is a continuation of AS.201.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.211"></a>
<p><h3>AS.211 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.112">AS.112</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.201">AS.201</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes development of techniques used to direct and inform. Students are assigned leadership and management positions in the AS.111 programs. AS.212 is a continuation of AS.211.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.212"></a>
<h3>AS.212 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.211">AS.211</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.202">AS.202</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasizes development of techniques used to direct and inform. Students are assigned leadership and management positions in the AS.111 programs described above. AS.212 is a continuation of AS.211.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.301"></a>
<p><h3>AS.301 Air Force Leadership Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.202">AS.202</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.311">AS.311</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of leadership, quality management fundamentals, professional knowledge, Air Force doctrine, leadership ethics, and communication skills required of an Air Force junior officer. Case studies are used to examine Air Force leadership and management situations as a means of demonstrating and exercising practical application of the concepts being studied. AS.302 is a continuation of AS.301.
<br><I>S. Ott</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.302"></a>
<h3>AS.302 Air Force Leadership Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.301">AS.301</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.312">AS.312</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R EVE (3-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of leadership, quality management fundamentals, professional knowledge, Air Force doctrine, leadership ethics, and communication skills required of an Air Force junior officer. Case studies are used to examine Air Force leadership and management situations as a means of demonstrating and exercising practical application of the concepts being studied. AS.302 is a continuation of AS.301.
<br><I>K. Dillard</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.311"></a>
<p><h3>AS.311 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.212">AS.212</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.301">AS.301</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Consists of activities classified as advanced leadership experiences that involve the planning and controlling of military activities of the cadet corps and the preparation and presentation of briefings and other oral and written communications. Also includes interviews, guidance, and information to increase the understanding, motivation, and performance of other cadets. AS.312 is a continuation of AS.311.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.312"></a>
<h3>AS.312 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.311">AS.311</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.302">AS.302</a></I>
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Consists of activities classified as advanced leadership experiences that involve the planning and controlling of military activities of the cadet corps and the preparation and presentation of briefings and other oral and written communications. Also includes interviews, guidance, and information to increase the understanding, motivation, and performance of other cadets. AS.312 is a continuation of AS.311.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.401"></a>
<p><h3>AS.401 National Security Affairs/Preparation for Active Duty
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.302">AS.302</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.411">AS.411</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the national security process, regional studies, advanced leadership ethics, and Air Force doctrine. Special topics of interest focus on the military as a profession, officership, military justice, civilian control of the military, preparation for active duty, and current issues affecting military professionalism. Within this structure, continued emphasis on refining communication skills. AS.402 is a continuation of AS.401.
<br><I>S. Ott</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.402"></a>
<h3>AS.402 National Security Affairs/Preparation for Active Duty
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.401">AS.401</a> or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.412">AS.412</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-073</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the national security process, regional studies, advanced leadership ethics, and Air Force doctrine. Special topics of interest focus on the military as a profession, officership, military justice, civilian control of the military, preparation for active duty, and current issues affecting military professionalism. Within this structure, continued emphasis on refining communication skills. AS.402 is a continuation of AS.401.
<br><I>S. Ott</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<a name="AS.511"></a>
<p><h3>AS.511 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="mASa.html#AS.412">AS.412</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Consists of activities classified as advanced leadership experiences to continue developing critical leadership, managerial and communication skills along with maintaining an active, physical lifestyle needed in today's Air Force.  AS.512 is a continuation of AS.511.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="AS.512"></a>

<a name="AS.812"></a>
<p><h3>AS.812 Leadership Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Cadets develop critical leadership, managerial and communication skills while maintaining an active, physical lifestyle needed in today's Air Force. Consists of activities classified as advanced leadership experiences that involve mentoring the cadet corps, special projects, and event planning.
<br><I>P. Dela Cruz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Military Science<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/armyrotc/"><i>MS Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=MS&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++MS&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>MS.00-MS.499</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>ROTC subjects do not carry academic credit at MIT, but they can be counted toward the PE requirement.  Up to two points per year with a maximum of four points.
<h2>Military Science</h2>
<a name="MS.101"></a>
<p><h3>MS.101 Introduction to the Army and Critical Thinking
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="mMSa.html#MS.102">MS.102</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-3-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M7.30-9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=NORTH SHORE">NORTH SHORE</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the personal challenges and competencies that are critical for effective leadership and communication. Explores how the personal development of cultural understanding, goal setting, time management, stress management and comprehensive fitness relate to leadership, officership, and the Army profession.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Davis</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Davis</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="MS.102"></a>
<p><h3>MS.102 Introduction to the Profession of Arms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="mMSa.html#MS.101">MS.101</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W8-9.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-159</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the professional challenges and competencies that are needed for effective execution of the profession of arms and Army communication. Explores how Army ethics and values shape the Army and the specific ways they are inculcated into Army culture. Investigates the Army leadership dimensions, attributes, and core competencies and gain practical experience using critical communication skills.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Davis</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Davis</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="MS.110"></a>
<p><h3>MS.110 American Military History
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-159</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops an understanding of the effects the US military and American society have on each other through thematic exploration of American military history in the context of broader US history, and military strategy and global involvement. Through readings, oral and written presentations, and exams, students describe the role of the US military, its evolution, and its impact on society and technology; and critically analyze an armed conflict using the principles of war.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Mcdonough</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Mcdonough</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="MS.201"></a>
<p><h3>MS.201 Leadership and Decision Making
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mMSa.html#MS.102">MS.102</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-3-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Familiarizes students with the professional practice of ethics within the Army by exploring Army values and ethics along with the fundamentals of leadership, personal development, and tactics at the small unit level. Explores ethical and tactical decision-making case studies. Students required to demonstrate writing skills and present information briefings as preparation for development in becoming successful future officers.
<br><I>D. Brown</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="MS.202"></a>
<p><h3>MS.202 Army Doctrine and Team Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mMSa.html#MS.201">MS.201</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-3-1
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W6-8</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-147</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F8-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=NORTH SHORE">NORTH SHORE</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students practice and apply fundamentals of Army leadership, officership, Army values and ethics, personal development, and small unit tactics at the squad level. Provides systematic and specific feedback on individual leader attributes, values, and core leader competencies. Students demonstrate writing skills and present information briefings as preparation for development in becoming successful future officers.
<br><I>D. Brown</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="MS.301"></a>
<p><h3>MS.301 Applied Team Leadership
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mMSa.html#MS.202">MS.202</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops student proficiency in planning and executing complex operations, functioning as a leader of small and medium sized teams, assessing operational environments, accepting prudent risk, and leading fellow students. Through assignment to leadership positions in the ROTC Battalion, students are directly responsible for the training, development, and well-being of underclass students assigned to their charge. Students plan scenario based missions at the squad level using troop leading procedures and combat orders, enhancing their oral and written communications, creative thinking, and problem solving skills.
<br><I>N. Kassim</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="MS.302"></a>
<p><h3>MS.302 Applied Leadership in Small Unit Operations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mMSa.html#MS.301">MS.301</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R8-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-159</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-147</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Familiarizes students with group dynamics and how personal identity influences leadership. Students explore bases of power, influence tactics, and leadership self-assessments. Through assignment to leadership positions in the ROTC Battalion, students are responsible for the training, development, and well-being of underclass students. Students experiment with counseling, receive peer feedback, and explore elements of the Army Profession. Students build competence with the basics of maneuvering a platoon, the principles of patrolling including raids, recons, and ambushes.
<br><I>N. Kassim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="MS.401"></a>
<p><h3>MS.401 Officership: Mission Command and the Army Officer
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mMSa.html#MS.302">MS.302</a>
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops proficiency in planning and executing complex operations, functioning as a member of an organizational staff, assessing risk, making ethical decisions, and leading fellow students.  Through assignment to leadership positions in the ROTC Battalion, students plan and lead the execution of labs, directing and controlling the corps of cadets, enhancing their oral and written communications, and improving their application of troop-leading procedures and problem solving.
<br><I>P. Godfrin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="MS.402"></a>
<p><h3>MS.402 Officership: Mission Command and Company Grade Leadership
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mMSa.html#MS.401">MS.401</a>
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T7.30-9.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-147</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>R3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=NORTH SHORE">NORTH SHORE</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the US National Security Structure and how the Army operates as part of the joint force in a whole of government approach. Studies how various operational variables affect military operations. Through assignment to leadership positions, students actively plan and execute training within the program, direct and control an organization, enhance oral and written communications, and apply troop-leading procedures. Students also examine past leaders through a staff ride to the battlefields of Lexington and Concord.
<br><I>P. Godfrin</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
<hr width="90%" align="center">

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Naval Science<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/navyrotc/"><i>NS Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=NS&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>NS.00-NS.499</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>ROTC subjects do not carry academic credit at MIT, but they can be counted toward the PE requirement.  Up to two points per year with a maximum of four points.
<h2>Naval Science</h2>
<a name="NS.100"></a>
<p><h3>NS.100 Naval Science Leadership Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.200">NS.200</A>, <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.300">NS.300</A>, <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.400">NS.400</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W6.30-8.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Leadership seminar addresses professional issues of military leadership, ethics, foreign policy, internal affairs and naval warfare doctrine. Subject matter centers on preparation for commissioned service in the US Naval Forces by examining the role of the junior officer in the employment of naval power. Mostly student originated, the periods include panel discussions, practical applications, guest lecturers from academia, and speakers currently serving in deployed naval forces.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Langel</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Langel</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.11"></a>
<p><h3>NS.11 Introduction to Naval Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to naval science. General introduction to the US Navy and Marine Corps. Emphasizes organizational structure, warfare components, and assigned roles/missions of US Navy/USMC. Covers all aspects of naval service from its relative position within DOD, to specific warfare communities/career paths. Also includes basic elements of leadership/Navy core values. Designed to give student initial exposure to many elements of naval culture. Provides students with conceptual framework and working vocabulary. Completion of MIT NROTC Orientation Program strongly recommended.
<br><I>R. Wielgus</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.12"></a>
<p><h3>NS.12 Seapower and Maritime Affairs
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR7.30-9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-172</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A study of the US Navy and the influence of sea power upon history. Incorporates both a historical and political science process to explore the major events, attitudes, personalities, and circumstances which have imbued the US Navy with its proud history and rich tradition. Deals with issues of national imperatives in peacetime as well as war, varying maritime philosophies which were interpreted into naval strategies/doctrines, budgetary concerns which shaped force realities, and the pursuit of American diplomatic objectives, concluding with the current search for direction in the post-Cold War era and beyond.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.200"></a>
<p><h3>NS.200 Naval Science Leadership Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.100">NS.100</A>, <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.300">NS.300</A>, <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.400">NS.400</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W6.30-8.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Leadership seminar addresses professional issues of military leadership, ethics, foreign policy, internal affairs and naval warfare doctrine. Subject matter centers on preparation for commissioned service in the US Naval Forces by examining the role of the junior officer in the employment of naval power. Mostly student originated, the periods include panel discussions, practical applications, guest lecturers from academia, and speakers currently serving in deployed naval forces.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.21"></a>
<p><h3>NS.21 Leadership and Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores leadership from the military perspective taught by professors of military science from the Army, Navy and Air Force. Survey of basic principles for successfully managing and leading people, particularly in public service and the military. Develops skills in topics such as oral and written communication techniques, planning, team building, motivation, ethics, decision-making, and managing change. Relies heavily on interactive experiential classes with case studies, student presentations, role plays, and discussion. Also appropriate for non-management science majors.
<br><I>B. Masterson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.22"></a>
<p><h3>NS.22 Navigation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR7-8.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-051</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive study of the theory, principles, and procedures of piloting and maritime navigation, including mathematics of navigation, practical work involving navigational instruments, sight reduction by <I>pro forma </I>and computerized methods, charts, publications, and voyage planning. CORTRAMID cruise recommended.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.300"></a>
<p><h3>NS.300 Naval Science Leadership Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.100">NS.100</A>, <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.200">NS.200</A>, <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.400">NS.400</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W6.30-8.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Leadership seminar addresses professional issues of military leadership, ethics, foreign policy, internal affairs and naval warfare doctrine. Subject matter centers on preparation for commissioned service in the US Naval Forces by examining the role of the junior officer in the employment of naval power. Mostly student originated, the periods include panel discussions, practical applications, guest lecturers from academia, and speakers currently serving in deployed naval forces.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.31"></a>
<p><h3>NS.31 Naval Ships Systems I: Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lecture series on technological fundamentals of applied and planned naval ships Systems from an engineering viewpoint. Topics include stability, propulsion, ship control and systems.
<br><I>H. Nowak</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.32"></a>
<p><h3>NS.32 Naval Ship Systems II Weapons
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mNSa.html#NS.31">NS.31</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T7-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-149</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Overview of the properties and behavior of electromagnetic radiation pertaining to maritime applications. Topics include communications, radar detection, electro-optics, tracking and guidance systems. Sonar and underwater sound propagation also discussed. Examples taken from systems found on naval ships and aircraft. Selected readings on naval weapons and fire control systems. Physics I (GIR) and Calculus II (GIR) recommended.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.33"></a>
<p><h3>NS.33 Evolution of Warfare
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Traces development of warfare from dawn of recorded history to present, focusing on the impact of major military theorists, strategists, tacticians, and technological developments. Seeks to understand the relationships between military training, weaponry, strategies and tactics, and the societies and cultures that produce and then are defended by those military structures. By examining the association between a society and its military, students acquire basic sense of strategy, develop an understanding of military alternatives, and see the impact of historical precedents on military thoughts and actions.
<br><I>M. Hritz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.400"></a>
<p><h3>NS.400 Naval Science Leadership Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.100">NS.100</A>, <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.200">NS.200</A>, <A HREF="mNSa.html#NS.300">NS.300</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-2-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W6.30-8.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-270</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Leadership seminar addresses professional issues of military leadership, ethics, foreign policy, internal affairs and naval warfare doctrine. Subject matter centers on preparation for commissioned service in the US Naval Forces by examining the role of the junior officer in the employment of naval power. Mostly student originated, the periods include panel discussions, practical applications, guest lecturers from academia, and speakers currently serving in deployed naval forces.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.41"></a>
<p><h3>NS.41 Navigation and Naval Operations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Recommended first class cruise and <a href="mNSa.html#NS.22">NS.22</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Comprehensive study of tactical and strategic considerations to the employment of naval forces, including communications, tactical formations and dispositions, relative motion, maneuvering board, and nautical rules of the road.
<br><I>R. Geer</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.42"></a>
<p><h3>NS.42 Leadership and Ethics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mNSa.html#NS.21">NS.21</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T7-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-110</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes ethical decision-making and leadership principles. Students read and discuss texts written by such philosophers as Aristotle, Kant, and Mill to gain familiarity with the realm of ethical theory. Students then move on to case studies in which they apply these theories to resolve moral dilemmas. Provides a basic background in the duties and responsibilities of a junior division and watch officer; strong emphasis on the junior officer's responsibilities in training, counseling, and career development. Student familiarization with equal opportunity and drug/alcohol rehabilitation programs. Principles of leadership reinforced through leadership case studies.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="NS.43"></a>
<p><h3>NS.43 Amphibious Warfare
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=W59">W59-149</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>This seminar course is an introduction to the fundamental concepts and history of amphibious warfare, from the classical period to the present day.  Emphasis is placed on analytical study and critical thought rather than memorization of historical facts.  Students will trace the evolution of amphibious warfare through analysis of case studies using amphibious and maneuver doctrine as a framework.  By the end of this course, students will comprehend modern employment concepts and challenges relating to the use of amphibious forces.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>NS.00-NS.499</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table>
