<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Engineering School-Wide Electives<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=SWE&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>SWE</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="SWE.006"></a>
<p><h3>  Engineering Innovation and Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m2b.html#2.723">2.723</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.902">6.902</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.662">16.662</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-1-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based seminar in innovative design thinking develops students' ability to conceive, implement, and evaluate successful projects in any engineering discipline. Lectures focus on the iterative design process and techniques to enhance creative analysis. Students use this process to design and implement robust voice recognition applications using a simple web-based system. They also give presentations and receive feedback to sharpen their communication skills for high emotional and intellectual impact. Guest lectures illustrate multidisciplinary approaches to design thinking.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Kotelly</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Kotelly</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.007"></a>
<p><h3>  Engineering Leadership Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.650">16.650</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.913">6.913[J]</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.667">16.667[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m6c.html#6.912">6.912</a></I> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-2-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to leadership frameworks, models and cases within an engineering context, in an interactive, practice-based environment, honing leadership and teamwork skills. Students participate in guided reflections on individual and team successes, and discover opportunities for improvement in controlled settings. Activities include design-implement activities, role-plays, simulations, small group discussions, and performance and peer assessments by and of other students. Content throughout the term is frequently student-driven. First year Gordon Engineering Leadership Program (GEL) students register for 6.911. Second year GEL Program students register for 6.913. Preference to students enrolled in the Bernard M. Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.008"></a>
<p><h3>  Engineering Leadership
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.912">6.912</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.651">16.651</A>)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</a></I> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-0-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to the models and methods of engineering leadership within the contexts of conceiving, designing, implementing and operating products, processes and systems. Introduces the Capabilities of Effective Engineering Leaders, and models and theories related to the capabilities. Discusses the appropriate times and reasons to use particular models to deliver engineering success. Includes occasional guest speakers or panel discussions. May be repeated for credit once with permission of instructor. Preference to first-year students in the Gordon Engineering Leadership Program.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Magarian</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Magarian</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.009"></a>
<p><h3>  Engineering Leadership Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.913">6.913</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.667">16.667</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.911">6.911[J]</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.650">16.650[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</a>
<br>Units: 0-2-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to leadership frameworks, models and cases within an engineering context, in an interactive, practice-based environment, honing leadership and teamwork skills. Students participate in guided reflections on individual and team successes, and discover opportunities for improvement in controlled settings. Activities include design-implement activities, role-plays, simulations, small group discussions, and performance and peer assessments by and of other students. Content throughout the term is frequently student-driven. First year Gordon Engineering Leadership Program (GEL) students register for 6.911. Second year GEL Program students register for 6.913. Preference to students enrolled in the second year of the Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.010"></a>
<p><h3>  Engineering Systems Analysis for Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1a.html#1.146">1.146</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.861">16.861</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.332">IDS.332</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers theory and methods to identify, value, and implement flexibility in design, also known as "real options." Topics include definition of uncertainties, simulation of performance for scenarios, screening models to identify desirable flexibility, decision and lattice analysis, and multidimensional economic evaluation. Students demonstrate proficiency through an extended application to a systems design of their choice. Provides a complement to research or thesis projects. Meets with IDS.333 first half of term. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. De Neufville</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.011"></a>
<p><h3>  Ethics for Engineers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1a.html#1.082">1.082</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.900">2.900</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.904">6.904</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.01">10.01</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.014">22.014</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.9041">6.9041</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrates classical readings that provide an overview of ethics with a survey of case studies that focus on ethical problems arising in the practice of engineering. Readings taken from a variety of sources, such as Aristotle, Machiavelli, Bacon, Hobbes, Locke, the Founding Fathers, and the Bible. Case studies include written analyses and films that address engineering disasters, biotechnology, court cases, ethical codes, and the ultimate scope and aims of engineering. Students taking independent inquiry version 6.9041 expand the scope of their term project.
<br>Fall: <I>B. Trout</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Trout</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.012"></a>
<p><h3>  Introduction to Modeling and Simulation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1a.html#1.021">1.021</A>, <A HREF="m3a.html#3.021">3.021</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.333">10.333</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.00">22.00</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic concepts of computer modeling and simulation in science and engineering. Uses techniques and software for simulation, data analysis and visualization. Continuum, mesoscale, atomistic and quantum methods used to study fundamental and applied problems in physics, chemistry, materials science, mechanics, engineering, and biology. Examples drawn from the disciplines above are used to understand or characterize complex structures and materials, and complement experimental observations.
<br><I>M. Buehler, R. Gomez-Bombarelli</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.015"></a>
<p><h3>  Management in Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m2c.html#2.96">2.96</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.930">6.930</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.806">10.806</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.653">16.653</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction and overview of engineering management. Financial principles, management of innovation, technical strategy and best management practices. Case study method of instruction emphasizes participation in class discussion. Focus is on the development of individual skills and management tools. Restricted to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>J. Chun</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.016"></a>
<p><h3>  Project Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.914">6.914</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.669">16.669</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-2-1 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students attend a four-day off-site workshop where an introduction to basic principles, methods, and tools for project management in a realistic context are covered. In teams, students create a plan for a project of their choice in one of several areas, including aircraft modification, factory automation, enterprise software, flood prevention engineering, solar farm engineering, among others. Develops skills applicable to the management of complex development projects. Topics include cost-benefit analysis, resource and cost estimation, and project control and delivery, which are practiced during an experimental, team-based activity. Case studies highlight projects in both hardware/construction and software. Preference to students in the Bernard M. Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program.
<br><I>O. de Weck, J. Feiler, L. McGonagle</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.017"></a>
<p><h3>  UPOP Engineering Practice Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1c.html#1.EPE">1.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.EPE">2.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.EPE">3.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.EPE">6.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m10b.html#10.EPE">10.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m16a.html#16.EPE">16.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.EPE">22.EPE</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2c.html#2.EPW">2.EPW</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-0-1 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides sophomores with guided practice in finding opportunities and excelling in the world of practice. Building on the skills and relationships acquired in the Engineering Practice Workshop, students receive coaching to articulate goals, invoke the UPOP network of mentors and employers, identify and pursue opportunities and negotiate terms of their summer assignment. Students complete a 10-12 week internship, which includes filing three progress reports, conducting one informational interview, and possibly hosting a site visit by MIT staff.  Returning to campus as juniors, UPOP students take part in reflective exercises that aid assimilation of learning objectives and reinforce the cognitive link between all aspects of the UPOP experience and disciplinary fields of study. Sequence begins in the spring of sophomore year and ends in the fall of junior year.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Crim</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Crim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SWE.018"></a>
<p><h3>  UPOP Engineering Practice Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1c.html#1.EPW">1.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.EPW">2.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.EPW">3.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.EPW">6.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m10b.html#10.EPW">10.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m16a.html#16.EPW">16.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.EPW">20.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.EPW">22.EPW</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops foundational skills for the world of practice in science, technology, and engineering. Sophomores receive classroom instruction, and one-on-one and small-group coaching in basics of professional identity building. They attend field trips to local employers and receive job interview practice, coached by industry volunteers. Over IAP, students attend a weeklong Team Training Camp of experiential learning modules - led by MIT faculty with the help of MIT alums and other senior professionals in business, engineering, and science where students participate in creative simulations, team problem-solving challenges, and oral presentations, and practice networking with employers. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Crim</I><br>IAP: <I>J. Crim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
<hr width="90%" align="center">

<h1 align="center">Special Programs<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=SP&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>Interphase EDGE, Program XL, Terrascope, FASI</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p><a href="#PIP">Interphase EDGE</a><br><a href="#PXL">Seminar XL</a><br><a href="#ISP">Terrascope</a><br><a href="#FASI">Freshman/Alumni Summer Internship Program</a>
<h2><a name="PIP"></a>Interphase EDGE: Pre-Freshman Summer Component</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/ome/programs-services/interphase/index.html"><i>Interphase EDGE Home</i></a></b>
<a name="SP.100"></a>
<p><h3>SP.100 Interphase
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Commitment to register as a freshman in the Fall
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interphase is a seven-week program designed to enhance the academic success of students entering MIT. The program has a dual focus: it gives students an introduction to the MIT experience by exposing them to the rigors of a full subject load while simultaneously preparing them for academic success beyond MIT. The program includes calculus; chemistry; physical education;  physics; writing, oral presentation and teamwork skills; and supporting academic activities, including small-group learning. Students can earn transcript credit for subjects taken in the program, sometimes resulting in advanced placement in corresponding subjects taken in the Fall. Activities include day trips to area cultural, recreational, and business sites. Students participate in a range of personal and educational development seminars and activities designed to ensure their smooth transition to college life.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<p><p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><a name="PXL"></a>Seminar XL</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/ome/programs-services/seminar-xl/index.html"><i>Seminar XL Home</i></a></b>
<a name="SP.110"></a>
<p><h3>SP.110 Program XL: You Can Be a Success at MIT
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: First-year undergraduate standing
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Academic enrichment program for first-year students, XL utilizes the innovative and effective small-group learning concept to enhance academic performance in calculus and science. Students meet in study groups of five to six participants with facilitators trained in effective classroom techniques and concept focus. Study groups help students to reinforce concepts learned in the regular curriculum, and help them gain mastery of concepts and problems that are often more challenging than those dealt with during lecture. Emphasizes the full participation of each student with the facilitator acting as guide. The regularity of weekly meetings enhances the students' understanding of MIT's academic expectations. After the initial meetings, students are encouraged to take more responsibility and to lead the group in problem-solving sessions. Each study group meets for a minimum of three hours each week. The meeting time is set by the XL facilitator based on students' schedules.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Uchima</I><br>IAP: <I>L. Uchima</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SP.120"></a>
<h3>SP.120 Program XL: You Can Be a Success at MIT
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: First-year undergraduate standing
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Academic enrichment program for first-year students, XL utilizes the innovative and effective small-group learning concept to enhance academic performance in calculus and science. Students meet in study groups of five to six participants with facilitators trained in effective classroom techniques and concept focus. Study groups help students to reinforce concepts learned in the regular curriculum, and help them gain mastery of concepts and problems that are often more challenging than those dealt with during lecture. Emphasizes the full participation of each student with the facilitator acting as guide. The regularity of weekly meetings enhances the students' understanding of MIT's academic expectations. After the initial meetings, students are encouraged to take more responsibility and to lead the group in problem-solving sessions. Each study group meets for a minimum of three hours each week. The meeting time is set by the XL facilitator based on students' schedules.
<br><I>L. Uchima</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<p><p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><a name="ISP"></a>Terrascope</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/terrascope/www/"><i>Terrascope Home</i></a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?termId=&departmentId=+ISP&subjectCode=&instructorName=&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a>&nbsp;<a href="http://web.mit.edu/is/cert/"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b>
<p>For descriptions of subjects offered through the Terrascope Program, refer to 12.000 Solving Complex Problems and 1.016 Introduction to Earth System Engineering and Science.
<a name="SP.35UR"></a>
<p><h3>SP.35UR Undergraduate Research in Terrascope
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Undergraduate research opportunities in Terrascope.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Epstein</I><br>IAP: <I>A. Epstein</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Epstein</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SP.360"></a>
<p><h3>SP.360 Terrascope Radio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-168</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An exploration of radio as a medium of expression and communication, particularly the communication of complex scientific or technical information to general audiences. Examines the ingredients of effective radio programming, drawing extensively on examples from both commercial and public radio. Student teams produce, assemble, narrate, record and broadcast/webcast radio programs on topics related to the complex environmental issue that is the focus of the year's Terrascope subjects. Includes multiple individual writing assignments that explore the constraints and opportunities in radio as a medium. Limited to 15 first-year students.
<br><I>A. Epstein</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=SP.360');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SP.3S50"></a>
<p><h3>SP.3S50 Special Subject: Terrascope
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers areas of study not included in the regular Terrascope curriculum. Preference to students in Terrascope.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Epstein</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Epstein</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<p><p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><a name="FASI"></a>Freshman/Alumni Summer Internship Program</h2>
<p><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/fasip/www/NewPage/"><i>F/ASIP Home</i></a></b>
<a name="SP.800"></a>
<p><h3>SP.800 Freshmen/Alumni Summer Internship Program
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-0
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Prepares freshmen for summer internship or research experiences. Enables students to explore their professional interests and careers early, providing an edge in the increasingly competitive internship search process. Includes sessions on self-assessment and career exploration, professional etiquette, internship search skills, interviewing, communications, networking, and dynamics in the workplace. Attendance at the sessions is mandatory.
<br><I>T. Menghi</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="SP.801"></a>
<p><h3>SP.801 Freshmen/Alumni Summer Internship Program II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mSPa.html#SP.800">SP.800</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students who have completed the subject requirements for SP.800 and work in an approved internship or research experience are eligible for SP.801, the second component of the Freshmen/Alumni Summer Internship Program. Students continue their career development and prepare for their sophomore internship search through this course.
<br><I>M. Pepin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
